description:
I've worked round the corner for so long and each week I tell myself I'll go. I FINALLY got around to going Saturday lunch time with my dad. I kind of half wish I hadn't, because I don't know how I'm going to stop myself eating here every day. 
We were the first customers of the day and they weren't finished setting up the dining room yet, but we were welcomed so warmly. My dad was convinced to have a beer - they were only $4 because, I guess, it's FiDi at the weekend. 
We ordered imperial rolls and fresh shrimp rolls to start. They were good and super fresh, however the sauce with the shrimp rolls was quite bland. I wish it had either been a stronger peanutty sauce or stronger flavours in the roll (maybe cilantro?). I don't know. Something was missing. 
But then it happened. Number 22. Curry noodle soup. It was incredible - really tender noodles and veg in the sweetest mild curry broth. The portion was huge, but it was so great I didn't leave a drop.
author: Poppy C.

description: Unbelievable curry fish noodle soup!! Best I've ever had. And you can't beat the prices.
author: Alyssa G.

description: Sai deserves four stars for their food - it is comforting, filling, and authentic. However, the restaurant ambiance is less than comforting, as it is not particularly clean, both inside and outside of the establishment. I have eaten there once, and was a bit concerned about the overall cleanliness, but that hasn't stopped me from ordering takeout time and time again (out of sight, out of mind??). Regardless, it's affordable and quick if you call your order in and take it to go. Their curry chicken pho is perfect for cold days, and I also really enjoy the vermicelli bowls and spring rolls. Definitely try their imperial rolls as well, they are crispy without being greasy.
author: Regina L.

description: Reliable, convenient and pretty damn food.   I won't lie, I only ever order the beef pho, vermicelli with 5 spice con or imperial rolls.  Oh, and great service and well priced for the location.
author: Kendall B.

description:
I'm hesitant to give a 4 so probably I will come back another time to try Bun Rieu.
I had bun bo Hue today. Not bad. The taste is 7/10 but there was too little meat. Beef slice is really thin and I love my beef to be thick and tender. It's really spicy probably since I ordered in Vietnamese.
author: Vy T.

description: Waitress took my order from across the room and barely turned around. I ordered a spicy trims soup which was pretty watery and not very flavorful. Pretty consistent with other reviews here.
author: M S.

description: The real deal. Green curry. Gracious service. Tasty and not too heavy for an evening. Visit this gem between the confluence of downtown and culture.
author: John G.

description:
An abundant menu which made it hard to choose from. There's really not much to say about the service or cleanliness of Vietnamese establishments. They're all the same and I don't mind at all as long as the taste of their food delivers. A coworker of mine ordered the coconut soup and I ordered the vermacelli. The vermacelli wasn't anything memorable. For some reason, mine was the last dish to come out and it wasn't even a hot dish! 

The place gets packed and for much reason. Service is fast and food is plentiful and good! I don't see anything wrong with this place. Why 3 stars you may ask? Because it's not the best Vietnamese food I've had nor is it the cheapest.
author: Jenna T.

description: Oh no... I ordered take-out and the food came looking like left-overs (amount wise). This stuff is very much cheap take-out food that isn't very cheap. The chicken basil and fish clay pot basically tasted the exact same and was over sauced with their sour/basily mixture. Along with that I got 2 small takeout boxes worth of rice. Nuupe. I'm sure they have some solid dishes but I wouldn't risk it next time.
author: Lydia Z.

description:
Oh Sai's....I have such a weird relationship with this place.  I really don't think their food is all that great, but I come here at least once or twice a month simply because there aren't any other Vietnamese places near my work.  

My go to's are:

Lamb or beef curry noodles
Bun Rieu
Pho
Rice Plate with every topping possible

The food isn't terrible and after 5-6 times coming here you know what you're getting.  Anyways 4 stars for hard working mom n pops that are just making a living.  If they went away I'd be so sad.  I hope I don't lose any yelp cred for giving them 4 stars for not so great viet food.
author: Vince L.

description:
My coworkers and I came here for lunch around 11:45, and it was already starting to get pretty packed. Luckily we had made reservations over the phone beforehand, so we were able to get seated immediately.

It was my first time here, so I decided to try their pork chops with rice($10). I had that recently at another Vietnamese restaurant and it was delicious. However, I was very disappointed by the dish here. The pork chop was not the cut of meat I was expecting, and was kind of dry and bland to boot. There wasn't a strong grilled flavor that I've come to associate with this dish. Also the portions were disappointingly small compared to some of what my coworkers ordered at about the same price point.

I wouldn't mind giving this place another shot, but now I know never to get the pork chops with rice dish again. One of my coworkers ordered the beef stew noodle soup and I tried a bite, it was delicious! Maybe that's the thing to get here...
author: Dianna H.

description:
Sai's is conveniently located nearby my workplace, and I was currently craving Vietnamese food. I was contemplating between ordering either the rice claypot with chicken and shrimp OR the pho bo. I went with the latter and ordered it from my office.

-They told me my order would be done within 10-15 minutes, the typical wait time for a takeout order of pho. Although I gave it time and walked slowly from my office, I still had to wait in the restaurant, which was fine. They accept cash and card as payment, which is perfect considering that some Asian restaurants are cash only.

I didn't know what to expect since I've never ordered takeout pho. I didn't want to pay tips, and I've read previous reviews of sanitary issues. Upon eating the pho from its plastic container, I noticed that the noodles were clumped together, and the ingredients were mainly on the top, inconvenient with the soup ratio. It was delicious, probably because I was craving pho. I would go back in person to eat at Sai's, and probably try the rice claypot with chicken and shrimp.
author: Erica K.

description: Wanted Pho and i got a great bowl.  Nice restaurant and staff was very nice.  Pho was tasty and spring rolls were as well.
author: Theresa H.

description: First time here since I'm from the valley and I'm a pho expert, I've tried every pho place from San jose best, Sacramento best and los Angeles finest pho place. When I stubble upon this mom and pop's original Vietnamese place in downtown San Francisco I had to try the broth of the soup. Great authentic Vietnamese place and I highly recommend this place
author: hertz f.

description:
I am so glad my colleagues suggested Sai's for lunch! I had never been here and was barely aware of it.

On my first visit, I decided on the Rice in claypot with shrimp and chicken. The dish hit all the right notes! The jasmine rice was nicely starchy but not overly sticky, while slightly crunchy where it hit the searing hot walls of the claypot thus forming a lovely 'socarrat.' The chicken was a touch seared, the shrimp done just right and juicy, and the sauce with the mushroom and bok choy all topping the bowl of rice was scrumptious! I boxed half my meal as it was a pretty generous portion. 

On my second visit, I decided on the sauteed chicken with three mushrooms. The portion was huge, and came with a generous side of jasmine rice. Again, the sauce they used was delicious and was the perfect foil for the jasmine rice. However, I was a little disappointed with the chicken as it tasted more "steamed" than "sauteed". Except for curries, I belong to the group that prefer meat to get at least a little bit of sear before it is hit with the sauce. And since the dish was a "sauteed chicken" I expected it. The mushrooms however were tasty and cooked just right. The inch-long segments of scallions didn't add to the dish; I wish it were bokchoy or some other leafy greens instead. Again, I took half my meal home; when reheated, it tasted even better as the sauce had seeped into the jasmine rice it was sitting on.

Granted, on both occasions, I could have wolfed it all down but I was sated with just the half, and decided to savour my meal one more time.

The prices barely crosses over to the '$$' sign. Most are in the very low tens and could have easily wandered off into the '$' range.

With the price, the portion size, and mostly due to the flavours, I can see myself coming back repeatedly.
author: Umesh T.

description:
Sai's is Great! NOT "Bare Bones"!  They have been hustling at this leased location for 32 years.  Mom & Dad retired now.

I came to S.F. to visit a gov't building. On my mind was getting some good chow, at some point.  Some point ended up down the road.  The office had moved twice in one year, not updating Google Maps.  I asked S.F. bus drivers where Stevenson St was, but it turned out to be a side street.

I had walked past SAI'S at lunchtime, it was packed. Much later now, 7:00 PM, it was raining.  I passed by Sai's on my way back to my car.  A Vietnamese lady was exiting Sai's with a to-go dinner.  I had eaten a sandwich earlier, but a steamy bowl of pho soup would be perfect with this rain.

I asked her opinion of Sai's.  She said Sai's was awesome, her favorite!  My stomach went SURVEY SAYS: *ding!* PHO!!  My choice was Pho Bun Cary Ga, chicken curry soup with thin vermicelli.  

Yams, squash, & taro in a mild yellow curry broth, with Huge chunks of chicken & thin vermicelli.  Mmmmm!  Thai basil, jalapeno slices, & lemon wedge on the side. You can request free fresh bean sprouts.

I felt comfortable, like at a friend's home.  Sai's is sensible, not "bare bones".  Look at the photos mounted on the wall, Hmong people smiling. 

Now, lunchtime.... is Not so "homey."  Monday through Friday the Financial District locals crash the gates like an army .  The Sai kitchen gets stressed as they try to accommodate all the Fi-Di peeps on their lunch hour.  Juggle your schedule to avoid this Rush Hour, and enjoy some home cooking from Sai's.
author: Amigo K.

description:
This negative review is mainly due to an experience I had and witnessed. The food is actually quite good. Not everything on the menu is great, so choose wisely. 

I am disgusted with how the owner treats his employees. The original owners are his parents. They've retired now and left their business in the hands of their trusted son, who mistreats his employees. 

My mom and I ate here this afternoon. After paying for our check, we wanted to sit a little longer and enjoy our tea. We asked one of the waiters, an older gentleman, to refill our pot. As he's refilling, the owner screams in Chinese, "WHY ARE YOU REFILLING THEIR TEAPOT?! THEY'VE ALREADY PAID!" 

Wow. Are you seriously screaming at him for adding hot water to used tea leaves? Are you that cheap, or do you just enjoy berating your employees? 

As we were sipping our tea, the same waiter begins to clean a table near us. The owner yells at him again asking, "WHY AREN'T YOU CLEANING THE OTHER TABLES?!" 

He hasn't even finished cleaning one table, and you already want him to move onto another? Why don't YOU get up off your ass and do it, instead of just yelling at your employees while not doing jack shit?

His parents should be disappointed in how he's running the restaurant. He has absolutely no respect for his employees and for elders. Shame on you.
author: Jenny Y.

description:
Sai's Pho is part office legend part convenience. Located just blocks from the TransAmerica building in the financial district the line usually stretches out the door. Because of the speedy service and SF weather, I've been here for the Pho many many times. 

They have a full service menu, but the damp dreariness that I so love about San Fran's FIDI makes this a must stop over location if you can tolerate lines and decent thai food. 

Expect soup nazi behavior.
author: Adina P.

description: Awesome - I'm addicted and it's in my 4 day rotation of must have when I make my frequent trips out west. I never grew up with Vietnamese cuisine and even after my reluctance to try it, now I can't eat enough of the basil, chiles, cilantro and lime. If in the City and you're craving the yummiest  Pho - this is the spot and so inexpensive.
author: Andrea R.

description: Great experience from the food to the service to the atmosphere. My girlfriend and I both got the five spices chicken and rice, and we split an order of imperial rolls. The imperial rolls were delicious; I easily could have eaten 30 instead of 3. The chicken and rice didn't disappoint either. 10/10 would recommend!!
author: Hunter K.

description: Sai's is a great 'working late' dinner place. I find the prices fair and the quality just good enough. A lot of the restaurants in the financial district are lunch places that close around 3, or are bars that aren't great to go to if you need food but also have to go back to the office. Sai's is nice and casual - don't expect the best meal of your life but it's comforting, tastes good, and fills you up!
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
We got lucky today cuz this place is always so crowded during lunch. Probably slow cuz of the Labor Day weekend. It was also hot today and they don't got no air conditioning. 
Food was really good. Especially the shrimp & chicken claypot rice and the imperial rolls. That claypot rice was hella good!! Im definitely gonna get that again.
author: Linda W.

description:
I've ordered here quite a few times since it's the closest Vietnamese restaurant to my work. I have tried most items on the menu. Their soup is kind of salty. Most items are overpriced for the quality and quantity. Compared to most pho places in the Bay Area (Fremont, San Jose), this place is disappointing. 

The staff is really nice, otherwise this would be two stars.
author: Catney A.

description:
I literally pass by Sai's Restaurant all the time but never noticed the lunchtime crowd or how giant this place is! My friend took me here on a lunch date on Tuesday afternoon. Even though there was a bunch of people waiting outside, there was no line to be seated. Everyone must have been waiting for take-out.

My first impression of this restaurant was dingy and outdated, not in the authentic way. All the waiters were nice, though. We were immediately given water, and our orders were taken. I got some sort of beef pho, which was brought out in light speed! Impressive for the size of the restaurant.

I couldn't finish most of my food because of a massive chorizo burrito I had earlier that day. The waiter expressed the utmost sadness at what looked like my discontent with the food. I felt bad! But I did pack up my leftovers to go. Overall it was a decent experience with great company. I'm glad there's a Vietnamese place around here!
author: Stefanie C.

description:
I came here with my friend after 6 PM and it was pretty empty. He ordered the chicken pho and I ordered the beef pho.

I thought the broth was quite flavorful. There was a lot of noodles in the bowl and they gave us the typical jalapenos, bean sprouts, limes, and basil leaves. However, I was a bit disappointed that the order didn't come with tripe/beef tendon, etc. But, I came out full & satisfied which is the most important thing.

The pricing was around $12 dollars with tax and tip.
author: Victor L.

description:
3.5 stars, rounding up to 4.  Pretty good food, decent prices, quick service. Slightly off-putting location, but I'd come back!

Bill came out to about $30 total to share this delightful amount of food: 
- SHRIMP SPRING ROLLS  (~$7): shrimp as expected (not particularly tasty), but the wrapper tasted like mochi which was interesting
- PHO GA/ chicken soup ($9.50): good amount of shredded white meat chicken, yay! healthy and predictable tasting. Came with very fresh bean sprouts too!
- SHRIMP + CHICKEN CLAY POT (~$12.5): tasty, healthy, crispy rice like the bibimbaps, yum. shrimp was surprisingly fresh, and chicken was tasty - bok choy and dried shiitake mushrooms were also tasty. Well marinated dark meat and a hefty amount of saucey cornstarchy salty goodness. Enjoyed this bc it reminded me of very homestyle asian cooking. 

Quite a bit of seating, but there's definitely a lunch rush - so come earlier than later. Clay pots here are where it's at.
author: Kristie C.

description: Really large portions of food and are packed with flavor. The reviews with bugs found were a bit concerning. On this particular visit, the guy waiter seemed to be a bit rude though have heard he's usually friendly. Perhaps a bad day?
author: Kimberly H.

description: They make the best Vietnamese crepe here and now they have a happy hour menu too! Got to try the tofu and calamari appetizer today, will be back for more! Took a co worker here and she fell in love with their ice coffee. I cannot wait to try their all their new desserts, seem to be Hawaiian inspired! Lady at the counter was super sweet and attentive to us, given how busy they were. Keep in mind I arrived around 1:00 - 1:15pm and no wait for a table for 2. Thanks again for taking care of us!
author: Tuyen C.

description: This place was delicious and the price is unbeatable. The service was very fast, and it was a quiet, calm atmosphere. I would love to go back and urge others to try it.
author: Julia O.

description: I won't go to this restaurant ever.  Servers not treating well with customers, and very bad food too... I strongly recommend not to go this restaurant.
author: Sneha K.

description: I ordered the seafood noodle soup.  The only authentic seafood in it was two shrimp.  Otherwise, it was a lot of noodles and pressed/fake seafood cakes and a few pieces of cabbage.
author: Suzy Q.

description: 3.5 stars. Place gets super busy quick. Must come early. I love their apps (egg rolls, spring rolls, pot stickers). The 5 spice chicken and their curry noodle are my favorite dishes. Their pho is only so so. Got to go into the heart of Chinatown for pho.
author: Karen H.

description: It's a hidden gem - a hole in the wall Vietnamese spot in the FiDi with low prices and fast service. Not  trendy at all. My pho was passable and I'll definitely return.
author: Andrew K.

description: Came here for lunch today with my buddy and we had the beef pho and some kind of fried pork egg roll..  Sorry, this review is lame because he ordered and I never looked at the menu.  I'll tell you what though, they hit you with the Jasmine tea right off the bat which I love, and the Pho was off the hook.  Loved it. I felt like a million bucks when we left.  It's pretty loud and pretty busy, kind of hot in there too. They opened the door right before we left for airflow but I was already dripping sweat. It's a me problem. Combo of food sweats and temp sweats i think. Anyway, good stuff.
author: Brian S.

description: Food, is really good. I like the chicken and shrimp rice claypot! Rice is crispy without it being burned and the chicken is tender and savory. The curry lamb is great too! The broth is really bold. The portion is quite large .The waiters are friendly and quick. The place is pretty quiet at night, so its very enjoyable. The price is standard around $12ish.
author: Elitè T.

description:
Downside of staying in the Financial District is that literally everything closes after 5. We weren't walking distance to many things, so I was thankful we stumbled upon this gem during our stay in December.

Place doesn't look like much. We came here for dinner twice. Delicious!! We've never had curry pho before, and it did not disappoint! The curry broth is out of this world! The only negative is the noodles... we've never had thick pho noodles before, so that was a little weird. It gets mushy in the broth, unlike the type of noodles we've had at other pho places. The imperial rolls were also great!

At nighttime, like around 7-8, it's pretty empty. Both times we were the only patrons inside. Crazy large portions. We each got our own bowl the first time (big mistake as we didn't have a fridge or microwave in our hotel room). The second time, we shared one.
author: Ryan C.

description: Weren't sure where the line to go eat and order pick up. Wish an employee would have come outside to tell customers or tourists. Other than that, it was good beef ball soup I had, and reasonable price for SF. Def come here for lunch or a quick eatery. Not bad.
author: Belle V.

description: Excellent pho. Go early to avoid lines. Perfect on a cold or rainy day. Ambience leaves something to be desired.
author: B. Y.

description: Pretty good vietnamese food. A little pricey, but considering this is in FiDi, it's not too bad. I think the people who run this is either Chinese, or Northern Viet. Pho is good, standard. I'd come back. Very friendly staff, too.
author: Marie D.

description:
I've been here twice and it's always a solid choice.  No frills and glamor, but good food at a pretty reasonable price.  I usually come here for a weekday lunch, but a little before the lunch hour, so there's never been a wait.  Not sure what it's like if you come at noon. 

This last visit I got the Vermicelli w/ Imperial Rolls & Chicken (the #88).  You can spice it up with a little Sriracha or sweeten it with another sauce they have at the table, but overall it's fresh, clean, tasty and filling.  

I'll definitely be back, especially as it gets colder outside.
author: Denis S.

description:
Stopped in for lunch after noticing how busy the place was and figured it must be good! 
The place is kinda small and was very crowded during lunchtime on a weekday. The service is okay, not slow but not friendly either. 
Their menus has a wide range of things and is easy to understand if you aren't familiar with Vietnamese food. Both of the dishes my husband and I ordered were very good portion sizes. I ordered the curry noodles and my husband got the chicken Pho. The dishes were good but I wouldn't say outstanding. 
Overall it's a okay option for lunch but nothing amazing, probably won't go back.
author: Christina M.

description: Great pho with a long line for a workday lunch.
author: Jim I.

description: Amazing food!! Seriously rice plate, pho, appetizers, Thai iced tea (my favorite) all delicious!!! Staff is very friendly and you get fast service for such an affordable price. Working in downtown you'll easily spend a lot of money for lunch. This place is affordable and the portions are huge!!! Looking forward to trying heir happy hour from 4-6pm!
author: Deborah E.

description:
Came here with a coworker around 12:30 with the intention of getting seats. It was so crowded! There was even people waiting outside (and on a rainy day too)! My coworker and I opted to order to go and take it back to the food back to the office and eat it in the kitchen. 

I ordered a mango beef over rice to go. First thought when I opened the container was "where's all the mango?!!". There were only FOUR little slices of mango. I kid you not... For ordering a dish with mango in the name, I kind of expected there to be a little bit more than four mediocre slices..

The food tasted rather plain. It didn't have any type of flavor in my opinion and was rather bland. A simple stir fry with beef, onions, carrots, bell peppers, and celery over rice. I felt like I could've made this at home. 

I do see a lot of people writing about the pho though. So maybe this place is more known for their pho, rather than their rice plates. I'll have to try the pho next time.
author: Cynthia T.

description: My favorite vietnamese place in sf fidi! Delicious pho and rice plates. They are generous with the sides (bean sprouts, basil, jalapeno). They usually get very busy so call in to make reservations or order ahead. Delicious food, reasonable price, friendly wait staff. What's not to love?
author: Naing L.

description:
Honestly really decent pho. 
I'm not a pho connoisseur so I'm not sure how much you can trust my opinion. 
The broth is more on the savory side, less sweet, which I personally prefer. I got the beef pho and the meat was all super tender, and the noodles were perfect. 

The bowl was huge and I could've split it into two meals, and this was all for about 10 dollars. Which, when you're talking San Francisco and the Financial District no less, is not bad in my book. 

Also great customer service here. The waiter who served me was extremely friendly and helpful. I think there were regulars there when I went and he knew their drink orders and such. I'm not in the area much, but I'll make sure to put this place on my bucket list if I ever find myself here again.  

Note, the restaurant isn't the cleanest looking (especially the bathroom) but it's something I can look past.
author: Jenny Z.

description:
I got the imperial rolls with noodles.  It was very tasty, and I am looking forward to trying other items on the menu.  The place is packed by noon, so show up early!

Also, they have a focus on customer service, so that really makes this place a 5 star operation.
author: dutchy s.

description:
There are cockroaches here. Repeat: there are COCKROACHES here, crawling on the walls, the tables, and sometimes food.

I ordered the crab soup. Service was quick and rude. Water and food came fast.

As I was eating, a cockroach crawled down the wall and on our table.

I searched the reviews for "bugs" and "cockroach" a ton of other people had the same, if not worse, experience.

I don't care how delicious the food is, I don't want to see cockroaches wondering around / on food.

And the food isn't even that good!
author: T L.

description: A great place for happy hour!! 50% off beers and $5 appetizers. They also have items during happy hour that aren't on the regular menu like salt and pepper calamari or prawns. Spicy fried tofu is a must! Those dish is soooooo good. Wasn't bad having some Bluemoon to wash it down.
author: Natalie L.

description: Ok, I'm currently having my lunch and I'm eating their 5 Spice Roast Chicken & Rice and all my mouth can say, "Holy, shatbaz, what came in here and made my taste buds sing!!" I mean, the restaurant is nothing to rave about but I guess how crowded it is, it must be a good place to have lunch. Anyway, I've had 5 Spice roast chicken from other places but, "Wow" Sai's is by far the best I've had. I'm going to come back and try the other food to see if this is a fluke or Sai does have great food!
author: Kathy T.

description:
I don't usually write reviews at yelp. As a matter of fact, this is my first review on yelp. I would have let it go but the manager deserve this.

We found a cockroach in the food and we said we wont pay for the the plate. Upon which the manager gets angry and starts screaming at us. Showed middle finger to my teammate and one of the waiter said to group of my Indian colleagues - "You guys eat cockroach in your country, why are you making a big deal here?"

Apparently, this is not the first cockroach review for this place. Thats why manager didn't care enough and just focused on getting the bill paid.

I wish he or his staff was at least apologetic for the food safety violation instead of kicking us out.

Please save yourself from potential food poisoning and extremely rude behavior.
author: Sachet D.

description:
There's not a lot of really good Vietnamese restaurants in the financial district. Sai's is a beacon of hope in the Vietnamese void. 

They have some great-tasting food at reasonable prices and it's served up quickly, even during the busy lunch hours. It was always packed when during lunch time when I was there, and the staff was very friendly and accommodating

I've had several rice combo dishes there, and my favorite was the Five Spices Roast Chicken over rice. This is hands-down one of the best Asian chicken dishes I've ever tasted. 5-stars for this dish.

This is a great restaurant, and I really miss it. I'll definitely be back again.
author: Charles A.

description:
Love the food, hate the wait! Good thing I know people who know people. Came here for lunch with my coworkers. Coming with a group of people is great because we can try out a variety of dishes. Coming with a bunch of pick eaters (non-chinese loving co-workers) is not so great because they'll order anything but authentic Vietnamese stuff (i.e. asparagus beef, fried shrimp...really?)

Anyway, we did get the Banh Xeo, "Henry's noodles," spring and imperial noodles, catfish and eggplant claypot, aka, the good stuff. Henry's noodles are not on the menu, they made it especially for our group. Everything was delicious! Solid food.  

This place is super busy, a bit crammed and probably not the cleanest restaurant in the city. Who cares, the food is amazing! P.S. even though there's a line, but service is quick, so it moves pretty quickly.
author: Em T.

description:
Convenient location if you are in the Financial District, but the food is pretty mediocre.

The inside decor is not fancy, but is much nicer than the restaurant looks from the outside.

The Bun Rieu is pretty good.

The pork summer rolls had too much lettuce and the pork was bland and in need of more marinade.

The BBQ Pork and imperial rolls was also on the bland side.
author: David T.

description: Tôi đa den tham San Francisco và đen nhà hàng Sai's . Đây là mot nhà hàng Viet Tôi thích tat ca các món ăn  nhà hàng nay . Nhung món ăn yêu thích nhat cua tôi là Bun Rieu và Sauteed Chicken With Mushrooms. Tat ca các món ăn rat ngon giá ca phai chăng , sach se, phuc vu tot
author: Nga L.

description:
Only authentic Vietnamese restaurant in FiDi!

Prices are great, portions are big, and the owners are super friendly.

I always get #80 - Vermicelli with chicken.

Tip: come early on rainy days (before noon). Everyone wants pho on cold days.
author: Peter D.

description:
My friend and I decided to do a late lunch. Still a line outside, but they try to get people in and out.  

Food = good.  Definitely skipped the pho this time.

For an appetizer, we tried their lemongrass beef spring rolls = epic.  It's so moist, flavorful and addicting. Two rolls cut into 4 pieces and comes with nouc mam sauce.  Plenty to share.  $6.75.

Tried the combo #3--fried prawns (too much batter), imperial rolls (crispy), BBQ beef (bland), five spice roasted chicken (tender, juicy and delicious!!), comes with rice and nouc mam sauce.  Plenty of food for one, and then some. $13.25.

Vietnamese coffee = good and strong.  They took a while to bring the glass of ice that goes with the coffee, despite being told that they would bring it soon.  $3.25.

Service = as everyone else says, ain't great but the food and drinks are good.  They did not refill our water.  They did not check on us.  They took our order, dropped off the food, and lastly, dropped off the check when it looked like we were done. 

Prices = moderate.  

Plenty of take-out going on here, so if you've got the time to call ahead, do it.
author: Fannie S.

description:
Saaiiii Whaaat?! This place is great. A hopping lunch spot every day of the week. In the heart of the financial district you will quite often find a line of hungry patrons waiting for a table between 12PM and 1:30PM. If you come after 1:30 you're much more likely to get a table. I arrived about 1:35 on a Friday and waltzed right up to a table. When you arrive, and there is no line, don't be afraid to just walk in and sit down (the servers tend to ignore you). 

I ordered the vermicelli bowl with beef, which I really enjoyed. I had lots of leftovers for dinner that night. The food is yummy, definitely has that authentic feel. Now the actual building itself is nothing special and it is a little warm and humid inside but don't be frightened - I'd say it is because they are cooking up a storm in the back! 

Their one downfall is the customer service, if you get so much as a grunt that is a good thing! If you can get them to smile, I'll be really impressed. But the upside of the lack in customer service means that they don't bother you and let you take all the time you need to enjoy your dish.
author: Aletta B.

description:
I love Sai's.  They're my go-to for comfort food when I'm downtown.  My family and I have a few staples that we go with - Pho Ga (chicken noodle soup), garlic basil chicken (with these kick ass thai chilis they have), and my son likes the sesame chicken.  

We've recently started ordering the grilled pork chop with bbq shrimp plate (both rice and vermicelli options) and the chicken and shrimp clay pot with bok choy.  I always ask for extra bok choy because it's so good the way they make it.  Yum!  

The staff is usually pretty busy, but if you go in before noon or after 1:30 then they'll stop to chat for a minute.
author: Sirena D.

description:
Visiting SF and went to Sai's for the first time. I don't usually eat Vietnamese food, but I must say that I was surprised. It was recommended that I try the five spices roast chicken over rice. 
The chicken was very good, with just enough flavor but not too salty, rice was cooked to perfection (best rice that I've had in sf), and the price was very reasonable! 
Their menu has something for everyone, and their friendly service makes for an overall great experience!
author: Cristina G.

description: As soon as I walked into Sai's, the fragrance of the food immediately took me back to a trip I had taken to Vietnam last fall. The wait staff is friendly and the food is phenomenal (and authentic!) It's not the fanciest place and it may appear to be a bit of a hole in the wall, but who cares if the food is delicious and reasonably priced? My waiter was accommodating to vegetarians and made some great recommendations. If you're craving Vietnamese food, definitely stop by Sai's!
author: Delaney C.

description: For the financial district, this is a decently-priced Vietnamese restaurant. There aren't many options as far as pho goes, but I got a Pho Bo (beef pho), which had beef balls and brisket (I think). You don't get a choice of what cuts of meat or size of pho you want. Nonetheless, it was filling and warming on a cold rainy San Francisco day. My friend got the Imperial Rolls which were perfectly fried and tasty. Even during a holiday work week, it was busy. During a regular work week, I imagine there's a line out the door.
author: Annie L.

description:
Is there a more iconic comfort food than pho? Whenever I'm sick or lonesome or just cold, pho is the first thing I think of. 

I'd passed Sai's probably a thousand times when visiting a client across the street, but I'd never had time to wait in the long line. So when my boyfriend surprised me at work and wanted to go have noodles for dinner, the back of my mind led me to Sai's.

The restaurant was completely empty except for an older lady counting change at a table. As we ate, the tables filled up a little bit.

I ordered the curry chicken noodle soup, which came in a huge portion. How do people eat this for lunch? It was delicious, with a mild curry broth, plentiful noodles, and dark chicken meat. 

If you're in the area, I'm sure Sai's will make an excellent lunch. If you're not, you'll easily find a table for dinner. It's worth a try!
author: Christina S.

description: I discovered this place online and decided to give it a try.  It was so good, I came back today and ordered the same.  Food is very fresh, great service and very affordable.  It is not fancy at all, but if you want a great tasting meal, come here.  You will come back again and again.
author: Zachary R.

description: Went there had a my lunch there. Ordered a sea food noodle soup, and I found two hairs in my soup. After learning there my stomach felt upset. :( Probably not going back anytime soon. Although, the soup tastes good.
author: Gatsby Y.

description:
Definitely a fan of Sai's. Get here before 12 and you and your party will get a table. On a weekday, at exactly 12, the house was full! Nice family run place. Service was always polite and generous but food takes a while to prep if there's a lot of people.

I always get my favorite #80 vermicelli bowl with imperial rolls. The pork is always a good choice. Had beef once and found the meat a little too chewy so not going to recommend. The imperial rolls are always fried to perfection. Golden and crispy mm mm delicious!
author: Benita M.

description: Noodles like grade school science lab agar jelly, soup like straight-from-the-can campbell chicken/beef broth (just add sugar, star anise, and fish sauce). To top at all off, you get harried and contemptuous service. I've given them 3 tries and I don't think I'll be back.
author: Ken H.

description: I moved away 2 years ago and miss Sai's terribly. It was around the corner from my office so I went at least once a week if not more. Their food was always delicious and their service is top notch. I'm a vegetarian so my favorite dish is the V15, coconut curry with vegetables and their spring rolls. Their shrimp dishes and chicken soup are favorites of my friends. It's family owned and family run and they work incredible hard to make delicious food not only affordable but in a quick manner with large portions. After all this time I still crave it and whenever I visit the Bay Area I make sure a Sai's stop is involved. If you're looking for an authentic home cooked meal I couldn't recommend Sai's any higher.
author: Laura S.

description:
Definitely the best and most authentic Vietnamese place in SF. 

Run by a super friendly family. 

The food is delicious and so flavoursome.  The lemongrass chicken spring rolls and the spicy hot and sour noodle soup are to die for.

It's a typical cafe style with no embellishments but the food is superb
author: Nm B.

description:
+1 for location, +1 for awesome prices, +1 for authentic decor/setting (considering it is FiDi), +0 for mediocre food

Come here if you want pho in FiDi and don't feel like walking up to Golden Star.

Food is very very mediocre, I get their pho as a means for convenient sustenance. Beef is usually dry, broth tastes like salt water + bouillon, but they get the temperature right (hot as balls), and beef balls never fail!

Location is awesome, can't miss the random loud one story Viet joint with all the pleasant aromas right next to the park / pyramid.

Price is amazing for the location ($10 pho), they must have totally missed the memo on SF Techflation.
author: Roger L.

description: Best Fried rice in San Francisco. It's very similar to what I have in Taiwan. Even though it's a Vietnamese restaurant. My husband comes here for fried rice at least once month. He only want to eat the Seafood Fried rice here. I prefer beef one.
author: Chia C.

description: Two best items on the menu are the Vietnamese Coffee and any of the Curry Noodle Stews.
author: Chase T.

description: My go to place for many years since moving to the city. Their noodle soup is very clean and flavorful. I get their chicken, beef, seafood noodle pho depending on my mood. Their crunchy Imperial rolls are to die for especially when you wrap it in lettuce and dip with their signature sauce. Yum!!!
author: Shamoo S.

description: I had the catfish clay pot and it was good. Fast service and decent prices!  Usually a busy spot during lunch time so try to come a little earlier than 12pm. I usually Yelp most of the restaurants I try but I def have to say Yelp reviews about this place were off this time. To me, this restaurant is a solid 4. For you to be able to order, eat and leave within 45mins, that's great! Pho wasn't my fav; stick to their claypots and noodles :)
author: Noor S.

description: One of the fresh tomato slices had mold on it. The guy apologized, but did not pick up them.
author: Vasily K.

description: Came here for lunch and had the chicken pho and it was good.  The broth was very tasty and flavorful.  I'm not much a noodle person but I have to say I really liked it.  There was a few more items on the menu that I will be back to try.
author: Jon L.

description:
Sai's is good if you have a hankering for pho but the lines are long at lunch and the food is very mediocre. I think it's a reasonably priced option that is good for small groups because they move parties through lunch quickly. I would advise getting there before 12 

Perhaps next time I will try their clay pots instead.
author: Jess C.

description:
Rude service! The female waitress was giving
attitude when i asked for jalapeños. Never stepping foot in this hole in the wall again.
Not to mention the noodle soup is filled with msg.. arghh..
author: Juls W.

description:
Update:

I wanted to include that first review, (because the food is so damn good tasting), and Sai's doesn't deserve to get slammed without a little recognition....

However, during my lunch today, I spotted a cockroach- and after reading some other reviews- it sounds like he's not alone...

Cockroach was on the wall, inches from my face. He was eyein' me. He was eyein' my meal, and he was ready to pounce...

So, I killed him-Straight up.

I really hate to do it Sai's - because you've provided me with many a tasty lunches- but I gotta hit you with the 1 star rating, because cockroaches are just plain nasty; and on top of that - you've turned me into a killer.
author: Ian W.

description:
My friend and I got  a corner table what we moved to accommodate more room, just to find out that it was infested by cockroaches. Total turn off.
Address this issue please!!!! I really enjoy your pho.
author: Alejandro M.

description: The food is great! A great taste of Vietnamese flavor while receiving great service from employees. Relatively cheap prices as well.
author: Megha P.

description:
Everything I've had at this restaurant was nothing short of amazing!  You can tell the chef has had years of experience, the flavors in each dish mesh perfectly together, creating a lovely experience truly deserving of the title "Cuisine".

Their prices are very reasonable, from $8-12 per person. 

The service is great for an Asian restaurant. Moreover, even during peak hours, you won't have to wait longer than 15 minutes for your food.
author: Anson Y.

description: It had been over 13 years since I'd eaten here and my office decided to order from here today. The menu selections were amazing, ranging from the typical Vietnamese rice dishes, bun noodles, pho, crispy noodles, chow mein, many vegetarian dishes and chef recommendations of curries, Tomato Crab Soup Noodles and Lemongrass Beef Bun and clay pot dishes. It all sounded great but once we all got the food, I remembered why I stopped eating here. It just isn't that good. My Bun with Chicken and Imperial Rolls was boring. It had very little vegetables and especially light on the Pickled variety and the Chicken was dry and lacked flavor. The egg rolls were not that good and tasted oily and not fresh. The Vegetables wuthering Tofu over rice lacked seasoning and was so bland. No one raved about the food so we aren't going back. I think the most redeeming quality is the choices of dishes so at least everyone can pick something to eat.
author: Jen L.

description:
Had the pork lunch combo for $11.00.  Also comes in chicken and beef.  Combo has rice, prawns , imperial roles, slaw and tea.  My buddy and I shared a table with a nosy couple who listened in our conversation as we made up fake outrageous stories.

Food came fairly quickly, but on a cold day they left the doors open and the hot tea refills didn't come often or fast enough.

Also the owner was having a swearing competition with a worker in Vietnamese.  I thought it added to the ambiance as my buddy and I tried to figure who won.
author: Erik H.

description:
Another gem I recently discovered in the Financial District! A coworker and I came by around 12:30 and there were lost of people standing outside waiting to be seated. But as soon as we were about to put our name down we got seated- how lucky right! 

I was craving Bun Rieu and that was the main reason we came to Sai's. I heard a lot of good things about it and I've noticed that not all Vietnamese restaurants carry this item on their menu. When it came out- the temperature was so hot. It remained hot until we left the restaurant. Not going to lie, I was even sweating while eating it. And it was 50 degrees outside that day. There's something about the Bun Rieu that its more like a comfort food, not the way pho makes me feel. Nevertheless, it was amazing. The broth was flavorful and it also had a little kick to it. This is now one of my favorite lunch spots. 

I'll give it five stars some other day. I forgot to mention that, we waited about 15 minutes for our food. Two tables that were seated after us got their food before us. Not acceptable when you're running your business at the busiest time of the day.
author: Dara S.

description:
Food was delicious!! I went with a group at lunch and we shared everything (well almost, I'm a pescatarian).  Shrimp claypot was AMAZING! so much flavor, just added some sriracha for spice!  We also ordered the fried shrimp appetizer. Very good.  Seafood soup was a little bland, Lamb soup looked and smelled so good.  My friends order that every time and love it. 

Service isn't the best...but worth it for the food! :)
author: Ashly J.

description: Their pho is pretty good here. You don't have to wait long for your food. Only issue is the service. You can ask for water 5x times and still get no water. Not friendly service. Weekday lunch generally gets pack though.
author: Sury C.

description:
Came here with a coworker during lunch. Beat the lunch crowd thankfully because it gets packed.
I had the Imperial Rolls and lamb curry soup. Rolls were good. Not the best I've had but good.
Lamb curry soup was BOMB. Broth was perfect. Even the potatoes tasted fantastic. I look forward to returning to try the other soups. On a cold day this place is it.
author: Matt H.

description:
There's always a line at this restaurant and because of that I really wanted to know what the hype was about. I came here with a group of 6 hungry coworkers and all of us ordered different types of food. Some ordered pho, some ordered rice plates and some ordered vermicelli bowls. I was one who ordered a vermicelli bowl. My coworkers and I are people who would eat everything and not waste any food. 

Unfortunately, Sai's disappointed us all! We had to wait for our table, wait for our food and the worst of all was the food!!!  All 6 of us didn't like our food at all! We didn't have anything good to say about the food. Everything didn't taste good at all! EVERY THING WAS BLAND AND DRY!!! We didn't finish our food nor did we have it packed to go.

Sorry Sai's, you disappointed a bunch of hungry folks that were craving Vietnamese food and my coworkers and I wouldn't come here again nor will we recommend this spot to othe people! We prefer Great Saigon Restaurant on Kearny Street!
author: Alice X.

description:
Meh, there was a line down the street and the pho was nothing special, just your plain, very typical middle of the road pho. 

It was warm, that was about as far as the goodness went. 

And I almost slipped and killed myself walking to the restroom. So be careful in here!
author: Monica G.

description: Fantastic downtown lunch place. Go early or else you'll be waiting in line. Chicken clay pot and fish curry are excellent.
author: Alex L.

description:
I got the crab noodle.
It was a large portion and very taste. Very little crab.
The soup was not salty which was good . I felt really thirsty afterwards and I have a feeling it is bc or msg. 
I would come back.
author: Alison W.

description: Found this incredible Vietnamese Restaurant !!! Ordered the vermicelli with pork (amazing), spring rolls with beef (amazing)! The place was crowded and loud but very clean. Portions were huge, Vietnamese style so it was easy to share. I'm definitely coming back to order other items on the menu!
author: Pau Y Monica C.

description: Glad I came here on a weekend because seems like this place is swarmed during the work week. I'm really into Vietnamese soup and I ordered the lamb curry soup and it was fantastic! Average price for SF, but definitely enough soup for two meals. Would totally come back!
author: Dis K.

description: My favorite place for Bun Rieu, it's the best in the city. Usually come here at 11:45 to avoid the line.
author: Brenda W.

description: Man I hate to be a band wagoner but this is hands down the best Pho been to every little Saigon there is and this takes the cake with beef pho. So impressed and it is so hard to do.
author: Christian L.

description:
I was coming here by myself for lunch and my experience on that day.

The service was fast, served a cup of tea and took my order right away. Except, there's a couple of things that irked me. One, minutes after I've placed the order, the server was asking me to move to another table with other strangers because there's party of 2 that just came. I understand it was busy and all, but some people like myself would rather have tables to themselves and came in first. And two, after i ate and got a check, I was paying with my card and waited; until some other server lady gave me the wrong card and told her that's not mine. So I waited for another 5 or so minutes until I actually got my card, signed for it, and didn't give any tip. I usually do give tips, but this service was totally unacceptable.

The food, I've ordered bun rieu (tomato soup with crab meat balls and tofu), which is one of the special orders. The soup pretty bland but the tofu and crab meat balls were ok. Might as well stick to the regular orders like beef/pork/chicken soup and rice plate.

Meh, not coming back again during busy lunch hours.
author: Kaydee B.

description: I've been coming here for over 10 years and order the same thing every time. The curry fish is my favorite dish to eat in San Francisco!
author: Chris B.

description:
I enjoyed the Bun Rieu here as well as the Beef Stew. Both bowls of soup are huge and flavorful. Imperial rolls were the size of lumpia (really small), not very imperial sized and the wrapper was too thick. The rolls are good but not my favorite. They sure did come out super fast though so I think plates are made non-stop since folks may tend to order them a lot. 

Service was friendly. If you're coming for weekday lunch, yes, get there early, probably 11:50am at the latest if you don't want to wait in line.
author: Maya S.

description:
I don't normally say bad things toward people and things. But this is the dish I don't want to rank for a star. 
I ordered a chilly and sour shrimp soup with vermicelli. It didn't worth the price of $13 including tax.
The scallion is dry and taste like piece of firewood, the shrimp must died several days ago, and to make the soup sour, they just simply put vinegar in it.
I was really starving since it is a late lunch. Now I feel like vomiting and don't even want to eat anything. Of course, I didn't finish even half of the soup. 
This is my first comment on yelp. I'm lazy. I feel like I need to let people be careful of what they gonna eat here.
author: Yirong Z.

description:
I really want to like Sai's pho but every time I come here, the broth taste way too plain! I catch myself drenching sirracha and hoisin sauce every single time. 

The amount of time that it took to receive my bowl of pho was abnormally long. I know the restaurant was packed, but we almost waited 30 mins to receive our pho, and considering that it's pho, it shouldn't have taken that long. Pho is usually known for coming out in minutes!! 

There will definitely be a wait during lunch since its in the FiDi, but it's pretty fast since there's a lot of seats Inside. 

I would come here again but order something besides their plain broth.
author: Sabrina L.

description: I ordered the pork chop over rice and ask to add an omelet, the guy forgot to put it down and told me that I didn't ask in a very rude manner. Besides, it's way too expensive to order a rice plate with only pork chop costing me 11 dollars. There were only three little tiny thin pieces of pork chop. Usually with that price in other Vietnamese restaurants the rice plate will come with 3 item: one nice thick and big and juicy piece of pork chop, shredded pork, and egg. It's wast of my money to eat it here. Don't recommend!!!!
author: Tracy Q.

description:
Got the curry noodle soup that everyone was raving about, but the lamb version, because...who can say no to lamb? 

The soup is pretty rich and thick, probably a good amount of coconut milk in it. It's really flavorful and goes well with the noodles. But the noodles were not cooked well, some of it was still not completely cooked all the way through and stuck together. 

We also got an order of imperial rolls, which were delicious...haven't had an imperial roll i didn't like at a vietnamese restaurant that i can remember. They're lightly fried and the sauce is a great tangy complement. 

It's a good spot for a quick lunch on a workday...portions are big, but be prepared for the food coma from the heaviness of the food.
author: Annie S.

description:
One star for poor quality food. The meat is fatty and dry, the pho broth is bland, and the vegetables are usually served limp and wilted. You can do better by walking 2 blocks over to Chinatown.

Also, one star for prominently supporting Aaron Peskin with placards all over their storefront. Peskin is one of the most offensive politicians in San Francisco history. Peskin helped cause the housing crisis we're in today.  Peskin also illegally harassed and threatened to fire city employees who disagreed with him on policy matters. 

If you care about good governance you should know who you're supporting with your dollars when you shop -- if you avoid Chick-Fil-A or Domino's because you don't like the politics of their owners, consider taking a stand closer to home too.
author: David C.

description:
I work near this restaurant so I venture here for lunch take out sometimes. I either 1) call in prior to picking up the food. The food will them be ready right as I get there, no wait! or 2) order when I arrive. 

I usually get the five spice chicken vermicelli bowl. They are very generous and give large portions.
author: Michelle F.

description: One of my favorite Vietnamese joints in the city, especially for vegetarians! The vermicelli bowl and the veg spring rolls are a must try!
author: Vineel S.

description: Depends on what you're looking for. The food is pretty good. The downside is the place itself - cockroaches on the walls while you eat. Clearly it's dirty, but how much does that "bug" you?
author: Sarah A.

description: Won't be coming back. Shitty service mediocre food. Overpriced. Walk a couple blocks up find a place that deserves your business
author: Marcus S.

description:
If you work around embarcadero, Montgomery and pier, sai might be the best choice to go for Vietnamese food in terms of distance. Their service is so fast and food quality is always as expected.  It is not place where you can go, sit and chat too long.  

Curry chicken noodle soup is the safest choice if you like curry soup.  Curry beef noodle is too heavy and greasy and curry seafood tastes bland. 

The pho is 7 out of 10 in my opinion. 

I would recommend be there at 11:30 am for lunch to avoid the rush hour.  The wait line get too long during the rush hour.  They don't take reservation.
author: sarah b.

description:
------ updating for last 4 years -------------
They ARE STILL AWESOME AND THE ONLY PLACE for Pho and Curry Soup !!! 

Speaking of honest people: they found and returned my credit card after 2 weeks  !!! 

I left my stomach and taste buds at Sais !
author: Alex S.

description:
In one sentence, Sai's is one of those restaurants that falls into the group of "I would only go there if I'm stuck in the area" category. They collected the stars on Yelp by 1) people who work near by so that Sai's is their Vietnamese lunch choice and 2) people who never been to Vietnam but thought they had the best Vietnamese food in the US.

I've definitely had better Vietnamese food, both in Vietnam and the US. Sai's just doesn't deserve more than 2 stars on my standard: 1 for their grilled chicken, 1 for their location. The rice is a bit cold, the grilled beef taste awful (dry and not fresh) and the fish sauce doesn't taste authentic. Service isn't helping, nor the restaurant decor. I didn't hear any staff speaking Vietnamese at all, they were mainly speaking Cantonese, which made me suspicious of their knowledge on making authentic Vietnamese cuisine.
author: Shaz L.

description: The food was delicious and I liked the authentic vibe of the place but if you have Celiacs disease or are very gluten intolerant I recommend you stay away. I went for lunch today and while I was told I was made a gluten free meal, and have no doubt that they made every effort to do so, I have to assume they have cross contamination issues in the kitchen because I've been dealing with after effects of a dose of gluten ever since. Perhaps if you aren't very sensitive to gluten you will be okay but a no go for sensitive folks like me.
author: Alexandra H.

description:
Whenever its a busy day at work, my co-workers and I are always eating from Sai's - it's our favorite restaurant! We are so happy that Sai's is only 1 block away - we can order from Sai's everyday if we like (and sometimes we have).  Over the years, I have tried many of their dishes - all are excellent - and my current favorite is the 80 with chicken - which is the vermicelli bowl with chicken and imperial rolls.  Sooo good.  I also really like the Banh Xeo (the crispy crepe).  Also, on a cold day, my all-time favorite is the Bun Cary Ga (curry chicken noodle soup) - which is totally delicious and it warms me up quickly. 

There is usually a long line, especially on cold days, but it is well worth the wait.  The food comes fast and it is really good.  The service is friendly - and they all smile a lot.  Enjoy!!!
author: Charissa N.

description:
I was in the neighborhood for business and chanced upon Sai's. It is a interesting setup, looks like they took over 2 stores and combined the 2, there are two separate rooms with a door connecting the two. 

Service was curt which is fine. The food was a mixed bag. My bbq beef arrived cold and I had to send it back for them to heat it up. It was too chewy even after that and I could not finish it. The egg rolls were over fried. The veggies dishes were better. The 3 mushroom tofu and crispy noodles were good.

Looks like a pretty popular place, got real busy over lunch.
author: Sunil R.

description:
I love this place!  They are always busy with a line out the door during lunchtime.  I have to admit it is pricy for Vietnamese food but once in a while is a treat.  I enjoy their combination plates, as well as, their curry catfish.  

Service may not be the best as they get very busy!  If you need water refilled or tea, best to flag down a wait staff or you may be sitting there for awhile .  

Overall the food is good!
author: FG L.

description: Bun rieu here is amazing! Lil meatball shaped crab meat and flavorful broth!
author: Judy N.

description:
Been meaning to pop into Sai's for about three years now, ever since my first job in the big city (onto job numero dos), when I walked by it every. single. day. Though I'm now about five blocks away, I finally made it inside. 

Arrived at 1:30 to find the place full, but not busting at the seams packed, and was seated right away, a glass mug of hot tea poured as my butt hit the chair. I was excited to find the back page of the menu is all vegetarian, including a veggie hot and sour soup -- a rarity, which I indulged in. For $8.50, I had the biggest bowl of spicy soup imaginable, chock full of mushrooms, noodles, veggies, and tofu. Try as I might, I could not fit all the liquid inside of me. 

Sai's decor (or lack there of) is reminiscent of the now defunct Chef Jia -- no frills, very Chinatown diner as I call it. But the food was great, the service fine, the price right and the tea warming to the soul.
author: Alicia O.

description:
Sai's is a little gem - a great inexpensive Vietnamese meal in the financial district. 

If they had Pho with tendon in it I would be even happier!
author: Yvette K.

description:
Sai's is a complete blur to me really, a mass of desperately hungry FiDi lemmings in a subway car masquerading as a Vietnamese restaurant. All jutting elbows and oversized handbags swung like left hooks in a ring. At least, that's my recollection at the height of the lunch hour when I came here with a colleague. It's not one of my usual haunts since I work a good half-hour walk away, but it was a nice change-up from my usual sammie on the run since good Vietnamese restaurants are not a common sight near the demolished Transbay Terminal (except Perilla, of course... http://www.yelp.com/biz/perilla-san-francisco#hrid:ABLmycgZr6dwFtVUfY1JkA.).

We got a table right at the front door, and it felt like being in the middle of a bowling lane with people aiming their strikes at me to watch my pins drop. Luckily, not many of them were good bowlers. What caught my eye on the menu was the $10 Chicken and Shrimp Claypot (see photo). Delicious, hearty stuff and so chock full of ingredients that it was hard to know where to start devouring it. I managed though. Service is quite stealth here, but you can assure yourself a quick turnaround given the inevitable wait. Come early to avoid a faceful of handbag.

FOOD - 4 stars...no major standout but a truly satisfying claypot on a cold day
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...ambiance?
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...quick and quick
TOTAL - 4 stars...it's about the food here, a good thing for an understandably busy FiDi lunch stop
author: Ed U.

description: Good Food and reasonable price but crowded and loud during lunch hours. The service is fast but not that friendly.
author: Subodhani M.

description: Good, decent reliable place for the price and authentic Vietnamese. Can't complain.
author: Parley G.

description:
Pretty much the only decent place in the FiDi to get Vietnamese food.  My co-worker and I shared an order of spring rolls and I got the pho tai while she got the pork chop rice plate.  We got here before 12 & were lucky to be seated at one of the last tables.  This place looks small on the outside but has a decent amount of seating and gets super packed.  

Nothing special about this place, standard spring rolls & I've had much better pho at other places.  The broth doesn't have much flavor.  Prices are a little higher than your typical Vietnamese restaurant as it is in the FiDi.  It also took her forever to get her pork chop.  Don't think I'd return, but it's nice to know that it's around.  2.5 stars rounded up.
author: Cat C.

description:
Great choice for a delicious and somewhat-authentic Vietnamese lunch (despite the owners being Cantonese!).  This place can be packed on weekdays during lunch hour, however, we came around 2pm on a Saturday so it was pretty empty near closing time.  We ordered:

Curry Lamb Noodle Soup - 4 stars - the curry broth definitely made this dish unique and was quite good. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sais-restaurant-san-francisco?select=kdjjKN1mJSOkvvWO_WT9bQ#iTjCwdh9PZQs2zLeKP3XEg)

Bun Rieu (crab meat & tomato noodle soup) - 4.5 stars - highly recommend this traditional soup dish. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sais-restaurant-san-francisco?select=kdjjKN1mJSOkvvWO_WT9bQ#kdjjKN1mJSOkvvWO_WT9bQ)

Both soups were delicious and the service was very prompt.  The Vietnamese coffee is also quite good.  Prices are reasonable ($14-15/person after tax and tip).  The only thing keeping it from 5 stars would be the interior design/decor and restroom which could both use an upgrade and more frequent and thorough cleaning.
author: Yun W.

description:
I have dined here for lunch with the GF about three or four times now.  I usually get basil chicken which is on the chef's recommended menu.  It contains basil, onions, and carrots.  Honestly, it is a very simple sounding dish, but the flavors are all there.  It is served on a separate dish from the rice which is great because if they combined it, the rice would probably be over sauced.  It is a good amount of food, which fills me up.  

The GF usually orders Bun Rieu which she absolutely loves.  She likes the texture of the noodles and the flavor of the soup.  I am not a big fan, but I have to admit, the soup is pretty good, even when I do not like tomatoes very much.  

Street parking is virtually impossible, and even when you do find a metered spot, you probably end up paying $4+ for an hour.  I would suggest parking in the garage nearby, which is cheap and convenient.  

We usually get seated quickly, even though lunch time is very busy.  This is probably because everyone else is in a large party and wants to be seated with each other.  

Good solid spot to eat at in the Downtown area.  I would come back again.
author: Victor L.

description: Okay, okay. I came back for some pho and I have to say, it was pretty damn good. Huge heaping hot steamy bowl with shredded chicken and more bean sprouts than 3 bowls could handle. Typical Asian service where getting a straw and a cup of ice or your check is greater than or equal to working in a coal mine, but c'est la vie!
author: Natasha P.

description:
Came during lunch time at 12pm on a Thursday.
CROWDED AND VERY LOUD - difficult spot to grab a casual lunch to get to know someone.

FOOD:
- Beef Pho (3/5) ~$10
Broth was a bit light, portions were dynamite. 

- Curry Noodle Soup with Chicken (4/5) ~$9
Curry broth was flavorful, though could use more spices. There was excessively a lot of chicken (all dark meat by the way, which is considered awesome in my book) compared to amount of vermicelli.

SERVICE: (4/5)
Staff members are very cognizant and work really quickly.
author: Vi T.

description: I have tried 3 different soups here all were excellent. My favorite for a richer soup was the lamb curry... it has a thai flare to it. It's delicious and the lamb is so tended. Best Pho I have had... the broth here is just excellent and so flavorable.
author: Christina A.

description: This was the first place where I tried Vietnamese food. The good thing is that the service is real quick. You'll get the food quickly. But there is a lot of rush during lunch hours and you might have to wait a bit. I had the Chicken Curry Noodle Soup which is HUGE for a person to finish. It tasted decent. The Sautéed Chicken with Veggies is pretty nice. Also the Thai Iced Tea is great.
author: Sidhesh B.

description:
I've been on the search for decent Pho in the financial district(when I'm not working I go to Sunflower and Kevin's in the Sunset 2nd.). I think Sai's wins that award. 

I'm giving them a 4 because I'm just amazed and glad to find a place that is worthy of satisfying my Pho craving while at work. Typically I'll settle for 5 Spice Chicken from Perilla or just not get it at all, because every other place I have tried was a joke(see Soup Junkie).

So today, I walked from Market/Front all the way over to Sai's in about 8 minutes to meet my wifey. 

We were luckily sat immediately. I've heard there can be a bit of a wait. (we arrived at 1:15pm on a Friday). 

I ordered the Beef Pho and she got the Chicken Pho. 

They both came out rather quickly and looked the part. I'm not a fan of mystery meat beef balls so I picked those out and left them on the condiment plate. I tossed in sprouts, basil, lime and jalapenos. 

My first sip of broth was quite pleasing. A good beef base and salty flavor. Yum indeed. After the soup began to spice up things were perfect. The beef steak that was in the soup was not overly tough and had a good flavor as well. After a while I dripped in a bit of Sriracha for variety. 

I tried my wife's chicken soup and thought the flavors were good there as well. 

The service was a bit sloppy and the restaurant didn't leave me with any clean feelings, but I didn't see anything unsanitary happening. I did get a dirty glass which I just didn't drink out of. Also our servers never came back after giving us our food and drinks. No extra napkins or follow up. I don't really expect great service at a Pho place, but a bit more attention would have been good. At this point, I'm still happy about them and they are getting my 4 for being exactly what I wanted and satisfying. 

Will go back, soon.
author: Mack L.

description: Found a dead cockroach in my noodles. Never going back. Not sure how this place has a health rating of 92...
author: Dana C.

description:
Can't believe Sai's averages below 4 stars! Great, authentic Vietnamese flavors and dishes in FiDi, ample seating, speedy service, good prices. What more can you ask for??

Dishes I love here:
- chicken w eggplant
- curry chicken soup
- beef w ginger and onion
- bbq beef on rice 

Also really like their imperial rolls.

The place is jam packed during the noon shift, so come on the early or late side for easier seating.
author: Jeremy T.

description:
Always a sure shot especially if you're looking for some food in the financial district in the late afternoon. 

So far, I've never been disappointed with the Pho. Delicious, always fresh and quick.
author: Rudi B.

description:
I heard so many good things about this place, but my experience was not so good.

I went for Vietnamese Spring Roll & Chicken rice noodles.
It was ok, but was not impressed.

My suggestion is to go early (11:00 to 11:30AM) to beat the lunch rush. 

What was unfortunate was that they were really rude once the store started to become busy around noon.  

I felt very rushed to finish my lunch, pay, and leave.
author: Sunny S.

description:
Claypot rice is awesome!
It is always packed in lunch time but it is worth waiting for sometime.If you don't want to wait on the line for lunch, go there around 11:30.
I recommend its Claypot rice. It has a lot of seafood,greens and chicken, seasoned with soy sauce and ginger. It is so tasty!
author: Takeshi H.

description: So Effin disappointed service was bad, the whole restaurant was just as bad but the food is the worst. Hate to tell yah peep they are not Vietnamese. Enough said I would never come back.
author: bouneson s.

description: Wow! Really good food and customer service. The servers are very sweet and the pho very delicious. Worth the trip to downtown.
author: Federico O.

description:
Such a great lunch spot for the hungry working man or woman! I will warn you, there is a line and it gets packed REAL fast. If you are on a time crunch from the office, I suggest either being her right at 11:00 when they open or waiting until after the lunch rush (around 1 or 2) 

The service was great and very punctual. Our server took our order as soon as we sat down and our food was brought out within 10 minutes of sitting down. I went with two of my co-workers and we ordered the Shrimp Spring Rolls - full of flavor and the dipping sauce was to die for! 

Our main entrees came out moment after our spring rolls, so the table did get a little crowded. I & one of my co-workers ordered the Chicken Noodle Pho and my other co-worker ordered the Prawns, Chief Special meal. We were also served hot sea, but come to think of it, they never asked if we wanted water, soda or anything else to drink. 

The reason I am giving 4 stars instead of 5 is because - they didn't ask if we wanted any other drinks with our meal, we felt rushed to finish our meal, so the next group could get in, and a group had trouble getting passed our table to exit, almost knocking over my tea - a little bit of a space issue in there. 

Overall, it was a great lunch and I am very full right now. Bring on the food coma!
author: Amy K.

description:
Mehhhh. I have had better Vietnamese food than this place. I ordered # 2 combo and it was too much food. The rolls were not crispy anymore, the bbq pork was really dry and the breaded shrimp was all breading, barely any shrimp.
The 2 stars are for the fish soup my friend ordered which had really good broth and flavor. 
This place gets packed and the line is out the door for a Friday lunch. Well I guess because its the only decent place around FIDI.

 Maybe I should come back and give it a try for the fish soup and beef soup.
 We shall see.
author: Claudine V.

description: Literally the best pho in the city!! This place gets super busy but it's worth it...the staff is fast and amazing. Treat them with respect, they are the givers of gods greatest creation.
author: Katie L.

description:
Sai's is the home of the psychic waiter...let me explain.

My office mates and I were looking for a quick lunch and Sai's is right down the street from the office. There was a short line and we waited about 5 minutes before getting a table. After looking at the menu, I was set on getting the Chicken Noodle Soup. Enter the psychic waiter, he takes everybody's order and grabs their menus. It was my turn and before I can open my mouth, he walks away. WTF??? When he returned to do his rounds, I told him he forgot to take my order. He said 'No, you wanted Chicken Noodle Soup, right?' My jaw dropped, utterly speechless....

So comes the food...the hot bowls come quickly for everyone. Size of the bowl is small for the price you pay, but of course you're in Fi-Di country, so everything is just a tad bit more expensive. The soup was alright, maybe a little on the salty side. So, one star for size and cost, one star for the alright soup, one star for the convenience and a well earned star for the psychic waiter.
author: Mike L.

description:
Gross. I've been here before and it was generally decent, but I came back since Pho Hoa is closed and this is the only other pho place I know of in the area. 

There isn't much of an option for Pho and even then, it's only "beef" or "beef ball". They don't even get the good beef balls with the tendon. No tendon, no tripe, wtf. No thank you. 

The broth is super bland and there's no flavor to it. Noodles had a weird taste to them... just gross. 

Service is whatever because they treat you like it was a bother to them you even showed up. 

Will I be back? I think not!
author: Jeannie L.

description:
love coming here for lunch. it's always packed, but i've never had to wait longer than a minute. 

i get the chicken pho every time, so good! the spring rolls are okay, but the imperial rolls are fantastic! i would definitely recommend them as an app.

definitely my favorite chicken pho place in the city so far
author: danielle a.

description: best chicken pho in town! I never mind waiting in line for it!
author: Jenna W.

description:
Came here for solo lunch. The restaurant was busy but I got seated immediately. Thought it was great but the good thing ended there.   As soon as I got seated I see the workers were shouting in Vietnamese (to be accurate, a man was shouting at a woman) and I was told to move to a different table. Moved to a second room which is much warmer. Them the same yelling guy came and started yelling again at the woman. I see two people with the food (which a half way done) and told me to move!  I finally said "are you kidding?!"  
Then the man smiled apologetically and said I could just stay at that table.
I was ready to order but took a while because it is so busy. Then they asked me (told me) that another solo person would share the table. I could care less. 
The food was not even great. Just mediocre.   My favorite Local Vietnamese restaurant is. MUCH better. 
What a disappointment!
author: Hannah S.

description:
I had the vermicelli with imperial rolls and BBQ pork! It was amazing!!! The rolls weren't just deep fried. They had a crispy bird's nest like batter, sorta like tempura but finer. As always, the vietnamese know how to cook their pork! The sweet sauce complimented the moist, thin vermicelli noodles :) and the based of the dish was laden with fresh vegs like bean sprouts and chopped up lettuce. I wish there was more bean sprouts. 

My friend had the chicken and mango dish with rice. It was ok but I preferred my dish. 

We also shared a side order of fresh spring rolls (shrimp). They were ok. A little stingy on the shrimp but other than that it was all good. 

I'll definitely head back to this place again. Fast, efficient service and I already have a favorite  go-to dish that has won me over :)
author: Amanda L.

description:
I've walked past this place a million times and finally decided to give it a try. 

I have to say I'm pretty disappointed. I ordered the Beef Pho (#19) to go. First taste: Broth isn't complex whatsoever. It tasted too sweet and was a bit too brown. Not sure what's up with that. Also, it only contained a few measly pieces of steak and meatballs. There were no options for tendon, rare steak, or tripe. The container was PACKED with noodles. I would have preferred more broth, more meat,  and far fewer noodles.  

I guess this place is fine if you're pressed for time and really desperate for pho, but I probably will not return.
author: Casey M.

description:
I came here for lunch with the Boyfriend and his mom last week and I was honestly skeptical as they were walking me through the door. I'm kind of picky when it comes to my Asian food venues. It also didn't help that Boyfriend mentioned that this place had previously had a rodent problem? I mean, nothing necessarily looked out of place and nothing was overtly dirty -- at least, no more than you would typically expect at such an establishment (I know you know what I'm talking about).

I ordered the pho bo (beef pho), Boyfriend ordered the bo kho (beef stew with noodles) and Boyfriend's mom got a curry fish dish (can't remember/find the name). Our food took forever to come out, which sucks. Granted, they were pretty busy, but nothing that warranted for the curry fish dish to come out first about 15 minutes after we order and THEN the pho and the beef stew didn't come out for another 15 minutes after that. I honestly think the waiter forgot our food hadn't arrived.

Taste-wise, the food is what you expect it to be. I liked my pho fine, but it's no better or worse than the pho I've had in the East Bay. Granted, I think it's fairly difficult to screw up pho, but I could be wrong. The curry fish was really good, too, and I may order that next time instead since it was more flavorful than what I ate.

Overall, it's a solid Vietnamese place near the FiDi. I don't think it's worth the down-the-street line, but if you want to score a table then get here early (I'd recommend 11:30am).
author: Anna W.

description:
Gotta get-get some fuh this afternoon, and in 2008, their fuh got poor to so-so yelp reviews. It's July 2009, and the fuh is still so 2000 and late! The fuh broth is bland and msg'd out; the beef is not what flank steak should look or taste like; the noodle is a glob of rice flour. Instead, head over to the nearest pho substitute - the Pho Hoa at Embarcadero Three (http://www.yelp.com/user_details_review_search?q=%22pho+is+okay%22&userid=09T1oyi6c-9lvyt7gQCD2w). Also was not impressed with the "bun rieu", as it was also bland. Maybe next time I better try the rice plates again, or the rolls like other yelpeeps suggested.
