For a place practically in FiDi, it hasn't changed through the years. Still got the divy feel...hmm, on purpose? Also, for a VNese restaurant, the workers spoke Cantonese and English, and only the owner spoke VNese. I couldn't decide which language to use.
author: Peter L.

description:
Been going here for years!  My favorite plate is the #73 sliced BBQ pork with rice and salad.  Split an order of imperial rolls and I'm all set!

Lemon grass chicken is good, pho on a rainy day is perfect... I like everything here!
author: Marylouise R.

description:
Lifehack: order a soup and split it with a friend. Their quanitities are beyond huge and then it's only about $4 for lunch. My recommendation is the Curry Noodle soup.

Enjoy!
author: Ami D.

description:
First impression: too hot, no AC, not even a powerhouse fan. I came here craving pho, but that desire rapidly dissipated after I walked into this greenhouse. I suppose if the goal was to emulate a Southeast Asian summer, these folks had it down.

Okay, I exaggerate the heat, slightly. After all, it's summer (/winter) in SF, and 98% of the time AC is beyond irrelevant.

Still, that doesn't change my feelings on the food, which was decidedly mediocre. I ordered the basil chicken, and while the flavouring was fine, the meat didn't seem your most expensive poultry cut. There also wasn't much of it. The bulk of the dish consisted of peppers, onions, and other vegetables that take up space but leave you fishing for more protein. Could be more generous - it's chicken, not caviar!

I also sampled the other entrées my table ordered and wasn't blown away by any of them - including the pho. I don't consider myself the ultimate arbitrator on pho authenticity, but this broth failed to conjure the magical feelings I associate with a good bowl of pho. Silver lining: I enjoyed their Vietnamese beer, give it a try?

Given its location, this place deserves accolades for serving pho and staying open for dinner. However, there's better Vietnamese food to be had in the city.
author: Kathy S.

description:
3 stars for the food being just OK. I'm from San Jose (home of Little Saigon) and I've had wayyyyy better Vietnamese food and for cheaper! Although they have a nice variety of authentic dishes, it is more of Chinese fusion restaurant to me. 

On the plus side, the service is fast and its a right next to my work if I'm ever craving mediocre, overpriced "vietnamese food"
author: Amanda M.

description: Best pho in town!!!!. Could run into long waits during lunch... worth the wait however....  servers are friendly..
author: Riley K.

description:
It wasn't love at first sight, or taste in this case, but Sai's has quickly evolved into a default spot for lunchtime Asian comfort food to combat cold and damp SF afternoons. 

I avoided Sai's for a while after my first experience becuase they didn't seperate the noodles from the broth when I order it to go which meant soggy noodles. Meh. But through the persistence of, and devotion to the place by my colleagues, I've come to enjoy some key dishes here. 

First, every cold day requires the curry chicken/beef-stew noodle soup. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/IaDXv2ZNo2HUeTatlsjMsw?select=Mpm8m5_SikWJxUealEaa9w) Alternatively you can switch out noodles for rice. Like all good South East Asian curries, it's a rich coconut milk based curry, not too spicy, just a soul warming meal. While the chicken is more typical, I really like the beef stew - the slow braised meat just falls apart in your mouth. 

The next go-to choice is the chicken and shrimp claypot rice. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/IaDXv2ZNo2HUeTatlsjMsw?select=PoY8g3eW4rl_8P9gnc0VUg) It's a nostalgic taste perhaps but the combination of shrimp, chicken, bok choy, and crispy rice covered in hoisin sauce just hits the right spot. The secret we believe has to be salted fish. We know it's in there somewhere for a little more savory oomph. 

Other good choices include the imperial rolls, fresh spring rolls withshrimp (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/IaDXv2ZNo2HUeTatlsjMsw?select=67T22k-DXpOvVJEbRSE6fQ), Vietnamese "potstickers", sauteed mixed vegetables (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/IaDXv2ZNo2HUeTatlsjMsw?select=8q-EaHfZBYDCh2dfbKH4Wg), bun with imperial rolls and pork (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/IaDXv2ZNo2HUeTatlsjMsw?select=RYnkkR04S0gpz9mjhxUkYw), beef stew noodle soup (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/IaDXv2ZNo2HUeTatlsjMsw?select=teMiyofONhsHWRdt0xSHMg), and beef pho (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/IaDXv2ZNo2HUeTatlsjMsw?select=Is3NxRcak9L95jPWhZwlIg). They're all pretty decent which says alot about the place. There aren't too many dessert options and the eat-and-go lunch crowd rarely orders it but if you must have a sweet treat, the fried bananas and ice cream (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/IaDXv2ZNo2HUeTatlsjMsw?select=cFbF-sCEpvEMO3hvjOp68Q) are decent. 

I've slowly grown to like Sai's as a satisfying lunch spot. It gets line-out-the-door crowded during the peak times of noon-1.30pm but here's a tip if you're in a larger group, you can actually call ahead to get a table; just make sure your whole party shows up at said time.
author: Jon L.

description:
I honestly don't know why this place only has 3 stars on Yelp, but I kinda want to keep it that way. Don't get me wrong, it's not because they have bad food, bad service or vermin. IT IS BECAUSE THEY ARE THE BEST KEPT SECRET IN THE FiDi!!!! I have ordered most of the non seafood items on the list and I have yet to be disappointed. My order is always correct and I always get service with a smile even when things are crazy.

When I first went to this place, I was a bit leery because, from the outside it looks like the typical low health score restaurant in the area, but I was wrong. Every day at lunch there is a huge line and every chair was filled! Before ordering I excused myself to go to the bathroom, because unfortunately, as SF foodies know, you can judge the cleanliness of the kitchen by the cleanliness of the bathroom. The bathroom was in a dark corner of the restaurant and surprisingly it was very clean and even had supplies! (I wasn't planning to be disappointed but it was a pleasant surprise)

Pleased, I went back and ordered the BBQ Pork Bun and it was fantastic! Perfectly cooked and no gristle! Sai's uses fresh ingredients, cares about what they cook, and they have a loyal fan in me! 

But stay away because this place is mine! And I don't want other people to find out!
author: Antoinette C.

description: This place is gold. Best vietnamese restaurant in the FiDi.
author: Tiff T.

description: Terrible service and you have to stand and wait for seated like 15 mins. There is just one guy to take order. Good are just eatable. Don't come if you don't wanna ruin your day.
author: Cece Z.

description: Meh, this place used to be okay, on the basis that it was cheap, but now it is on par with SF prices (like airport food prices), but not in quality. I'd skip this one next time- I had the crispy noodles and my friend had a vermicelli bowl, and both were just... meh.
author: Nancy W.

description: So good! Curry beef noodle soup is amazing. A bit crowded, but in FiDi what isn't!
author: Nancy C.

description:
Met up with a friend for dinner here last night. 
We started with the imperial rolls which were good, a little soggy, but good. And then I had the beef pho and he had some kind of lamb curry soup. I've had a bad cold so I didn't try any so as not to contaminate his food with my germs.

The pho was ok. I asked our waitress what kind of meat they used and she said lean beef strips, so I was surprised to find some weird sausage looking things floating around in my bowl. The beef was pretty scarce.

It was cheap and filled my soup craving, but I've had better pho elsewhere. I might come back to try a claypot.
author: Rachel E.

description: Their bun rieu is def. my comfort food, esp. during tough work days. Ventilation does need some work. Avoid long line at lunch hours.
author: SW Y.

description: I tried the pork belly rice.. I would prefer more meats or vegetable. But i do like the special sauce, which reminds me of vietnam
author: Chang L.

description:
It is one of the cleanest Vietnamese restaurant in the Bay Area.. It is very rare that, you see a kitchen that is spotless.. They were several staff members preparing meals and all of them took their time washing the veggies.. Yes I was outside watching ;) 
The owner/server is not the friendliest man on earth but he is efficient.. He answered all our questions and quickly got us everything that we ordered.. Their fresh rolls are very fresh and tasty, imperial roll was crunchy but not oily.. We had few of their noodle soups and all was very good.. My favorite was the seafood noodles.. 
We also had broccoli and beef, seafood curry.. All of them were really tasty and good.. I would highly recommend this place as the food is tasty and quick... 5 star for the food, 3 for the service.. Average 4 :)
author: Seda M.

description: I came here to try the pho, it was recommended by a coworker, and I was disappointed. If I ever go back, I would order very differently.
author: Lacy S.

description: Not a really fan of Sai's Pho. It's bland and could use more seasoning. But the staff are extremely accommodating!
author: Vhalerie L.

description:
Came here for the first time today and had a great experience. Met up a friend (who has been here plenty of times), arrived before noon so we didn't have to wait to be seated. 
I ordered the Seafood Pho and Imperial rolls. My bowl was pretty large.
Neither one did not disappoint! 
Service was fast and friendly. The exterior is not much but it's clean, quick and affordable.
author: Anna P.

description: This is a cute and casual family-owned restaurant. It's right by the Transamerica Building and Park. Their service is quick and pleasant, and they have great ventilation inside the restaurant - so you never feel too hot or crowded inside, even though there's usually a line outside to be seated.  You get hot jasmine tea with every dine-in meal.  My favorite is the vermicelli noodle bowl with imperial rolls and grilled pork (you can select beef or chicken as well). My friends have ordered the Pho and Curry Noodle bowl and also enjoyed their meals very much.
author: Vinh T.

description: Came here after seeing the long lines the day before. I was not disappointed. Being alone I got seated right away sharing a table. The portions are huge and the food was fresh.  My mistake was ordering shrimp slpring rolls and the vegetable vermicelli which was way too much food for one person. I ended up sharing my lunch with a stranger across the table that ended up being a really fun experience. She called it  "karma." The service is good and food came out really quickly. Definitely worth a go.
author: Sue Ann F.

description:
The five stars are for the beef curry noodle soup alone. AMAZING! It's seriously the best thing I've eaten all year and I've eaten a lot... From small holes in the wall to decadent tasting menus at Michelin-rated restaurants... Still, this dish stands out and I cannot stop thinking about it.

We came here on a whim on a rainy day. My boyfriend said he used to frequent Sai's when he lived in SF and said their beef curry noodle soup was awesome. It didn't sound appealing to me so I decided to get a regular bowl of pho. Big mistake. I ended up eating more than half of his bowl. The soup had so much depth! It was rich and creamy without tasting greasy or decadent for no reason. Don't get me wrong though... It's definitely decadent.  I also really enjoyed the noodles. They weren't your typical pho noodles, but perfect for this dish cooked al dente (the only way to serve noodles in my humble opinion).

Maybe my opinion is skewed because I wasn't expecting much, but this completely hit me upside the head and has left me craving it non-stop like a crackhead going through withdrawals. I only wish they opened on Sundays or closed later so this South Bay girl could get her fix.

Outside of the beef curry noodle soup, everything else was mediocre. The place is no frills and feels a bit run down. It's basically your average pho joint with decor and service to match. The spring rolls were pricier than typical, but they were good and I'd order them again. 

The next time I have a chance to go back I've already decided that I'm going to get a minimum of two orders of the beef curry soup to-go so I can take them home (without noodles) -- one to freeze and save for my next insatiable craving and another order so I can try to dissect the recipe in an attempt to make it myself.  Wish me luck!
author: J L.

description:
My biggest concerns with this place were (a) the wait and (b) cleanliness.  I was pleasantly surprised with both.  As to the first point, a party of 2 at 1145 = hardly any wait.  It was really, really crowded though even at that time, i.e. slightly before the lunch rush.  By the time the lunch rush started, the wait looked insane.  There were lots of small tables so I bet smaller parties have an easier time than bigger groups.

As to the second point, it was clean.  I'm not really sure what other reviewers were talking about but it looked fine to me.

The food was good.  Not amazing but probably my favorite Vietnamese in the FiDi.  All in all, good experience and I look forward to coming back.
author: Banana S.

description:
Cockroach in beef noodle soup.
I use this restaurant for 8years and food is okay, but it is not clean.
author: Jk K.

description:
I had stopped by a couple of times since I was desperate for Viet food and there's not much of a choice in my 'hood unless you want to hoof it up to Chinatown. 

Again, the food is pretty meh, but what turned me off for good is seeing sacks of raw vegetables - onions, carrots, ginger, etc. stored on the floor right near the mop bucket, which was full of dirty water and a wet mop.

Ick.
author: .Hon H.

description:
I've had numerous rice dishes and they have all been great, but don't come here for the pho ... it's gross!

The broth is disgusting and it's missing a lot of the regular ingredients found in pho. If your a regular pho eater, you will be disappointed. A total waste of $10 bucks!
author: Jay L.

description:
Parking?  Hahaha, bus or Bart to downtown and walk.  Or you better work around here.

I love this place.  I really feel they give you a good a mount for the price and it's fresh and tasty.

I love their five spice chicken and their imperial roll.  It's so good I don't want to order anything else because of how awesome it tastes.

Wish I still worked nearby here.
author: Bing D.

description:
Skimpy on meat with a lot of vegetable filler

I got the curry chicken with vegetables. i'd say it was 15% chicken, and the rest was onions and celery.
The sauce was delicious but not a $10 value lunch.
author: Erin S.

description: Love this restaurant for lunch.  Have been going there for years and I believe most of the staff is the same.  It is very crowded during lunch so I often get there are around 1.45 PM - and get a a table.  Love the Chicken curry Pho!  Price is right and service is quick.
author: Eivind S.

description:
Yes it is that good. The line at noon are all the people that know its worth the wait. The yellow curry fish soup is what gets me in there. I know that I love vietnamese food, but this soup is something, no other place close by has anything as good. 
The food is worth the wait. Nothing else to report, standard asian restaurant, you can eat there or take to go and eat your desk, same thing, there's no interior to write home about, its all about the food.
author: Try E.

description:
Seeing that this place is close to work, I figure that it was about time to try this place.
Frankly, this restaurant is one of the few examples where it's more worth it to trek up a couple more blocks away from the FiDi to get some quality vietnamese food. 

Don't get me wrong though, their Bun rieu and beef pho aren't bad but considering it's price, I would rather walk up a couple more blocks up on Washington street in Chinatown to get something cheaper with the same, if not better taste. 

In addition, seeing that it's in the FiDi, they seem to rush you to order. Within the span of a minute and a half, I had three waiters asking for my order. Calm down yo! I'm trying to decide! Give me some space...
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Rice Plate # 3 = Amazingly delicious! 

If all Vietnamese food was as good as this combo plate of BBQ beef, 5-Spice chicken, fried shrimp and Imperial rolls with cabbage salad and nuoc mam sauce; it could rule the world.

I am not an Asian food devotee, the flavors here are just superb.

Plus they have my favorite kind of round chop sticks.
author: Alona G.

description:
This is an average Vietnamese restaurant that is usually empty perhaps because of the price to quality ratio in terms of food.  There are much better options around the area if you're willing to explore other cuisines.  Nothing is done well and everything looks okay whether you start with shriveled up fried Imperial rolls or the bland taste of mixed vegetables over crispy egg noodles.  

Service is fast, but parking can be tough.  The ambiance is simple, clean and spacious with a cold feel to the place.
author: Jenny L.

description: This is my third time here for lunch, two times dine in and once to go. The food isn't fancy, but nice and homey and really hits the spot. I'm especially find of the noodle soup with tomato and crab! The portions and menu selection are a good for a downtown eatery; light eaters can probably share an order.
author: Camille L.

description:
(See pic)

Came back with a colleague during busy lunch hours which was totally different from my last experience. There's a line but the wait was only like 5 to 10 minutes.

This time I had chicken and it was tasty. I kept eying my colleague's roasted prawns as they looked really good too.

The Vietnamese coffee is drip as you order and it's as usual good strong.

It's a decent sized place with cute some skylight ceiling but I do hope they have better ventilation, especially when on a cooler day when they close the front door.
author: T L.

description: Amazing. Fast if you get order to go. Always busy so get here early if you want a table. Lemon grass clay pot best item on the menu.
author: Jonathan H.

description: Best Vietnamese food in San Francisco by far!!! The combination rice plates #1and #3 are phenomenal !!! All the PHO here is on point especially the chicken Pho .. If you want the best and live around or out of the city, the food is worth the drive.
author: Elias G.

description:
Good place for lunch if you're craving Vietnamese and you're in the Financial District. They have a wide selection of Vietnamese dishes (not just pho) like banh xeo and clay pot rice. Their pho was around $10 for a good portion in the FiDi area. The soup was hot and flavorful and there were generous amounts of steak meat--just how I like it.

The service wasn't all that great since I had to ask twice for tea and the seating was cramped. but that's understandable since it was rush hour and it's one of those eat-and-go lunch places.
author: Cheri S.

description: Came here around 11a.m to avoid the line, and we got our table right away. My friend order a vermicelli bowl, and I ordered Chicken Pho. We had the coffee as well. That one was good. My friend liked the food. Unfortunately, I didn't like mine. The soup was so salty, and I'm a salty eater. Lucky I checked it before I put black sauce in. I think I have tried better Pho in SF.
author: Zisele N.

description:
Last night, after a good workout, we were to figure out something healthy, warm and inexpensive to eat. After settling on Vietnamese, I was reminded of Sai's by someone who overheard our where-to-eat food dilemma. 

I've been here a few times and the food has always been consistently good, but dinner under $10.00 is a great deal. The menu has many options but I tend to go for the Beef Pho, Beef Curry or Combination Plate. 

I've been here a few times for lunch and it can get busy, but at night - after the FiDi workers go home, it's empty and the service was fast and friendly.

We all left really pleased with our meal and not feeling overly full. You know you had a good meal when you are still craving it the next day.
author: Rebekah T.

description: Came for dinner and tried the curry beef stew noodle soup. I don't know if I will ever try anything else because it was that good!!!! Huge portion too!  The server was very nice and polite.
author: Karen S.

description:
I went here solo for lunch. I had read good things about it and wanted to give it a try.

There was a line when I got there but everyone was seated quickly.
The service was prompt.

I ordered Imperial rolls and a clay pot with rice, chicken, and shrimp.

I thought both dishes were very good. I will definitely be returning. 

I have since returned multiple times.  I have enjoyed everything they have served.
author: Mark D.

description:
Barf.

The imperial rolls are the size of my fingers. They're super oily and over deep fried. The pho is also pretty gross.  Super bland and oily.  They put red onions in it rather than white so it tastes like a sandwich.  The noodles are over cooked so they're mushy. I really don't know why this place is so crowded.
author: Marisa R.

description: Lamb curry noodle soup always a winner. The iced coffee is great. Had the basil chicken. Tad spicy. The Vietnamese grilled chicken with rice was good but I was in the mood for something saucy.
author: Alokenanda L.

description: They are very fast, so even if there is a line, you will be seated relatively promptly.  I had the beef pho today and it hit the spot.  The broth was flavored well and the beef was still tender despite being fully cooked in the soup.
author: Natalie S.

description:
Southern style pho! Fast service! Tasty food! Not super spendy! Curry chicken soup! Shrimp and pork claypot! 

That is all. Enjoy. But be prepared to wait at lunch time.
author: Karena Q.

description: Everything I've tried here has been good. My favorites are the imperial rolls and the chicken pho. Expect a long line, especially on rainy days. In fact, calling in orders for pick up is best.
author: Ashley B.

description:
We came here for lunch, and I tried the BBQ pork over noodles.  The food was okay -- everything seemed soo cold!  The BBQ pork seemed as if it had been pre-made far in advance.  

I don't remember what my friend ordered -- I'm thinking it was beef stew noodles.  It's hard for me to remember, given that I've never seen anything truly authentic with broth like that.  It was a strange color, and had a film of oil.  

Overall, this place might be okay if you are on a time crunch and can't make your way up to Chinatown.  Definitely not very authentic viet food here.

There's a wait if you don't arrive on time, so arrive early! Service was normal.
author: Tramy V.

description: I really enjoyed my #80 with Pork. This is a Vermicilli Bowl with Pork and Imperial Rolls. I love Imperial Rolls! The place was packed with a line outside, The service was good and they did not rush you. I have passed this place hundreds of times and I am so glad I finally went in!
author: Adrienne G.

description:
Sai's is most definitely the place to go for Vietnamese cuisine if you respond yes to more than one of the following:

a) You work in the "ad ghetto" of San Francisco's Financial District
b) You are starving and are too lazy to walk all the way to China town for legit Vietnamese food (aka cheap and still yummy) 
c) You want to eat decent Asian food but don't want to lose your lunch after looking at the floors or from washing your hands in the restaurant's bathroom :) (btw, I am Asian, so I'm not being racist by any means. Just realistic! lol) -_-
d) You are ordering to-go and want something fast

If you answered yes to any of the above; you, my friend, need to pay this place a visit.

However, I will warn you, there are a couple of negatives to this place. If you do plan on staying to have "work lunch" with your coworkers, you'll have to hold that corporate shmack talkin' a few minutes (about 10 to be precise) because the lines are sometimes out the door! Another negative would have to be the price. I personally do not think a decent bowl of pho should EVER cost more than $5 and some change (before tip). Anything beyond that is just highway robbery for rice noodles, a few leaves of basil, a handful of bean sprouts, and 5 thinly sliced pieces of meat. 

All in all, this place is good (5 spice chicken is pretty decent!) and I plan on coming back...just won't be ordering the pho here anytime soon :).
author: Jasmin W.

description:
This hole in the wall is a true SF hidden gem. If you have never had vietnamese curry pho, then you have to go to Sai's. 

If your going for lunch do not be there a minute after 1130 or you will be waiting outside.
author: Brent A.

description:
I have been eating there almost once a week for a year. I had to go away for business for a while and I craved it.

Sometimes the food gets spiced up with interesting family fights but that does not bother us.

Pick it the day that you have time, want to enjoy good food for lunch and if you are not very picky about the decor or the excellent service.

Sooo goood... (they have their days but I would say 87% of the time).
author: Juli L.

description: Sai's is the best choice for Vietnamese food in FiDi.  You can always call in your order over lunch, and it's a great intimate dinner spot if you like Vietnamese.  Parking is pretty tight, but we are usually able to find something in the evening.  I would recommend the 23 1/2 (sauteed prawns w/ mixed veggies over crispy egg noodles), and I am a fan of their Bun (vermicelli bowls).
author: Irena P.

description:
Possibly the only pho place in the FiDi open past dusk.  It's obviously not going to be better than places in Little Saigon so don't even try to form such expectations.  An extensive menu of Vietnamese dishes are decently prepared.  Perfect for FiDi residents looking for a close and inexpensive dinner option.  This place is truly "A-OK"!

Imperial Rolls: Funny how the name sounds so regal whereas the reality is simply something deep fried... a style of cooking consumed by folks far from regal in this country!  This is a standard dish at most Vietnamese restaurants, but their preparation pleasantly surprised me.  The rolls were thinner than usual for a higher crunch-to-pork ratio.  Also, some parts were lightly fried and some heavily fried for a nice texture variation.

Pan Fried Crispy Crepe w/ Shrimp & Chicken: Not on all Vietnamese menus, Bánh Xèo is always a welcomed appetizer.  The coconut/turmeric crepe was light and crispy.  The shrimp had been pan fried for good browned edges.  The chicken was ok and they went a tad crazy with the bean sprouts.  So much going on and so yummy.  

Beef Pho: No tripe, no tendon: fine by me!  No flank and no brisket: huh?  A very minimalist soup of thin eye round (mostly cooked and barely any rare sections) and meat balls.  I used to think it odd, but now I miss the pages upon pages of the various beef part combination options for Pho Bo at other restaurants.  Once you get over the one-pho-for-all communism, you can appreciate the tasty broth and ample portions of beef.

Lemonade: Why do Vietnamese restaurants always give me limeade when they advertise lemonade?  However, it is quite refreshing and tastier than lemonade (except for meyer lemonade).  Thankfully they don't make the same substitution mistakes serving tofu instead beef, else I'd be saddened by the loss in translation.
author: Adam B.

description: I hate to be that person but I had a really really bad visit in this place. Bad service and old taste food. Our order taker have a bad attitude too. I always like Vietnamese food. In fact, Vietnamese food is my top 3 favorite food to eat! But this place really disappointed me..
author: Isabel A.

description: Sai's is a great Vietnamese restaurant and I definitely will return the next time I'm in San Francisco. It wasn't too crowded on a Thursday night. We ordered the Vietnamese Grilled Chicken and Chicken Pho. The pho did not have much chicken and was very bland, so I am taking a star off for that specifically. The grilled chicken on the other hand was delicious. We also split lemongrass beef spring rolls as an appetizer and they were perfect, not too much mint and a nice mix of flavors. The service was excellent; the waiter was attentive and timely in bringing our drinks, and the food came out quickly. Definitely a good little spot for dinner and probably lunch as well!
author: Quinn E.

description: Nice service, good food. Love fish balls, side order broth with sauted shrimp. Seafood noodle is another favorite.
author: Kai-wing B.

description: I've been to this place 20+ times and every time I leave I wonder why I entered in the first place. Terrible service and the food is mediocre at best. No reason to go there when chinatown is a block away. Only thing to expect there is a long line, a long wait, and terrible service.
author: Jay G.

description:
Super busy during the lunch rush.  Really cheap food for the financial district.  Probably the least pretenious/fancy restaurant in the financial district.  They really pack in the tables.   Not the best service, but that's to be expected at a place like that.  I get the sense they try to rush people in and out during the busy periods.

Extensive menu.  Will definitely go back to try more.
author: Derek L.

description:
The bowl to roll with here is the curry beef stew noodle soup. Awesome broth and tender chunks of beef. I could eat this everyday if I didn't mind the massive amount of MSG it contains. Every time I get back to my desk from lunch I'm running to the water dispenser to quench my insatiable thirst. The pho here isn't bad either. They use lemongrass which gives it a refreshing clean taste.

One of the better choices to get your Vietnamese/Chinese food in the FiDi without having to travel to Chinatown.
author: Eric L.

description: This has been my go to in the financial district for years. While there is a line, it moves quickly. If you're a smaller party, expect to be seated with other guests at he same table. But the food comes quick, always of the highest quality, and they bring the check quickly. Service is brusque but efficient.
author: James K.

description: Easily the best bowl of Pho I've had in San Francisco.  Get there early for lunch because the line will wrap down the street by 12:15.
author: David S.

description:
This place is POPPIN' every weekday at noon.  The owners must make a butt load of money, but I must say, the vermicelli bowl with grilled beef and imperial rolls wasn't that great. The curry noodle soup I had last time was also mediocre at best. I don't really understand the appeal of this place. Maybe it's because there aren't that many Vietnamese restaurants in the financial district.  

Anyways, back to the vermicelli bowl. The noodles were a bit too dry and sticking to each other.  The beef was dry and not tender. The imperial rolls were just fried dough with minimal meat. AND they did not have pickled jalapenos OR the chili flake hot sauce.  Those are staples at any Vietnamese restaurant!  

I am sticking to my Irving Vietnamese joints.
author: Rose J.

description:
Oh sooo Good!

Had the Shrimp & Chicken Claypot.  The chicken was really tender and just came apart when I mixed it with the flavorful rice.. PERFECT!

Can't wait to go back to try more dishes.

TIP: We got there a little after 12pm on Thurs for lunch and there was no line but the line started to grow outside, the space is not THAT big so plan ahead and allow for a good amount of time to wait for seating.
author: Lynda N.

description:
My first visit to a Vietnamese restaurant, so don't have a lot of experience in this type of food, but I'm going on a cruise next year with four stops in Vietnam, so maybe I will have a different opinion after trying the real thing next year.

Went at lunch time, so if you are going - get there early, as the place is small and looks like a hot spot for lunch, so you may be standing outside awhile.  We got there just before a group of 10, so lucky we were given a table quickly.

It is LOUD in there, so not a great place for a conversation, but it's got some energy, that is for sure.  A co-worker took me here - so it was a reco of hers.

Food - Appetizer - try the Shrimp Spring Rolls - fresh and well made with a nice peanut sauce.

Entree - being a newby - I tried the Combo #3 which had a little bit of everything - Rice - standard - but plenty of it - Cabbage Salad - I would say a Vietnam version of Cole Slaw - Crispy Fried Prawns - very tasty and good size - the coating was dark and different than anything I had and it comes with a dipping sauce that on first taste appeared to be vinegar based with some other stuff floating in it. - also good - I had the BBQ Beef and BBQ Chicken - both of these items were nicely prepared, not heavy on the spice - maybe a little more char broiled than BBQ (meaning no sauce).  There were also two deep fried tacquito-like rolls with some beef in them - not sure what these were, but I'd put them in a spring roll family - nothing special about them, but no one twisted my arm to eat everything on the plate! $12 bucks for all that food.

I'd go again.  A lot of folks were having really big bowls of soup with various stuff in them (PHO?)  So, maybe on a cold day - oh wait - it was August in San Francisco - and like 60 degrees with a strong wind off the bay - so I guess, next trip, no matter what the time of year - the soup would be a good choice in this city.
author: Steve A.

description: I found a Vietnamese version of Burmese Oh-No-Kow-Swe!!    Curry chicken noodle soup!
author: Morris C.

description:
The lines are long here, so my co-workers and I always try to get here before 11:45 -- after that, buckle your seatbelts!

This is one of those places where the food makes up for the lackluster customer service.  The shrimp and chicken claypot is one of my go-to dishes here, and never has it disappointed.  The cleanliness of this place could be upped a bit, but I guess one can just eat quickly and not look too closely!
author: Bay Area Explorer X.

description: Their curry chicken noodle soup gave me a boner.
author: Mick M.

description: I love this place! It's my first pit stop for yummy vermicelli bowls on my layover. I've tried them all.
author: D. N.

description: This restaurant was recommend by a friend.                                                  It was everything he said that it would be and more. It is a cool little place in an old San Francisco shop!  It looks to be all family run. They are very friendly and greet you as soon as you come in.                                        They seat you , give you a menu and then bring you a lovely cup of tea. The menu is very extensive with so much to choose from. I got the crab and Asparagus soup which was fantastic, nice and hot when it came. Then i also got the curry chicken. Fabulous  Darlings!  Of course it was a ton of food and they boxed it up for me to take with when i was through. Tasted even better the next day.   I am not a fan of Vietnamese food per say.   I more prefer Chinese or Thai. But, this is  one of my new favs!!     LOVE IT!
author: Teresa S.

description:
Way over-rated by some of the yelpers.

Not authentic at all.  The Beef Pho soup had no special taste in it at all which led me to believe that it was just the MSG.  (My friend and I can tell an hour or so after eating at Pho places if they use too much MSG)

And the pork chop dish?  Man.  I didn't think you could mess that dish up.  Those are the two dishes for our group to decide how it was.  There was barely any flaor in the pork chop and it was not the same type of pork chop served in the restaurants that we've been to.  Looking around I realized that more than 1/2 the crowd was not asian.

Oops.  It makes sense now.  I think they serve the working financial crowd how look how cute this place is and think "Ooh!  Look a pho house.  Let's go eat authentic pho!"  Not.

Tiny little bathroom.  Amazed that works for as much people they pack in there.

All in all, on with my search for the ultimate pho house in SF.  You can read my Oakland review for what I think was the best in Oakland.  That's the place to be!

P.S.  Driving home, my friend and I needed to drink lots of bottled water because we were really really thirsty if you know what I mean!  :(
author: Andy L.

description:
What doesn't get me excited are the prices of vietnamese food in the FiDI...overpriced...overpriced....overpriced. 

This stuff hits the spot if you work on the same block (which I do) and you're short on time...and your forgot your lunch...and you're craving Vietnamese food because it's cloudy outside. 

I wouldn't ever say, "Hey, yalls, we must get Vietnamese here!" and that is all.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Not bad at all.  I tried the egg rolls & the "chef's recommendation" clay pot w/shrimp and chicken; they didn't particularly blew me away, but they definitely weren't bad.  I can't say it's my favorite Vietnamese restaurant in the city, but even though I  was only so-so about what I had, the menu seemed pretty interesting - I definitely think it's worth another look.  

I should also say that the server was extremely friendly, and definitely willing to help out with recommendations & what was popular.  

All in all, it wasn't stellar, but I'm intrigued enough to go back and give it another try.
author: Brian F.

description:
My co-workers took me here on my first day on the job. So at least for sentimental reasons I like this place. What can you say, you never forget your first. 

This place is a 'tweener in the sense that it is located on the border of the Financial District and Chinatown.

It is best to come here early as a long line quickly forms right outside the door. I think it took about 15-20 minutes for us to get seated. 

In terms of food this place is typical of most Vietnamese restaurants. Interestingly enough the first item of the menu was not an extra large bowl of beef pho. That threw me off to say the least.

I ended up getting the grilled chicken plate, which, as the name of the dish suggests, is grilled chicken over some fresh veggies with a side of rice and a dipping sauce. The food was okay, nothing to rave about. There was the perfect amount of food, so I wasn't overly stuffed afterward (no food coma) plus the level of grease was appropriate (no heat burn or indigestion).

This is an alright spot for lunch in the Financial District. The prices aren't too expensive, most of the items listed on the menu are less than $10. The food comes out quickly, but unfortunately any time saved on that front is negated by the long initial wait to be seated.
author: Allan Y.

description:
My first time eating here, highly recommend. I like this restaurant for a couple of reasons: 
They are friendly when you enter and throughout your meal. They've been in the same location for 28 years. Mom, grandma, children and grandchildren work here. In my book, that means something. I like the story along with the food. They know how to get you in and out quickly as they're located in the Financial District. You 've come to a restaurant of regulars!
Most important...the food is great. We watched what was being ordered. Pho soups were No.1. Loved the curry chicken noodle soup. Great balance of curry, herbs and chicken. Also ordered a special beef bun that had a fantastic wok flavor.
Love that it is walking distance from us.
author: Michelle G.

description: This place has the best Pho I've ever had - I wish I could steal the recipe so I could make it at home!  Great lunchtime spot although it gets busy, but I've never had to wait longer than 15 for a table.  The place is small and seems to be family-run so service is always great!  Full Disclosure: I exclusively have the Chicken Pho here and haven't tried too many other dishes.
author: Adolfo E.

description:
So, I'm a geek.

Well, for sure during my Jr. high/high school years of painful attempting-to-fit-in looking like a nerd.  Nowadays I've seemed to erase the physical aspect of my nerdness but it seems to creep up and overtake me at times like that oily slime that came out of the water and covered the victims (an excerpt from a Stephen King short story).  Then again, when there was a LAN party that involved serious gaming (Gears of War) I was oh-so-there.

In order to satisfy the nerd cravings in me, I am a regular at a lecture series and usually go with a brilliant friend of mine.  Before these outings, I have to seriously prep my brain so that it will be up to its synaptic abilities.  I met my friend downtown at Sai, since he was hungry and I was mildly hungry.

Sai is located on the busy strip across from the SFFD.  Which means get ready for some loud sirens during the course of your meal.  Apparently in the afternoons, this joint is packed with local clientele dropping in from surrounding businesses.  Tonight, it was different.  We were the only patrons there that evening and I liked it.  It was quiet and we were able to consume away without any sporadic interruptions to our meal.

I had the Chicken yellow curry dish.  granted that I usually order curry dishes at Thai restaurants, but this one specifically came recommended by my friend.  It was a yellow curry and somewhat mediocre.  I suppose I'm more inclined to the Thai curries.  I also ordered the brown rice (currently on a health food supposition that will help me feel better surrounded by yogaphytes) and found it pleasantly heavy textured.  This means most of the hull was still evident on the piece of rice.

Inexpensive, quick and for the meal on the go before hitting a hard lecture, I'd recommend this place anytime.  Not to mention the loads of free parking in the area, a shock to anyone working in this district ;)
author: Miika M.

description:
This was the place to be when I used to work in the Financial District. The pho here was good. Beef curry noodle soup was also good, but a very heavy dish to eat for lunch. They actually give you tons of beef in the curry noodle soup.

As for the pho, the meat that that put in the pho isn't high grade and choices are limited. 

The rice dishes are also good. I get the mango beef and that is really good mixed with hot sauce. Most dishes cost  around $9.00 when I went (6 months ago), not sure if the prices changed or not.

Everything here is higher in price than usual pho places, but I would choose this place over pho hua at One  Embarcadero any day.
author: Erica T.

description:
See most people go about Sai's all wrong.  You cannot expect every SF restaurant to deliver in every way.  It is a dive, with that said, it is a damn good dive.  You have to know what to order.  I have been to at least 50 different Vietnamese Restaurants, even the hard core ones in San Jose where nothing is in English and you better know the language or go with someone who does if you even want your order taken.  I even make my own Pho and Bun at home....so I am not new to the food.  Sai's delivers on the foods they do best, 

Coconut Curry Fish - hands down the best dish of its kind you will find at Sai's
Chicken and Shrimp in a clay pot - I add tofu to mine..wonderful
The Viet crepe - solid- lots and lots of green leafies, not as much shrimp as before but hey the BEST EVER. TASTY.
Lemon grass chicken in a clay pot - wonderful...if you love meaty dishes.
Chicken salad - not bad.  Lots of fresh vegies, some crunchies, texture is pretty good.

Pho and bun average.  There are a couple other dishes....not so memorable, some I do not even like. But the fish and crepe make up for any shortcomings they may have.  it is not how many plates that are great, but that the plates that are great ....well .....are the best.  In SF you have go to places for what they do best, expecting every item in a dive to be excellent is not realistic.
author: Marcia P.

description: Was the food good? yeah it was.  Was it loaded with MSG. Yes it was.  F'd me up the rest of the day because of that.  MSG makes everything tastier, it's also super unhealthy for you. Cook something mediocrely and add MSG it will taste better.  The restaurant is clean, and there is always a wait.  these are things that may make the restaurant seem wonderful. But a wait doesn't mean it's good food, it just means the people in line heard the same thing you did.   the staff is chinese and  not vietnamese (though that doesn't really effect the food).  I actually would have given it 4 stars but the MSG thing kills me.  Good recipes don't need MSG.  Average or poor ones do.
author: Andrew r.

description:
This is some of the closest you will get in San Francisco when it comes to Authentic Vietnamese food! It makes it difficult to enjoy dinner unless, you are an early dinner person. Because of their location in the financial district, they close just past 5pm. 

The garlic basil chicken is something i loved so much that when I left San Fran, I couldnt help but have to learn how to make it at home and the taste is still just as good as here! 
Certainly a must go to if you are in the financial district of SF during regular business hours.
author: Jess C.

description: The pho ga is just okay here, and gets the job done if you are on the outer edge of FiDi, and are craving Viet-food, but too lazy to drive or walk to the Tenderloin. The waitress was nice, and the bowl arrived fast. Interior is clean. Prices are reasonable.
author: Derek N.

description:
Imperial rolls tasty but pricey.
Curry beef stew tasty but a bit pricey.
Pork chop and shrimp over noodles tasty but a bit pricey.
This is a nice find in the FiDi and we'll be back again. It gets busy at lunch times do beware.
As with almost all Viet places the service is fast and efficient if not always the friendliest.
author: Nick L.

description: SF Food inspection score = 67. I believe that's one of the worst scores I've seen. Food itself tasted average and service was prompt. A string of low food safety inspection scores for as long as they're available publicly does not give me confidence. The biggest puzzle was the lunchtime crowds. Previous yelp review about the bandaid in the soup was what caused me to look up this stuff. I normally don't want to know cuz I wouldn't have any more restaurants to go to.
author: Ichor B.

description:
Went there yesterday for the first time. It's about a 10 minute walk from my office, but worth it since there are very few quality inexpensive places to eat right around me.

I hadn't had a proper bowl of Pho in forever, so without hesitation I ordered a big bowl of it. The portion size, as with most Pho restaurants, is generous. I ate 90% of it, but I assume most people wouldn't be able to eat more than half :)

My friend had the basil chicken, and he said it was good. We split an order of Imperial rolls.

Overall, just what I wanted. I will be going back for more Pho fix.
author: Jordan C.

description: This restaurant is dirty and the food quality is pretty bad. Their customer service sucks too. There are better Vietnamese restaurants out there.
author: Scott M.

description:
If you've seen my flickr stream, you know I'm obsessed with Sai's Curry Beef Stew Noodle Soup. What's that, you ask?

Sai's Curry Beef Stew Noodle Soup is a bowl of curry soup larger than your head (unless, of course, you have one of those water mellon-sized noggins). In the bowl, you'll find curry broth, big pieces of carrots, onions and potatoes, big chunks of yummy fatty beef and rice noodles.

Load that monstrosity up with as much Sriracha as you can possibly tolerate and you've pretty much got yourself thirty minutes of heaven. That's 20 minutes longer than your boyfriend lasts, so for only $8, I figure that's a pretty sweet deal!

...and if you can manage to shove the entire bowl down your gullet, you're a bigger man than I. Good luck!
author: Brad L.

description:
A bit of a hike from Huddle Room D but on cold days like the ones we've been experiencing lately nothing beats a steamy bowl of pho ga - even if it's a trek to get to.

This pho will require generous seasoning but I appreciate that the noodles aren't clumpy and that the broth isn't too anise heavy.

Imperial rolls are tasty but the ones we were served came with just one piece of lettuce and no noodles or other traditional accompaniments. I missed them.

If these chilly temperatures persist, I'm likely to become a regular here.
author: Miriam W.

description:
I've been eating at Sai's, albeit infrequently, since about 1980 or thereabouts.  It was much smaller back then.  My sister's favorite is the 23 1/2 (don't know why it's called that).  My favorite is 5 spice chicken with the thinly sliced pickled daikon.  I've had their combo plates too but can't eat some of the stuff on there now so just go straight for the meat dishes.  It seems to be very quiet at dinner time during the week so if you go then, you'll immediately get a seat.  I just call in or drop in and take my food out with me.  Staff aren't real friendly but I'm not looking for friendship when I go here.  The food is good and it's near my work and it has my 5-spice chicken which I can't seem to make myself to get it to taste this good.

Sept. 2013--ok, I''m addicted.  I LOVE their chicken salad, the mix of vegetables used is delicious and refreshing, not sure if they put a sauce already on it but you do get a small container of that lovely fish sauce (but it doesn't need it, it taste great without).  I like their pho (beef) but it came with spaghetti noodles (that's what they looked and tasted like), I prefer the rice noodles and will ask next time I get pho.  Oh, and I got their bun rien (chef's special), was a little interesting but nothing to write home about--I think I'd prefer (1) rice noodles to compliment the crab balls, (2) having loose crab and not crab "cake" balls (they were ok but I want the crab taste more prevalent in the broth).

Summer 2014.  Had me some chicken salad again but got a huge MSG migraine from the food.  Don't know whether this was someone new making it and didn't know that good fresh food doesn't need MSG to taste excellent, of what.  I can't risk getting another MSG migraine so I'll avoid this dish at least.  I eat here when I have to work so I always have to go back to work after food, and having MSG doesn't work real well.  I still think the food is excellent, just kind of disappointed about them adding MSG.
author: Kai T.

description: Yes, I have experienced better Vietnamese food in the city. The only thing decent about this restaurant is it's location and price. Other than that, the food is pretty bland and difficult to eat. For instance, I ordered a noodle bowl with chicken; my chicken was in these ginormous chunks that made it look like ribs. The meat was incredibly fatty and pretty flavorless. The restaurant was dirty (not suprised by the 67/100 health score rating) and I will not be coming back here.
author: Tommy C.

description:
Wait...wait...wait...(wait some more).
sit down.
eat.
Curry Chicken Pho.
Coconut broth.
numnumnumnumnumnum.
I love you curry chicken pho.
You are now my bestest favorities thing to eat. Well, today. 
Especially after the chicken broke in two pieces and splashed broth all over my friends shirt. 
Red broth. Grey shirt. Muahahahahahha.
And if you ask, they will give you that little plate of veggies to go with it. 
Happy pho....sooo happy.
author: Danielle L.

description:
I go mainly for the pho.  Authentic, hot, spicy if you want it, and a great quick inexpensive meal.  And it's healthier than most of the lunchtime offerings downtown.

Ok, it's crowded, unglamorous and noisy, but it's also one of the best values in the city.

Yes, 4 stars here isn't the same as 4 stars at Gary Danko, but I'm going with value for the price.
author: charles h.

description:
Sai's is a bit of a hike for me, which is why I don't order from here as much as I'd like to.  But when I do get to enjoy a full hour lunch date, I like to come here.  Ok, yeah, the place is small and a tight squeeze but the staff is very friendly and the service is efficient.  It's ideal to come here between 11-11:30a.  After that, it's a bit of a wait.  

The pho and clay-pots I've tried are good, big-portioned and cheap. I've recently tried their Chicken Curry Soup.  It was very tasty. It had a lot of flavor and a lot of big pieces of tender chicken, but it didn't top the Chicken Curry Pho I had a few weeks ago in the Sunset.  Regardless, it still satisfied my Curry Soup crave.  Word of advice: If you order this, eat it there.  I made a mistake of bringing it back to the office.  The noodles soaked up a lot of the juice and they got soggy towards the bottom of the bowl.
author: Resa N.

description:
Update: 
 
Big Bowl of Hot Chicken Noodle Soup + Bugs in the Soup = Unhappy Me


Original Review:

Drizzly Day + Big Bowl of Hot Chicken Noodle Soup = Happy Me
author: Amy C.

description: If party of 5 or more, they will tell you 5 min but really it's 30 min or more wait.  Hence the low reviews.  However, Foods good. Come in small groups.
author: Sum W.

description:
Interesting and cozy location. My colleagues love this place but not me:( I don't like dark meat or weird things :( but I love the rice and the pot pie stuff. So I would go there again but probably order vegetarian food.

The place is really old and not very clean looking but people seem to love it!
author: T I.

description: Got introduced by a friend today and really enjoyed the Curry Lamb noodle soup. I didn't enjoy removing the bones. Maybe I'll go with curry chicken next time.
author: Nate B.

description:
I was a big fan of this little hole-in-the-wall place. You would have to come early to ensure a seat or else risk waiting for a table. I liked everything I've tried and I'm a creature of habit so I stick to what I know, unless someone in my party orders something that I might be daring to try. My favorite was the Joel's Classic. 

The reason why my review is in the past-tense:

Everything was great until one day I was in the area and decided to get some dinner for take-out. I asked to use the restroom while waiting on my food and saw the dreaded and undeniable dead cockroaches! UGH!!! Not the cockroaches....in my beloved Sai's....hold the 'special' sauce! oh my stomach.

The END.
author: Opinionated X.

description:
Yeah, I've had better...  With the line out the door you would think this place was the bomb but its not.  
The good: Thai iced tea, very nice not overly sweet and fried rolls
The bad: The beef broth and meat in the beef Pho, very disappointing, plain and the meat was tough
The ugly: The sticky tables and menus
If you are hard pressed to get Pho in the FiDi I would recommend Pho Hoa instead.  Their beef Pho has much better flavor and is a larger portion.  The service here is pretty lame too, you have to flag someone down to get water.
author: La C.

description: Although the health score is sub-optimal, Sai's is a pretty popular lunch destination for the FiDi folks. I'll ignore the activities in the back kitchen relevant to the health score and focus on the food. In general, everything is tasty and well presented but my favorite are the curry soup noodles. It is a mild curry soup tempered with coconut milk the drowns the rice noodles, vegetables, and meat. It is quite aromatic and flavorful, something that is unique and hard to find at other restaurants nearby. Avoid coming here during peak lunch hours but definitely a delicious spot.
author: Ed L.

description:
Yes.  YES!

I could seriously overeat here....& I typically come close to it when I am there.  For lunch, combos.  Pick one, you'll be all good.  

What else?  I pretty much stick to the combos for lunch, has always been a winning choice.  I also do the Nep Chien (Vietnamese potstickers!) or the Goi (salads-w/MEAT!).  Occasionally I'm down there on weekends & have the time to go through the rest of the menu.  That's a nice treat, but typically followed by a necessary nap.  ^.o

Fishballs.  Yeah, I know.  Not a remarkable food, but I L-O-V-E the @#$ things!  Dammit.  They've got'em there.

It's a nice family place.  They'll feed you good & treat you well there.
author: Dino N.

description:
I've been lucky because all my offices have been close enough to have lunch at Sai's. My coworkers are smart and come when lunch hour is ending. Otherwise, you'll be waiting outside or sharing a table with people you're just probably going to pretend aren't sitting right in front of your face.

My go-to is the Curry Beef Stew with noodles. Bright orange and greasy as all hell but tastes amazing. Maybe I have a thing for bright orange (jelly beans, radioactive curry, and convicts) but trust me it's good. 

I always end up staring at the guy with the tattoo on his neck. He's obviously a hard mutha but he he's fast as shit so the service is excellent.
author: May C.

description: I came here for a quick lunch with my supervisors at work, and the place was extremely busy. I was excited for my first hole-in-the-wall Vietnamese food experience, but I was a little disappointed with the food. I had the grilled chicken vermicelli bowl, which had way too much noodle and not enough of the fresh vegetables that make vermicelli bowls so great. The grilled chicken was okay, but nothing special. A lot of my coworkers had pho, which looked a little oily. They spent the rest of the afternoon guzzling water because it was way too salty! Prices are reasonable, but there are probably a lot of better-tasting options in the area.
author: Ashley T.

description:
5 spice chicken bowl. Everything was great until I couldn't chew through a piece of chicken. Turned out to be a band-aid. Disgusting.

At least service was savvy enough to comp the bill.

Will never go back.
author: Nick P.

description:
I've been to Sai's several times and normally, I come away thinking it's decent food.  However, having grown up in San Jose with its large Vietnamese population, I've had better.  I had yet to have a wow moment until last week.
A coworker of mine recommended the lamb curry noodle soup.  This was simply one of the most delicious noodle soups I've had.  It was flavorful and top notch.  I've actually had it now 3 times in the last week!

You can get a group in there, but you HAVE to get there early.  At 11:45, there's usually a line forming and forget a quick lunch at 12:00pm.

Overall, I think of Sai's is a 3.5 star place.  If we are talking about just a single dish, then the curry noodle soup alone could garner 4-5 stars.
author: Marcus K.

description:
It's not terrible, but there are plenty of better Vietnamese places around. I got a combo rice plate:

Fried shrimp: pretty good
imperial rolls: not great
BBQ pork: not good at all. Very tough, not very flavorful
Five spice chicken: best thing they had, tasty and juicy

Also comes with rice and salad. For $12 it's a decent amount of food.
author: John B.

description:
I've been here a few times with my coworkers. They frequent this place and the employees memorized their orders since they get the same thing almost ever time. 

I enjoyed the BBQ pork I ordered.. their Pho isn't that great tho.. I'd stick with the rice/vermicelli plates. 

Vietnamese Coffee is really good here.
author: J-nine I.

description: It was overpriced for Vietnamese food.  The quality of the food did not justify the price.
author: Kelvin S.

description: Quick service, and quick food delivery. This is a great place if you are in the neighborhood but not worth traveling to.
author: Erich V.

description:
I've had several things here which were all solid. The clay pot rice, imperial rolls, fried rice, pho, and five spice chicken all come in good portions and satisfy the lunchtime food attack when one is too lazy to walk a few blocks to Chinatown and save a couple bucks. The premium here isn't too bad though. $8 bucks instead of $6 for pho and the like. 
The only thing I cannot endorse is their bun. The sauce is lacking some umph, the beef was a bit too salty, they skimped on the mint and not enough veg to go with the somewhat dry and clumpy rice noodles. The fish sauce/vingear combo helps to get everything nice and re-hydrated, but it needs more bite and the salad as a whole needs more aromatics in the form of basil and mint man! 
Aside from that one minor issue this place is a decent option for all those TransAmerica building workers looking for a quick meal when its raining outside.
author: Stacy T.

description:
Pho-king A!

I love this place. There's usually a line, but the staff really books through it! Have a bowl of noodle soup or the chicken with green beans along with some imperial rolls for a great lunch that'll warm you up.
author: Nikki M.

description:
Yummy, Vietnamese comfort foods.. 

I ordered the seafood noodle soup to go when I got there and it was pretty fast. My coworker goes there everyday for lunch. I bet he has probably tried the whole menu! Too bad they didn't separate the noodles from the soup but it was fine when I got back to the office. It was loaded with a lot more seafood than I had expected. It was definitely filling and the hot soup made me sweat. If it wasn't too far out, I would have come here more often. I recommend this place and my other coworkers waited for a table and it didn't seem too long. Next time I'll have to eat in!
author: Jennifer D.

description: I'm pretty regular here for lunch and really dig on the coconut curry dishes in the veggie section. Nice portions - does need some Sriracha on it to make it really pop. The lady who works there noticed I kept ordering the same thing and started working with me to make custom veggie dishes that I'd like... veggies, tofu, no tomatoes... i thought it was sweet that she's taking the time to make me happy.
author: volker n.

description: The sea food fried rice, fish curry over rice and beff green bean are very good.
author: Yvonne Y.

description:
3.5 stars. Great value, comfort food, good portions and fresh tasting.  I came here the other night and it was as good as I remember. I have been coming here every now and then for years. It's been consistent.

I like getting the beef stew noodles. The beef is tender, the soup is a tomato base with stewed carrots.  Add in the fresh basil and bean sprouts.  It hits the spot! :)
author: Cindy Y.

description: My boyfriend and I are pho fantatics. We're tried most all of the Vietnamese places in North Beach. Sai's was our last place to try, but they are open very limited hours so it took a while to finally eat here. It's definitely a place that services people during lunch who work near-by in the financial district. Service is pretty good considering how crowded it was. I would say it's a solid bowl of pho, but not the best. I really like the fact that they don't use MSG though. BF and I both got pho, but the other dishes looked really good too.
author: Denise R.

description: I always crave pho. I can eat for breakfast, lunch or dinner. When I worked on the borderline of SOMA and Fidi, there were no good noodle soup places within close walking distance from me. Now that I work in the heart of Fidi, I was introduced to this place by a friend. I had the bun rieu and it was decently good as well as decently priced for being in the Fidi. Be aware: there is always a wait.
author: Amy Z.

description: Great little Vietnamese/Chinese restaurant - very close proximity to the Transamerica. There's always a long wait so as long as you get there by 11:45am you'll be good for lunch. Some of my favorites are the special crunchy noodles with green beans and pineapples, the mixed clay pot and the curry soup. The food is reasonably priced for the FD. The restaurant itself is not "fancy" by any means but if you want a quick yummy meal Sais hits the spot.
author: Allyssa B.

description:
My friend Glen and I recently dined here.  We got there early (11:30ish we left the office) and the place was already moderately busy. 
Even though it was a hot day I went for Chicken Pho and I made the right choice.  The portions were so huge that I couldn't finish my bowl, but this is definitely comfort food.   I can't wait to come back and try other dishes.
author: Katharine A.

description: Not much in terms of decor, but it's cozy and warm. Had the Pho Ga (chicken) last time and it was OK. Yet, the real star is the beef stew. Not the beef pho, the beef stew. You have to look for it under the beef section. Recommended. This was delicious and a generous portion. Quite wonderful on a cold day. The price is steep for a pho place. Maybe 30 percent more than normal, but gouging is typical of the financial district.
author: Brian C.

description:
Decided to come here for lunch today..I work a couple blocks away from here and have never been here before. I usually just trek over to Chinatown and have my Vietnamese craving fix there! Got here pretty early at 11:30 for lunch. We were able to get seated right away. Good thing too...cause by 11:50 I looked outside, and there was a line formed. 

I ordered the curry beef noodle soup....while it wasn't bad...it wasn't what I expected. The noodles were a little on the softer/mushy side, and the soup was very heavy. They did have lots of beef in the soup! And it wasn't very fatty like some other places may have it. I wished it was more soupier instead of feeling like I was drinking curry sauce.

Nothing fancy about this place at all..in fact if you ask me, it looks a little run down esp on the outside. I saw a lot of people ordering clay pots - but if you ask me, it looks like they just filled the clay pot with rice and put some food on top it and called it a clay pot dish. It's actually in a very good location, near the fidi - def try to avoid the lunch crowd by coming here early or later. While I was not impressed by my lunch dish, if I come here again, I will try something different here next time to see if my opinion changes.
author: Betty S.

description:
I always go here for LUNCH..

Quick service, great lunch deals, gets really crowded around 11:30AM-1pm

Food is tasty!

Last time I check rest room is clean...
author: Aemar E.

description:
It's a pretty average Vietnamese restaurants, but there aren't too many to choose from in the area.  

I usually come to this place with colleagues and friends that want to have Vietnamese for lunch.  I usually get the Pho or Bun, both are decent, but nothing that special.  It's still pricier than most Vietnamese restaurants and slightly below the average for flavor and quality.  Phos are around $8 and Buns are around $9, but it's cheaper & slightly better than the only other Pho place in the area, Pho Hoa, where it's about $1-$2 more for Pho and comes only with  two slices of beef.
author: Paul K.

description:
A couple of entertainment lawyers (David Given and Nick Carlin) introduced me to Sai's.

My friend Samantha is teaching me how to eat the noodles from the delicious hot pho with out making a huge mess.  We call it, "Practice". 

Get there early by (11:50) if you want to aviod the line, but it you need an excuse to talk to some one, invite them to lunch at Sai's at noon, and then you can use the line time to talk.

The food is delicious, they serve my favorite Bun in the city.
author: Kirsten F.

description:
I wanted to give this place another star for the imperial rolls, but everything else was so meh I couldn't. I ordered BBQ pork and rice dish after reading Yelp reviews about the pho. The meat was tough and flavorless, with the exception of tasting very charred. The garnish was some shredded carrot and a couple slices of cucumber. 

The server didn't bring me any water, and let me sit for about 10 minutes after my table was cleared before bringing me a check. 

My stomach hurts after eating here, I probably wouldn't go back. The only plus is that they do take credit cards, which few places around here seem to.
author: Beth D.

description:
I just finished eating here and my experience was just Meh.  I had the chicken curry and I got to say it was just bland.  The price is reasonable for SF about $10 for an item and they certainly give you a decent amount of food, but the taste just was not there.

If I go back I would definitely get another dish.  The one thing I can say about them though is they are extremely friendly and they get your meal out to you with amazing speed!

All in all it was an okay experience but I would probably go back to try a different dish.
author: Johnny A.

description:
I have honestly never tried anything but the fresh shrimp spring rolls and the curry chicken noodle soup.  But I can tell you that the springs rolls are one of the better ones I've had in the financial district.  The curry chicken noodle soup is delicious!  The chicken is always tender, never dry and the broth is perfectly seasoned, rich with chicken and coconut flavor and very addictive. Those two dishes alone keep me going back again and again!

Just be warned though you will walk out of that place smelling like food as the kitchen is tiny and open to the rest of the restaurant so if you have any important meetings that day I would pass!
author: Susan P.

description: Catering to the weekday lunch crowd of the Financial District, I don't have the pleasure of coming here often since they're closed on weekends. The few times that I have been able to visit this establishment have been quite good. The "five spice chicken" is tender and marinated well. The "imperial rolls" are yummy. The Pho rates and average THREE stars for me: decent, but far from memorable. What I enjoyed were the lunch specials, so that's worth going back for.
author: Helen L.

description:
I usually visit this restaurant to have lunch. They serve foods quickly and they are friendly. Also, food taste is really good. 

Especially, I like chicken fried rice. It's not so heavy and not so light for lunch meal. I recommend it someone who feels bored of ordinary lunch. 

All menu are accurate price as casual lunch meal. Have a good time in there~!!
author: Sungkyu S.

description:
yak,
I had lamb curry with noodle,.. 
Meat on the bones with A LOT of fat on it.. and I have a suspicion it was goat.
Noodles overcooked.
This particular dish is definitely overpriced.

This is one of the few Vietnamese restaurants in FiDi, that I could find. 
I will probably try it one more time when I get my next pho craving
For now giving it 2 stars
author: DImitry G.

description:
I met a few friends here for lunch today. My friend got there just in time to snag a table for four right before the line started.

It was my first time here so it took awhile to decide. I decided on the Combination 2 plate.

That was a lot of food. It was pretty good and I'm sure we'll go back again soon.

The friend rolls were just ok so I couldn't give it a better rating because those are my favorite.
author: Joie G.

description: Good food. Service wasn't great but not bad. Reasonably cheap for FiDi pho
author: Bunty S.

description: decent vietnamese restaurant, a bit overpriced, much prefer vietnam too in the tenderloin, but for local food near work in the financial district.... hits the spot for a ok Pho on a cold day, or a quick bbq pork salad when I'm in the mood. Clean location, long lines, family style seating, and fairly loud.... not great for a business lunch unless you don't mind shouting or leaning in over the table FYI.
author: Beth P.

description: I used to like this place, despite the uncomfortable seating, noise and poor service...  Until one day I got served a meal with... roaches.  Yes, there were several roaches floating inside a huge bowl of chicken noodle soup.  They looked like fried onions...  But those weren't onions, trust me!  Onions do not have legs...  The server treated it like nothing happened.  He apologized and offered to bring something else.  When I declined, he still charged us for the roach broth!  Glad they didn't charge extra for the roaches.  Later I learned about their very low food inspection score.  One of the worst in the city.  It was even published in a local paper, SF Chronicle, for it's low safety score.  The way people describe it recently makes me feel that things are not improving.  Personally, I am not going back to that place if I was dying of starvation.
author: LANA R.

description: This is one of my favorite lunch places and I come here frequently. I really like their tomatoe and crab meatball noodle soup. It is always serve hot and has good flavor. I also like their bbq chicken, the five spice chicken, bok choy and shrimp. I also like their jjasmine tea that they serve you. The place gets really busy and pack during lunch time so it is better to come after the lunch hour.
author: Anonymous B.

description:
The fidi doesn't have much when it comes to pho.  Pho Hoa is generic and expensive, slanted door is not authnetic and super expensive and then there is Sai's.  Affordable for the fidi and very good.  I always liked coming here on cold days, the portions are big and the broth is very flavorful in a subtle way.  The meat tended to be a little fatty but was manageable.

Sometimes it takes a little while to get seated, which sucks because you need to stand outside in the cold.  The place itself looks like a typical hole in the wall but it adds to the general feel of the restaurant.  Service can be a little slow so make sure you have time to spare when you come here.
author: Brent G.

description:
If I'm ever craving a creamier Curry Noodle Beef Pho, Sai's is the place to go. I have to say that I'm not a huge fan of the flavor until i add a small ramekin of hot sauce and mix it in with the soup. Otherwise, it's a bit bland for me. The hot sauce brings out the flavor of the curry and it's not as spicy as Capitol Kim Tar. Both are good in their own ways of course. Sai's curry pho has carrots and tender beef that's marbled with tendon. You get a choice of Beef, Chicken or Lamb. I've heard the beef is the best. 

The only problem is that even though we call ahead for pickup, the whole trip takes 35 minutes. Walking there from work, waiting a bit, and walking back up. Doesn't leave much for my 1 hour lunch break. Eating in is completely out of the question though. It's super packed and there is always a line during lunch. Be forewarned!
author: Donna H.

description: Yummilicios Vietnamese food, worth the drive.
author: Dinora G.

description:
The last time my boyfriend and I ordered food from this place we found a cockroach in our food.  When we went back to the restaurant and spoke with someone about it. The man behind the counter took the food container from my hands, picked up what I pointed out to be the cockroach and yelled out "this is not a bug, this is the marinade!!" 
Whatever!!! That thing had legs.  
I must say the kitchen looks pretty filthy like it would harvest cockroaches in there.  I wouldn't recommend this place to anyone!
author: Theresa B.

description:
breezed through here for lunch and ordered the #2 combo plate. it had fried shrimp, imperial rolls, salad, sauteed chicken and rice. the portions were just right and does the job....the rice portion was large but the rest on the plate was very small..you may end up being hungry even after a $9.75 no tip/tax order..
3/5 judochops
author: Dustin G.

description:
Good place for Vietnamese comfort food - steaming bowls of Pho, flavorful claypots, variety of rice and noodle plates, and vegetarian options. They also offer 3 serving platter-sized Combo. Rice Plates.  These combo. plates are huge!

My current favorite is the sauteed mixed-veg. with bean curd.  You can request brown rice for an additional $2.

Service is quick and friendly.

Noise level loud during the lunch rush.  Opt to call in and have your meal to go.  Dine in the tranquil redwood park next door.
author: Cathy K.

description:
Nothing beats a hot bowl of pho on a rainy day and Sai's hit the spot today. Certainly not the best pho I have ever had, but it calms the cravings.

If you plan on going to Sai's go early (by 11:30) otherwise expect to stand in line waiting for a seat.  Food is fresh and hot and service is quick.
author: Colleen B.

description:
Food here is good. Giving this place 2 stars on the following service. Ordered ice coffee to go during non peak time, another gentlemen orders one clearly right after me 2 minutes later.  We're basically the only 2 people there.  Takes 10 minutes here to make the ice coffee.  Once mine was done, they give it to this other gentlemen first.
My guess he was in a suit, and maybe they thought he deserved better treatment.  
Keep one customer and lose 1, instead of keeping 2 customers.
author: ed l.

description: yum for the yellow chicken curry noodles on a cold day, or well, anytime. it's the only thing i've ordered there; perhaps i need to venture outside-the-box and try something else like one of their rice plates. yes, try something else next time...but it's soooo good...okay, okay.
author: Mike C.

description:
The five-spice chicken is the best in the city. Top that with their vegetable vermicelli bowl and a side of imperial rolls, and you have yourself a $10 lunch. 

Yum!
author: johanna a.

description:
I would have given this place 4 stars if it wasn't for that damn insect that was in my fish curry.

My co-workers love going to this place.  I have eaten at the restaurant twice and had food delivered to the office once.  It's unfortunate that I had to find that bug on that last order...otherwise, I would have continued ordering from  here.
author: Michelle N.

description:
This is an amazing place for that quick, easy, and delicous pho fix.  They also feature a large array of Vietnamese dishes.

My co-workers and I return here every month for "payday lunch."  It's a lunch we all look forward to, and by the time the 1st of the month rolls around....our mouths are watering and our eyes are glaring at the clock anticipating that beloved lunch hour.

Without fail, we always get the five-spice chicken.  It's SOOOOO good and tender, and combined with the fish/vinegar sauce and rice...it's Asian heaven.  We also get the curry chicken soup, vegetable crispy crepe, sauteed noodles with veggies, and sometimes some egg noodle soup.  

It's always been REALLY fast, and while the service isn't exactly super friendly, it's good enough for a great time with your co-workers.

They also have HALO HALO!!! And as a Filipino, any place in the FiDi with Halo Halo definitely deserves 5 stars!  I thought I would never find a place in the city (besides JollyBee people!) that served this Filipino delicacy.

Thank you, Sai's!!
author: Vince S.

description:
I don't understand why there's such a line out the door for average Vietnamese food.  If you walk a couple blocks up to Chinatown there's a much better selection.

In any case though, the pho is pretty meh, and their dry dishes are decent.  Of course it's pretty cheap and quick, so this place definitely has that going.
author: Ren L.

description: Food is as good as other Vietnamese places in the area. But the service is just terrible. And yes never talk to the owner on the cash counter. He is just a super rude frustrated soul.
author: Vinod S.

description:
Some days four and some days three.

From a food standpoint Sai's is above average.  

I've found every dish I've ordered to be quite tasty...and in all actuality too large.
