The spices and seasoning of the dishes are always spot on and the rice is always perfect too (big deal for me).  The only detraction I can think of is that sometimes you know that this may not be the highest quality meat.  I know...I know, a fast Asian lunch place that caters to the business knucklehead crowd like myself for some relative cheap eats north of FiDi will not be serving Kobe beef, or hell, not even Neiman Ranch!  However, I like to think, that for the most part, I have an incredible suspension of disbelief.  More often than not the food at Sai's is so tasty that suspension stays...but on some occasions the quality of the meat is just so meh that the suspension fails and I'm like how I was when I found out Santa wasn't real.  

The ambiance is truly worth a look see.

One word.  Clusterfuck.  Shit...I'll throw in a possible close second: pandemonium.  However, I'll stick with clusterfuck and raise it to the Mega level as in Megaclusterfuck.

I rarely eat in Sai's.  I'm blessed, and cursed, to work in an office that likes to all stop what you're doing and all have lunch together.  So...I am always picking up some grub here...which...honestly, sometimes the highlight of my day.  If you have a chance try to camp out near the register while you wait for your food right in the middle of a lunch rush.  The kitchen is about, hmmmm, 40 sq. ft....no fucking joke.  the restaurant seats maybe 100 or so plus take out orders.  

Food flying, fires raging, people shouting, dishes flying, people darting and weaving, every age imaginable working, ...like 9 cooks and 3 expediters (who are all busier than one-legged men in a butt kicking contest)...and what seems to be like 3 people just constantly running around in a state of high agitation on the outskirts of the kitchen...I call them the Vietnamese Valence Electrons..

Truly a sight to behold...Megaclusterfuck.

Go...if not for the food at least for the craziness.
author: Chris D.

description:
Serviceable Vietnamese food...

Don't come for the decor...

Lines out the door at lunchtime, so keep that in mind...
author: Nathan W.

description:
Extreme disappointment! A friend and I went here for a quick pho fix and after looking at the extensive menu, he decided on chicken curry and I ordered the bbq pork and imperial roll bun. 

I asked for a side bowl of broth, the chicken based broth that is often provided when you order a rice plate. Although the soup was free, it lacked of flavor! My friend was not pleased w/ his chicken curry. Apparently the chicken tasted "funny" and all I could taste was carcinogens with each bbq pork bite.
author: Lan H.

description:
People-watching jam-packed weekday lunchtime.

Tasty dishes!  Vietnamese crepes and all the vegetarian dishes were awesome.
author: Melanie C.

description: This place is amazing. They normally have a line, but moves fast. The food is really good and they have variety enough to try different things everytime. It could be hard to understand a few things with the workers/servers, but beyond that if you are lookinh for good food and a affordable price, this is it!!
author: Andreina R.

description: I recommend the pho; everything else is fairly average. They're quite proud of their seafood noodles, which is alright. Otherwise, it's a no-frills, down-to-earth, fast and economical dining option.
author: Edwin C.

description:
This is the spot for Vietnamese noodle in the FiDi. The trick is to get there early 11:30 am sharp because after 11:45, there will be a line outside regardless if it's rain or shine. 

My friend had the Beef claypot and I thought the beef was a bit over cook and dry. However the sauce is awesome. My favorite would have to be Bun Rieu (Tomato and crab meatball) and the Vietnamese coffee there.

The imperial rolls are good but I've had better in Chinatown, the ones here just seem to be a little over fried. It's so fried, the meat inside is crispy. But I'm a sucker for fried stuff, so my meal is not complete without an order of the imperial rolls.

I would like to try their curry pho.
author: Christina W.

description:
Stopped in for lunch today and had the Garlic Basil Chicken.  Not bad!  Chicken meat could have been better quality.

Service was decent, free hot tea served and refilled throughout the meal.  This seems to be a popular place, and was pretty packed at the lunch hour.  I'd return and try another dish on the menu.  Certainly worth a try.
author: Justin H.

description:
One of the better Vietnamese places in the Financial District in SF is Sai's Restaurant. It's a little pricier than your usual pho, but it'll have to do since there's really no other good Vietnamese place nearby.

The scene:

Definitely get here early to beat the lunch crowd or else you'll be 1. waiting 20 minutes to sit and 2. waiting another 20 minutes for your food. What I find funny about this place is that it looks like it's run by a family of Vietnamese gangsters. What's even funnier is that they're not even Vietnamese. They're Chinese!

The food:

There are not many places that make curry pho. A few in the Sunset, a bunch in the Peninsula... Sai's happens to make a mean curry pho and a lamb curry pho at that. I came in with the intentions of ordering a curry pho, but came across the smell of the BBQ pork, so I ordered that instead. My lunch buddy was sweet enough to order the curry pho so I could sneak a bite from her.

BBQ Pork Over Rice - The dish was generally good. Nothing special than any other Vietnamese restaurant. I did wait 20 minutes for my dish and an additional 10 when I sent it back because it was cold.

Lamb Curry Pho - Drool, this dish is so good. The broth is soupy, spicy and rich in coconut milk. And the meat is so tender! The only problem is that the bowl is so huge, you can never finish it! But, you try. And then, you feel completely miserable after realizing you probably had half a can of coconut milk.
author: Sam L.

description:
It's hard to find a good Vietnamese place in the Financial District, so this is pretty much you best bet in the area.  Serves actual Vietnamese food (there are things other than pho).

The line can be long during the lunch hour, and the wait staff definitely tries to hurry you along.  If you want to have a slower lunch, come early, like 11:30.  There's no list, so you just line up outside and hope for the best.  As the other reviewer's point out, it can be pretty chaotic inside.

The food quality is ok.  It's not completely authentic, but it's pretty darn good for the FiDi.  I wouldn't order the pho there.  Go with the other dishes.  They have a decent combo menu for lunch that includes an imperial roll and main entree.

If you don't want to wait, call ahead and order for take-out.  Just walk right in the door, past the long line, and take your food to go and enjoy a nice meal outside.  Try the plazas around the Transamerica Building.
author: Kelvin V.

description:
So I haven't been to Sai's in over a month (shocking!!!) and I feel like I'm going through withdrawals.

In addition to the entrees I listed previous, I've also had the lemongrass beef bun which is best served with egg noodles (recommended by the waiter).  It's now my favorite item on their whole menu.

I really want that beef...so flavorful and delicious!

Oh, and that beef curry stew?  SO much better in noddle soup form.   And yes, it's beef. I'm an idiot...woops

Oh, to attest to how much my co-workers and I love this place:
2 of our co-workers are leaving to go back to Japan at the end of the month, but not before we have a "Sai's Night."  We're having dinner at Sai's and ordering pretty much everything off the menu as their "last hurrah."  

I'll be back after, but yes...Sai's Night.  That's how important this place is to my office
author: Naoko M.

description:
Reliable. Efficient. Appetizing.

One extra star because the bf goes here about 3 times a week!

Don't mind the line out the door at lunch hour (unless your boss expects you back in 10) because these people are efficient!  In n Out has a Vietnamese competitor!

The food won't amaze you, but it's delicious simplicity will impress you.  The vermicelli bowl (bun) is a MASSIVE bundle of noodles, fresh and crunchy veggies, with the standard sweet and sour sauce on the side.  Top this with 5 spice chicken or even the cheaper imperial roll option, and you have an aching full belly!

Sai's is fast, fresh, and extremely consistent.  From the vegetarian curries to the stir fry to my fave, the verm bowls, you won't be disappointed for an $8-10 meal!

Know Before You Go:
1. Long lines during lunch hours - virtually empty between 2 - 8PM.
author: Jane L.

description: Over priced dry BBQ pork says it all.  I work around the corner so have been here a few times.  At first I craved a good pho, and can't say it was too bad given that I doctored it up with hot sauce and lime.  The other times, I have had their specials, which are not special for the price. Don't use the bathroom because you will probably loose your appetite and not enjoy seeing the state of their kitchen.  Lucky for me, I finally realized that there was a better spot in Embarcadero 3 to satisfy my Vietnamese food cravings.
author: S J.

description:
This has been my go-to place for "Bun Rieu" (Tomato and crab meatball noodle soup)! First of all, the broth is very tasty without being oily and they fry their own fresh tofu. Also the crab meatballs are neatly formed into bitesize and very cute! I'm deducting 1 star because it's kinda pricey (around $9).  BUT it's completely worth it! 

Not sure about other items on their menu since I only come here for their Bun Rieu. =)
author: Suzi k.

description:
I don't even think to go to this place any more. First of all, the place is so noisy and place is so small that you even don't have a space to stand before the counter for ordering. And the guy standing behind the counter was not friendly. When i ordered the sauteed pork w/ eggplant, he seemed was not patient, so I repeated saying I want to order this dish. They cooked very quickly, but when I brought it back i found they gave me another dish - pork with mixed veg. I called the restaurant and guy said you pointed to this dish, What?? but did you hear what I was saying? i bet you didn't. He didn't want to talk any more, and hung up the phone. 

i definitely won't go back and i will recommend the eateries in Chinatown to my friends which is just a few blocks away.
author: pink p.

description:
Sai's has the best egg rolls with the translucent wrappings.

The clay pot is good enough to make one murmer "Father God, Son Jesus."

The server / owner Henry, is the nicest restaurant guy in the city.
author: Christopher R.

description: While their meat dishes are far weaker, Sai's excels at the vegetarian stuff. Their green beans in black bean sauce are the stuff dreams are made of. Zzzzz Mmmmm Zzzzz Mmmmm Zzzzz Mmmmm
author: Kathleen M.

description:
This place is seriously awesome.  My dry cleaning bill resulting from a meal here always exceeds what I had to pay to stuff my face with noodley goodness.  My current love affair is with the curry lamb noodle bowl.  Amazing flavor, and they somehow create a silky, velvety texture out of broth and noodles and lamb.  I think witchcraft may be involved, but I frankly don't care.

My only complaints are: (1) they use meat with a LOT of bone in it.  This makes it a touch hard to actually eat the meat in the dishes.  I happen to be a megan (eating only meat and meat by-products, the opposite of vegan), so I need to sink my (fake) choppers into some tender flesh in order to walk away satisfied.  However, megan does not equal wolf (it would be easier if Yelp recognized the "does not equal" sign, but sadly it doesn't), and I'm not willing to plop a bony and gristley chunk of meat on the paper tablecloth and chew on it.  (2) Unless you like eating lunch at 11:30 or 1:00, it is HARD to find a table here.  Esp. on cold days, which is when you really need some noodley, brothy goodness up in you.

Other than that, this place is fantastic.

P.S.: Did I -y enough nouns in this review?  Hmmm...yes, I think I did.
author: Ben P.

description:
I come here quite often and usually order a big ass bowl of pho ga (that's chicken noddle soup) when it's chilly and I'm feeling lazy, which is often.  There's something so comforting about excruciatingly hot soup steaming up my cold pink cheeks!  And the waiters and waitresses are sweet despite how busy they get - awww - I always ask them how they're doing and they always give me a big toothy smile :o) 

Occasionally I order their lunch specials - a great deal if you're super hungry! Comes with beef/chickent, spring rolls, fried shrimp, rice and salad.  I normally don't have dinner if I get the lunch special because it fills you up that much!

Anyhoo - the only thing that sometimes bugs me is that they make all the singles and/or doubles share tables and it can get awkward.  If you end up coming here alone - as I usually do - make sure you're prepared for small talk with strangers, or if you aren't feeling so social, bring a book or magazine.
author: Aim E.

description: Not as good as Saigon in downtown Oakland. Less salty, less greasy, more expensive. But now that I work in San Francisco, I guess this will do when I have a pho ga craving
author: Jeanine I.

description: Delightful!  A refreshing place, in the middle of the financial district
author: Charles C.

description:
i wanted vegetarian pho, which they don't have, so the waiter suggested a "custom" order of vermicelli and vegetables in broth that warmed my belly up on a cold, rainy day.

the veggies (bean sprouts, 2 kinds of mushrooms, and tomato) were fresh, the tofu soft, and i could feel my body absorbing all the nutritious pho goodness. pho is just one of those foods that seem to energize me on dull, rainy days. 

the place literally gets packed in the span of about 15 minutes (i.e. plenty of tables at 11:30, no tables at 11:45) so plan accordingly if you're on a timed lunch.
author: Shawn C.

description:
I had lunch here with a bunch of work peeps. Sai's is really busy during lunch but we were lucky and got a table without a wait. The food is excellent even if the service is slightly slow.

The coconut fish that I had here was excellent. I come from a part of India famous for sea food and this dish was as good as anything I had eaten back home. The clay pot that we ordered was also great. The lunch ended up being 10$ per head and it was well worth it.
author: Sudarshan G.

description:
One word: Mediocre.

I love me my Vietnamese food but I came here on my lunch break thinking that this place would deliver and was sadly mistaken. An order of charbroiled pork and imperial roll bun yielded 5 matchstick slivers of charred meat, and three of the saddest, most shriveled and dried out pieces of imperial roll I have ever had the misfortune of looking at. Don't even bother.
author: Clarissa S.

description:
It's been a few years since I last came to Sai, but I was feeling in the mood for noodles with pork and Imperial Rolls at lunchtime today.

Unfortunately, the mood for Vietnamese food hit me after my co-worker and I had already left the office building, which left me saying: Hmmm...I feel like eating Vietnamese noodles, and I vaguely remember a restaurant somewhere near by.  What do you think?

Well, she's a good friend, so she indulged me.  We zigzagged our way in FiDi, which also had us meandering into Franco Sarto at one point and ended up with me purchasing a pair of Mary Janes, and after a prayer to the Restaurant Gods (do not mock the Restaurant Gods), I finally managed to find Sai.

It was as crowded (read: line at the door) as I remembered it being years back.  But service was brisk once we got seated.  And we were ridiculously happy to be eating Vietnamese noodles while waiting for our Vietnamese coffee to drip onto the condensed milk...conversation was ridiculously punchy and lively.

Good times.
author: Sooj O.

description:
I'd forgotten how good this place was until Elaine S. told me she had lunch there the other day.  Thanks, by the way!  I used to have lunch here about once a week when I worked around the corner.  It's a 10-minute walk from where I work now, and it's totally worth it.

Get here before 11:45 or don't even bother.  The line is always out the door, and you risk looking through the window watching people savor their food.  

To quote Elaine from Seinfeld (not affiliated with Elaine S.): "Did you ever notice how happy people are when they finally get a table?  They think they're so special because they've been chosen.  It's enough to make you sick."

If there are only 2 of you, prepare to be seated at a table that may or may not be adjacent to another table for two.  There's a row of 4 tables for two, which is where we were seated.  I hate community dining, and it sure felt like it.  The people next to us were pretty loud, and I had a hard time hearing my friend.  It's OK, I can easily have a conversation with myself.

We ordered some Vietnamese spring rolls.  They were deep-fried and therefore delicious.  I ordered the marinated beef cubes, breaking the rule of never ordering the "shaking beef" unless I'm at a more expensive Vietnamese restaurant.  The beef cubes were overcooked for my taste, and they weren't as tender as I would have liked.  My friend ordered the chef's special garlic beef, which was a far better choice.

Next time, I will order something else.  I might actually go with the noodles instead of the rice.  I used to like those better.  The BBQ Pork and Vermicelli bowl is a LOT of food, and it's really, really good.

You should definitely stop by Sai's, unless, of course, you're in this country illegally.  Sai's is located across the street from the INS building, which makes you a sitting duck.  You've been warned.
author: Yan G.

description:
decent lunch place in FiDi if you're looking for vietnamese cuisine, and not just pho.  it starts to get packed around 1230pm so be prepared to wait a bit.  they have an extension menu of vietnamese noodle soup, rice plates, and rice vermicelli dishes.  

the grilled lemongrass chicken with rice was good.  i wouldn't recommend getting cashew chicken, which my friend got.  they aren't known for their pho either.  stick to the grilled meat vietnamese dishes and noodle soups!
author: Wendy S.

description:
Popped in here for a clay pot today.  Holy shit that stuff is tasty.  I especially enjoy the yummy shitake mushrooms that they nestle into the folds of yummy rice, chicken and shrimp.  Spray some of that vietnamese hot sauce on all of the above and, grrrr, you are on your way to a great lunch! 

Uno problemo. This is not the place to be quickly in and out, we had to wait quite a while for the food, so reserve this for Friday lunch or hit it in your off hours.
author: Claire C.

description: Pretty solid vietnamese food.  It's pricier than you average place so minus one star for that.  However, that doesn't deter people as there is a usually a line on a weekday.  If you don't feel like walking to Chinatown to get cheap food, this is your alternative.  They have a more extensive menu than pho hoa, so a good option if you want more than just pho.
author: Michelle H.

description: When it's rainy outside, I usually like to have noodle soup. I decided to go to Sai's (had it once before and it was decent). This time, I opted for #17 Seafood Noodle Soup. It was just what I needed. I'm particular about my broth because some places either water it down or they do the complete opposite - put waaaay too much additives like MSG that make me nauseous and have the absolute worst headache. But not this place. The broth was just right. There were lots of veggies and the seafood was clean. The shrimp was already peeled (yay!), there were little slices of fish cake, fish balls, slivers of cuttlefish. The bowl itself is quite large, but I don't usually aim to finish all the soup. Definitely will return. I went around 1:30PM so the crowd already died down and it was just me.
author: Valentina H.

description:
When I worked in the Financial District, we'd go to Sai's at least twice a week. The place gets crowded during lunch, mostly with professionals, so if you get in before 12 or after 1 you'll have a better chance of not waiting for a table.

I enjoy their chicken noodle soup. It has small amounts of chicken, but the cuts are good. The broth is flavorful, but light on the garlic. The tofu and vegetable curry is excellent. They have a chicken version of the same dish, but the cuts of meat are weirder. Their imperial rolls are always hot and crispy. 

The one time I ordered their pork and roll vermicelli bowl, I was disappointed to find it lacking in crushed peanuts and heaps of other garnish on top. 

Unlike a lot of other Vietnamese places around town, I consider Sai's to be on the cleaner side. The kitchen is small and grimy, yes, but the food feels and tastes fresher. I imagine my perspective would be different had I found a bandage in my meal like another reviewer.

Free jasmine tea and friendly service round out the experience.
author: Nik D.

description: Decent Vietnamese fast food. Good place for take out lunches. I like the imperial rolls appetizer and grilled prawns vermicelli bowl.
author: Helen Y.

description:
Overpriced and not that good.

The truth is that Sai's is a Chinese restaurant (with super MSG-loaded dishes) that serves some Vietnamese dishes Chinese-style.  The people who work there are not even Vietnamese.  I'm from NYC originally and there are tons of great authentic Vietnamese restaurants there so I know the real deal and this is NOT it.  As for the food, it's really so-so to be perfectly blunt and many of their dishes leave a lot to be desired.  If you're looking for Vietnamese food, sadly you won't find it in SF downtown.  You'll have to look elsewhere in the city where there are far better places.
author: Robert S.

description: My fellow and I really enjoy the Pho from here. I wouldn't call myself an expert, but I am definitely a foodie. I get the beef and he gets the chicken. The broths are flavorful and I enjoy the fresh accoutrements that they come with including sprouts, fresh basil, fresh jalapeno and lime. I normally prefer my meat raw in Pho, but theirs is cooked and tastes good. I hear it is packed at lunch. I want to try the rest of the menu.
author: Claudia O.

description:
Ok, I love pho. Can't keep away from this place even though it isn't the best. The waitress has my order memorized, she helps get my food quick and send me on my way. Despite the fact that she doesn't seem to speak English very well I'm sure she's a nice lady.
I think the pho has improved a little, tends to still be a little soapy when slurping the broth straight but I still enjoy devouring this soup.
author: Jenna P.

description:
We had dinner there with a bunch of friends.  The place is in the financial district. About 1/2 full on a Friday night.  Serving staff were friendly. Food was tasty.  Beef dish was very good, so is the shrimp paste on sugar cane stick.

Typical dinky dirty little bath room (just one unisex bathroom).
author: Peter L.

description:
#22 Curry Chicken Pho is quite possibly the best food invention since sliced bread! I remember my first taste of it like I remember my first kiss, except this time I didn't have to spin a bottle.  

It was during lunch last week with some friends, and my friend ordered it, while I played it safe with the regular beef pho.  The regular beef pho was okay (Chinatown has better), but I decided to mooch off my friend and try the crazy concoction of curry pho.  As soon as it hit my lips, I was enamored and infatuated! I proceeded to eat more of it and decided that I would stop mooching and would order my own next time. 

Which brings us to today, where I finally ordered it and had my lofty expectations met as I devoured the bowl of hot creamy but light enough curry chicken pho that seemed to have a whole chicken in there.  It was so big that I couldn't even finish all the chicken.  

So what's the moral of the story? Go for something new and you might be pleasantly surprised.  Also, spin the bottle never fails! ;)
author: James C.

description: Reasonably priced, enjoyed the prawn & squid curry.  Crowded, but service is good and quick.  Be prepared to be seated with a stranger, but same thing tends to happen in NYC so it's all good.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Whenever I'm battling a cold, it's the usual routine - Jamba Juice coldbusters and pho. The latter today came courtesy of Sai's. The true verdict will be when I wake up tomorrow, but so far I'm a fan. Super friendly service (had the feeling this has been a family run joint since day one), a healthy amount of chicken in my soup, all of which looked like white meat. And for $8, it felt completely worth it.

Yelpers say there is often a line, but I went around 2pm for takeout and didn't have any problem getting my food in less than 10min.
author: Jason B.

description: This is one of the places my coworkers and I go back to frequently.  The curry fish noodle soup is absolutely amazing.   The first 3-4 times I went here, I always ordered the same thing.  I've been branching out and trying some of the other dishes, such as the crispy noodle dishes, etc, and have been generally pleased with each choice.
author: Raymond M.

description:
tasty clay pot rice.
good noodle dishes.
quick service.
area fave.
eat here if you like good food.
author: Jeff W.

description:
I'm from San Jose, city full of Vietnamese Restaurants! Sai's is nothing compared to these places, but the odd thing is during Lunch time, there is a line down the block. If you want a quick bite, not a good place to go to.

THe food is pretty decent just the price is way too expensive for what it is. 

It's not like it's a nice restaurant or anything, I think it's just convenience and it might be the only Vietnamese restaurant close by.
author: Tam T.

description:
I had the beef curry noodle soup here. Amazing, delicious dish! Huge portions, just the right amount of spicy and creamy, and served steaming hot.

The only thing I didn't like was the wait to get in. You basically have to come at 11:30am to get a table or else risk not getting one. Also I tried calling in to make a reservation (which you can do) but when I said it was a table of two the guy who answered the phone yelled at me. :(
author: ting b.

description:
*3.5 stars*

An old standby but I don't come here for the pho.  I always enjoy the bun w/ the BBQ pork and imperial rolls.  All of their salads are good too EXCEPT for the chicken, which is dry and flavorless (it's probably just boiled w/o any seasonings).  I have ordered their chicken & shrimp hot pot and it was SO tasty!  LOVED the "burnt" rice at the bottom of the clay pot.  Last time ordered the lemongrass chicken clay pot.  I wanted to double check with the server if the rice was served INSIDE clay pot, she assured me, "yes" it was.  But when I got my food, rice was served on the side.  EXTREMELY disappointed. 

I have also ordered a fried egg (both over-easy and sunny-side up) on top of my rice dish w/ grilled pork and the yolk was served fully cooked both times. 

Needlesstosay, I do not ask for anything "special" anymore.  Just stick to the menu.  Oh, and if you want a seat at lunch immediately, go BEFORE 11:45.
author: Christine T.

description:
This place is DISGUSTING!!
THE ONLY REASON WHY IT'S POPULAR IS BECAUSE IT'S THE ONLY FREAKING VIETNAMNESE RESTAURANT AROUND THAT AREA... I rather walk up 3 blocks and eat at the better and cheaper pho places in Chinatown.

OK why do I think it's nasty? 

Because the service is very very slow, and it's very dirty and it's about $2 more on every item than an average decent Vietnamnese place. 

A month ago I went there for lunch. Had their stupid curry noodle beef and was sick for a week afterwards.

When they gave me my tea, I saw a large moth (close to dying) freestyling in the lukewarm tea. Then it hit me, everyone in that restaurant were drinking this MOTH TEA because the place don't bother to serve tea in individual teapots, it comes from that stupid huge tea tank.

Well yup, that's what you get for eating there I guess.
author: Catalina C.

description:
This is not one of SF's great Vietnamese places.  But it's so much better than the awful $8 bowls they peddle over at Pho Hoa that the entire Embarcadero crowd seems to come here for lunch.  Gotta get to Sai's by 11:45 or else you will wait.

The clay pots and curry noodle soups rock my world.  The pho, not so much.  There's better pho two blocks away, on Jackson, up the hill past Kearny.

But unlike the Chinatown pho places, Sai's takes credit cards, so it keeps perpetually cash-less people coming.
author: Ben A.

description: The service is pretty quick which was nice but the food was ok. I had their Spring Rolls and Vermicelli dish, I've had better in the East Bay. But from what I saw, everyone ordered the Pho so I think I'm going to try that next time.
author: Linda L.

description:
The best thing about this place are the beef/chicken spring rolls!!!! They are the best I have ever had in my life.. So good!!! REALLY GOOD!!! 

the pho sucks!
author: Tony L.

description:
Sai's is a rare gem in an otherwise uninteresting culinary part of town.  I used to go to Sai's at least once a week when I worked in the Financial District.  Now that I work from home all I do is fantasize about the day when I will revisit this glorious mecca of vietnamese goodness.

I usually get the same order of coconut curry fish.  It comes with celery but I usually substitute it for broccoli at no charge.  Pho is average but good on a cold San Francisco day.  

Beware, this place is packed at lunch hour with a line out the door, smaller parties of 2 have a much easier time of being seated.  If you know me I'm all about the price + portion = good value.  Sai's definitely embodies this equation.
author: Micah W.

description:
I've been here a couple of times and really like it. The food is very good and the service is attentive. I agree with others, the vermicelli bowls are great! 
Wonderful place for a quick dinner after work and you cannot beat the price!
author: Robert N.

description:
Heard from coworker so I tried.. disappointed.

$8 for pho and it tastes so bland... the beef is not the kind should be used for pho. (It is like the stir fry kind)

After hearing the staff speaking Chinese and reading the reviews, I believe the owner/chef is not Vietnamese.

I will go one time and try a Chinese dish. If that doesn't turn out good, I will not be back again.
author: Iris C.

description:
I got a seat right next to the cash register.  Actual quote from a newbie ordering takeout:  "Oh, cool, I SO didn't know this was even a Vietnamese place.  I'm SO fu$&ing going to eat here all the time."  You go, dude.

Anyway, my bowl of bun was a big bowl of fun!  I went with the imperial rolls and pork.  I really enjoyed it and give it a decided edge over the same dish at Golden Star.  The pork bits weren't as questionable as those I find in GS's version.
  
Service was fast and frenzied during this lunch hour, but my cup of tea was never unattended.  I vow multiple return trips here.
author: Daryl E.

description:
As I've mentioned, I'm not a fan of Vietnamese food usually.  I liked PPQ only when I was in the mood.  But Sai's blows me away, no matter what mood I'm in.

They have this amazing knack with green beans.  Yes, you heard me right - green beans.  Whatever dish they are in, they come out tender, crisp, and yet, flavorful.  I don't think I've had a bad dish there yet.  So far, my favorites are the Catfish Claypot, Lemongrass Chicken, anything with green beans, and Joel's Special.  And surprisingly, its not too greasy, considering.  I think that their emphasis on quality vegetables not drowned in sauce really helps.
author: Serena Y.

description:
I got beef pho.
Good broth. Questionable beef. 
$8 was kinda pricey for soup.
author: Stephen G.

description:
I didn't hear about this place, I smelled this place. It smelled so good as I walked by the first time. As soon as I got back to work, I asked my co-workers about Sai's and they all started telling me how good the place was. I had to try it for myself.

Lucky for me I work a block from this place.

Recommendations? Get there or call in your takeout order by 11:30. If you wait until noon, you will have to wait in line. The service is fast. Don't expect it to be too friendly. The price is right. The food is delicious. 

I think I just found my new favorite lunch spot!
author: Kathleen N.

description:
I found this place through my Vietnamese girlfriend. She said, "Kel, you have to come with me to this Vietnamese place for lunch, soooooo good." So of course I replied with "Let's go now!" Thank goodness I did, because we've been eating awesome lunches ever since.  Thanks Sally!

I'm a creature of habit, so my lunch of choice is an order of Vietnamese Pot Stickers (crispy rice around a succulent seasoned pork filling and dipping sauce) and their chicken curry noodle soup with an iced coffee in a to go cup. LOVE IT. I can never finish my soup, so I always get my left overs to go. Two lunches for the price of one. Oh yeah, and they pack it up for you too. Gotta love that. 

I heart this place. Go early or go late, otherwise wait in line. It's worth it.
author: Kelly K.

description:
For never having Vietnamese food before,  I thought the food was good, I ordered a combination dish that included chicken and veggie stir-fry, two fried Vietnamese spring rolls, a mound of rise and a side of beef. My friend got a bowl of pho.  The soup billowed over and depth of the bowl seemed to go on forever.   The service was incredibly fast though not very friendly.  But when you're on a lunch break you tend to appreciate timely service more than friendly service.  

After reading another yelpers review I was afraid that my spring roll was going to have dirt in it. So I ate it very slowly examining it for any dirt that I might be missing..  Luckily I didn't find any remnants of soil in my food.   :)  Had I done so I'm sure I would have been upset about it as well.
author: Meghan A.

description:
2.5 stars

I only come to Sai's when I want to share a nice lunch with my lovely coworkers.  It's more about the company, not the food that I enjoy when I'm dining here.  I'm just not that big of a fan of this place.  It's considered a hike from my office building, so I'd much prefer walking a couple blocks more to enjoy better Vietnamese food in Chinatown.  The food is priced at least $1-2 more than other neighboring Vietnamese restaurants too.  Oh, and not to mention that you have to get here at 11:30am or 1:15pm to avoid the long line out the restaurant.  

I've had the bun rieu (crab meat noodle soup), beef pho, and five spice chicken bun here.  They are average at best.  I especially didn't like the five spice chicken because the chicken was really mushy and so soft that it did not require any chewing...very weird.  I think some of the dishes lean closer towards Chinese rather than Vietnamese, and is a bit Americanized, all probably to accommodate the FiDi working people.
author: Diane L.

description:
This place is pretty darn good for lunch.  I've gone here a few times and have only gotten the pho (beef and seafood @ $7.95).  I've never been able to finish the huge bowls.  May be a personal goal of mine here in the upcoming months, though food coma may make coming back to work impossible.  Darn.

It definitely fills up quickly around noon-ish, so you're either going to want to get there around 11:30am or 1:00pm.
author: Chris M.

description:
YUM! I give them 5 stars for being a simple and delicious place. 

I went here after hours (5pm) so the place was not crowded like it would be at lunch. And I think I would recommend coming in at this time, because the place has a very relaxed, casual atmosphere that I feel is hard to find in the Fin. District. 

So the food. Delicious! Fresh and very tasty. Other vietnamese restaurants I have been to were not as skillfullly tasty as this one, but maybe I haven't gone to other better ones.

Anyways, I order vegetable chow mein and green beans in black bean sauce. Maybe not the most adventurous but what they hey, I'm a white girl.

Go here satisfy your tummy and relax with a yummy cup of tea and teapot.
author: Jade I.

description:
I used to work within walking distance from Sai's.  We used to plan lunch escapes so that we'd get there before the lunch crowd got crazy or very late lunches (same reason).  

Now that I'm not even remotely close by, I still make a point to go every now and then (but I usually go for dinner when it's not crazy, and after 6 pm -- when there is free street parking).  Every person that I've introduced has loved this place -- totally hole in the wall but DELICIOUS!  Curry Chicken Noodle Soup, yep, I agree that one is good.  And when I could come here a few times a week (I think I must have had more disposable income then, too), I would get that once.  But, what I dream about are the Shrimp w/ Eggplant over rice.  YUM!
author: Patty W.

description: Good Vietnamese, but I have had better. The 5 spice chicken is good, and the clay pots are good. But the pho is just okay. The broth tasted a little off, and they only had beef ball and steak, none of the tripe or tendon. Also pricing wise, it's like $1-2 more expensive than normal. Probably because it's in the financial district.
author: Eddy N.

description:
My friend and I came here for lunch around 11:30, earlier than usual, and I'm so glad we did because exactly at noon there was a long line of people waiting to be seated. The food is good. However, not only are their portions HUGE, the ingredients are very filling and fatty, which make me full quite fast. I ordered chicken chowmain and halfway through it, I already felt like I had enough. I just wish their food was a little lighter because I don't want to stuff myself.

Will I come back? Probably not. :)

Ok, I don't want to leave this review with out saying something good about this place. So, here I go. Good location, the service is great, and although their portions are large and fattening, it will definitely satisfy a very hungry customer. ;)
author: Narina A.

description: Sai's is the only other vietnamese place by work I know of for a rice plate or a limited bowl of pho (they don't serve tendon or tripe). The prices are the typical FiDi prices. I basically only come here for convenience. It does get busy quick & gets stuffy during the warmer seasons. My most recent stint was a take out order. Seafood pho. This is one of the only places I've ordered pho to go and had gotten it all in one container.  By the time I got it back to the office the noodles were mush and the container was 90% Seafood pho contents & 10% soup.  I only work a few minutes away. Not a very enjoyable way to have a bowl a pho. At least I 'm aware for my next to go visit. Note to self...stick with the rice plates!
author: Stephanie D.

description: Combo with imperial rolls, battered/deep fried shrimp, bbq pork, and a chicken/veggie dish w/cabbage salad--pricey by Asian food standards, but not bad.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
I had been wanting to try this place for a while. Finally on a FREEZING San Francisco day, I figured it was the perfect day.

We arrived to Sai's at 12:15..."Oh Sh** the line is out the door!"

We asked some people standing outside the door if they were waiting for a table, and they told us that we could just walk in and order, SWEET! I told the guy behind the counter that we wanted the "white noodles, with beef & the sauce," I'm not sure what number it was, but it was what I was expecting, it was the beef Vermicelli with egg rolls on top.

Luckily my bro & I split it, because it would have been way too big for one person! $8 for a two person lunch & we ate in the park...not a bad deal! And the food was good!
author: Elaine S.

description:
Gets crowded here for lunch. I've been twice - hated one dish and really enjoyed the other. The fish dish in the clay pot was not what I was expecting (I was expecting fillet over rice in a baked bowl)... instead it was on this huge plate with sauce with white rice separately. The good dish was the crispy seafood noodle dish. Huge portion, great toppings and good food. 

I guess I ordered the wrong bad dish. I would still come back to get my vietnamese fix since it's fairly close to work.

I don't think there's a bathroom at Sai's, which is really odd.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
One of the closer vietnamese places to work, introduced to by my coworkers.  Should definitely try and come early because there's usually a wait.  -_-

Swung by at around 12:15 last visit and had to wait a good 20-30 minutes.  Saw a lot of people order the curry noodle soup, so I went with that.  A bit too heavy with the coconut milk for my liking, so probably won't try again.  Though I do have to commend them for the chicken.  The chicken looks dry, but it's uberrrr juicy.  

One downside of the restaurant is that it's a bit crowded, a bit run down, and doesn't really have good ventilation.  So it's mucky and everything feels dirty.  EWWW GROSSS

Though all else aside, I'd still come back and would love to try their clay pot rice one day.
author: Emily L.

description: I gave this place  no star and a ( - ) !! this place is nasty dirty and bad bad customer service!!!!!! the cook is rude and the lady who seated u is also rude.. they glossip and talk bad about you.. right over ur shoulder !!! dont go there.. these women will ruin your day!!!  because they're ruin the rest of mine day :(.. it was bad choice for me to eat there.. to make thing better i would like to have this place shut down or even go out of business.. to have no manner like them shouldn't even be in the business in the first place!
author: Vi P.

description:
I come here once a week, and the food is pretty good. They lay the msg pretty thick, so there is this chappy taste after you finish the meal ( kinda like the taste after a zinc lozenge) , the pho is pretty good, but the shrimp spring roll is kinda dry ( you can tell its premade and sitting out for a bit).

Anyways, this is pretty good for a financial district place. I mean, really, there are not many option in this area so I shouldnt be complaining at all. Just go running for 40min and work off that MSG. 

It gets crowded, so come early
author: B H.

description: I love this place!  I can remember the first time my aunt took me to work with her when was still in high school and we had lunch at Sai's.  Ever since then, I  have always had lunch here when I visited the Bay Area.  Now that I live here, I have a hard time not eating at Sai's all the time.
author: Nova H.

description: The food here is just ok.  I love vietnamese food because of the unique flavors.  I didn't really find that here.  The pho is pretty bland and there isn't much stuff in it.....it's mainly broth and noodles and a few slices of beef --- where is the tendon and tripe??  The rolls were ok too.  Good place to come for something quick but if you want something a bit more authentic, go elsewhere.
author: Clara A.

description: Ordered the beef and fish ball Pho.  The broth was great, but not a fan of the beef balls.  Get there about 11:30, because by Noon there is a long line to get in.
author: David L.

description: Great lunch spot.  Fast service, but the line is out the door if you get here noon or later.  Food is fresh and served hot.
author: Jay S.

description: I went here today with my friend/co-worker. We have been really depressed and missing our Pho since Hi-Tea closed down, and we have been sampling around lately. I got the Hot and Sour Chicken Pho. Not too much chicken in it, and they cut up the noodles so they are short and hard to grab. When we arrived at about 11:40 there was plenty of seating but about 5 minutes later there was a line out the door. That is what I didn't realize, this is not a take out place, therefor you have to tip. Who can afford that in this economy at noon? Not I....
author: Emily H.

description:
My co-worker introduced me to Sai's. I've been coming to Sai's for a couple years now. The prices have gone up a bit compared to when we first started coming here on our lunch. 

We are always greeted and seated in a timely manner (when we beat the rush at lunch). They never forget to give us our tea and ice water. We always order the fresh spring rolls as our appetizer to begin with, which we love dipping with a mix of the oyster sauce and the hot chili sauce. 

I like to try different items when I go there. I like this place because we have the choice of brown rice with our entree. 

Overall, a nice walk from the Embarcadero Centers with pretty good food.
author: Kaye C.

description:
Hate me if you will, but I've never been a big fan of PHO. So, I cannot speak to that aspect of this restaurant. I know you're thinking, "Vietnamese and no Pho, what the hell are you thinking, girl?"

Let me explain. I don't do hot beverages or anything remotely related - it goes back to when I was a kid and my dentist thought it'd be a great idea to yank all but like 8 of my teeth to prep me for braces, which led to the subsequent instant Lipton soup in my thermos which was either too cold by the time I got to it at lunch time, or too hot when my mom insisted I ask those mean looking lunch ladies for hot water and my soup wouldn't cool before we had to rush to the playground - ah, but I digress and that is one long run-on sentence.


Here's what I like about the restaurant:

GREAT VARIETY in the all the dishes they offer. Personally, I like their BUN (or vermicelli) bowls which are tasty and in healthy portions. The other two dishes I can personally vouch for are YELLOW CURRY and the STRING BEAN dishes. Unlike Thai dishes, they inhibit a mild spiciness for those of us who don't like to return to work with terrible heartburn.

If you have room for desert, the fried banana with ice cream is a good choice. Personally, I like to have it in place of your REGULAR meal. Then again, I'm a dessert fanatic.

Another GREAT thing about this place is that they accommodate LATER LUNCH HOURS for those of us working a job where we feel happy when our work allows us to take a lunch. 


Things to know about this restaurant:

They get PACKED during the usual lunch hour. Go just before or a little after to expect faster service.

Be prepared to get cozy. They seat family style.

You have to ask for water, but tea is provided automatically.

Service is LUKEWARM, at best, but they are quick.
author: Carrie S.

description:
Sai's is not the best Vietnamese restaurant I've ever been, but it's decent, fast and cheap (dishes are $10 or less).  The owners are Chinese/Vietnamese and are friends of friends.  On that account, I have to support.  Best of all, it's about 2 blocks from work.

Anyway, the secret is to show up at 11:30 - otherwise you're going to be sh*t out of luck!  The line will be too much to handle.  Service is not great (servers are too busy to pay attention to you), but you just have to get their attention and you'll get what you need.

Recommended dishes:  banh xeo (Vietnamese crepe, although a bit messy), imperial rolls, pho ga (that's chicken pho to you).
author: Quyen T.

description: Certain food cravings overcome you when you are furthest away from your ideal restaurant. So when I get hit with the Pho craving and I am working in the FiDi, a food wasteland, Sai's is about as good as it gets. Place gets slammed at lunch so I usually opt for take out, which is quick, and sit in the scenic Redwood tree lined park in the shadow of the Trans-America building. Nothing special on Sai's menu, usually order by the same number and out the door in 5 minutes flat with some decent Pho to cure the cold sweats.
author: Ryan G.

description:
One time I found a long black hair in my vermicelli and I thought I was going to throw up my meal.  I was so sickened, I vowed never to return.  And then, the other night, I was in a rush to pick up a quick dinner and walked in for an order of imperial rolls.  I was in there for maybe a total of five minutes and I was on my way.  $6 for 6 imperial rolls.  Pretty decent.  The rolls were nice and warm, but the dipping sauce was kinda tasteless.

Anyway, I still don't plan to go there again in the future except in emergency situations.  I mean, I walk by that place all the time and see how messy and dirty their back room is.  Blech.
author: spiff e.

description:
This place bites.  They served better pho at the Hanoi Hilton.

I probably have gone here a total of 5 or 6 times.  Each time I tell myself, maybe it was just a bad day.  Nope.  I don't know about you, but if you can't make good pho, get out of the business.  The pho beef noodle soup should be the foundation to any Vietnamese restaurant.  It's frickin' soup!

So the last (and final) visit this week, I ordered the Five Spice Chicken with Pho.  They don't serve that.  You must buy the 'over rice' and then we can give you soup, they said.  Cool.  We sat down.  Server comes up, I ask him for the order and a pho on the side.  $3 dollars.  THREE DOLLARS.  For a side bowl of soup.  No meat, just broth.  Great.  So unless I get to keep the bowl they served it in, I had to decline it.  For principle's sake.

Bad move.

The chicken came out warm and GRAY.  How do you make chicken turn gray?  And it's not just my order, my buddy had the same problem.  Great.  Ok, so we dive in.  The chicken had the consistency of liver.  LIVER.  Like did I order a pate sandwich?  What is going on.  The skin was soft like microwaved.  I can't believe they served this slop to me.  

Sorry Sai, but I'm giving you two weeks in the box.
author: Isaac L.

description:
MMM Pho!   Soup and Sai's with my 2 best work friends is the ONLY thing I miss about my ex-job. That job sucked and it makes my head hurt to even think about it, but the Bo Pho at Sai's made it all ok, well almost ok. 

It does get crazy at lunch time , so sneak out early if you can.
author: cynthia a.

description: Love this place. Give it a try! I imagine it gets hella busy at lunch, but everytime I eat here, it's great. The place is clean, clientele does not seem like a bunch of insane people. Service is great. Can't really get any better than that. You can really just pick anything on the menu because you know that it will be good.
author: Rich_kids_of_yelp Z.

description: this is the best vietnamese food,I went here solo for lunch and I have since returned multiple times. I have enjoyed everything they have served.
author: Nicole R.

description: A tad more pricey than Chinatown vietnamese places, but quality of meat superior and seating a bit less cramped.  A great meal except my friend's order took so long, I was nearly finished by the time his arrived.  Reduction of one star as a result.  However, he reports the imperial rolls were the best he's ever had.
author: Marc S.

description: Pretty decent Pho for lunch.  Prices of course reflect the proximity to FiDi but still plenty of Asian customers.  Didn't find it crowded at all when we arrived at 12:45 and food came out super quick.  Unfortunately the waitress forgot my Vietnamese iced coffee but at least it wasn't on the final bill.
author: Jean K.

description: I got the lunch special with a combination of chicken, BBQ beef, fried shrimp, egg rolls, and salad. Portion's good, but I didn't really like the chicken or the beef.  But the sides were good. So, I don't think I would re-visit this place again, because I'm picky about how my meat should be cooked.
author: Young N.

description: This is a nice lunch Vietnamese place near work. Pho on a cold day, their noodle dish, rice dish, clay pot, they are all good. Avoid the peak hour 12:00 - 1:00, I usually go after 1:00 and get seats right away.
author: Yoko S.

description:
Honestly, Sai's is about as average as Vietnamese food can get.  It tends to get ridiculously busy during the lunch rush (especially between 12:00 and 12:45), and there can be long waits for the food even after you've been seated and ordered during this time.  

Everything that I've tried off the menu is about average quality - which is kinda a mixed bag.  On the one hand, I've never had anything from here that I'd classify as bad, but then I've never really had anything at Sai's that I'd call great.  

At least it is a relatively good Vietnamese place within reasonable walking distance from my office, and the prices are fair.
author: Matthew H.

description:
Sai's is one of those things I've never been especially appreciative of.  I spend a lot of time bitching about the shitty quality of all the shitty lunch food in the financial district, and I feel like Sai's doesn't get enough respect. From me. In general.

Because it's not somewhere I ever really recommend to anyone, or anywhere I even really ever think of when I'm not at work. But that seems discordant, because when I AM at work, nothing punctuates the day quite as well as dirty little Sai's and their fucking awesome clay pot and their crazy ass vietnamese iced coffee, and for about $14, the day is survivable. And even sometimes fun.
author: Megan W.

description:
Best flavor in vietnamese pho but too pricey for just beef broth noodle soup.  I think it's totally overpriced.

I spent $9 for noodle soup. (I could've had healthy huge portion salad at Mixt Green for $7.50)
author: N. C.

description:
Quick and tasty hot lunch in the Financial District.

As long as you don't go at 12:05-12:40 pm.

Don't do it.

I warned you.
author: Matthew R.

description:
This place looked perfect. 

My old roommate and I wandered unknown areas of the Fidi in search of adventure and noodles.  And if adventure wasn't in the cards, then noodles would do.  And if no noodles were to be found, some decent ethnic food would do.

I had had my fill of sammich's for the week.

When we stumbled upon Sai's, which was packed, it was destiny, and I was hungry.  We had passed on YoYo's because they did not have any seats (i had never been so I didn't know it's a grab and go) and Thai Express Something-or-Other was mostly curries.  

My partner in Noodle Adventure got some Crispy Noodle Combinationy thing that Sai's mysteriously calls 23-1/2.  I got the garlic basil chicken, figuring you can't go wrong with that.

I, unfortunately, wished I had gotten what my friend got.  

It wasn't horrible, but it wasn't quite what I expected and the meat was dark meat, and it was gamey and sinewy.

Needless to say, these three stars are for the noodle dish.
author: Jen I.

description:
I'll tell you one thing about Sai's... They got some BIG cojones.

They serve rather mediocre vietnamese food for more than 7 bucks a dish, RIGHT next to chinatown where you can find at least 4 places with equivalent (or better) food for less. Yet they STILL draw a big crowd everyday at lunch. i don't know how they do it.
author: Bernie L.

description:
Get here early.  Seriously, the wait is redonkulous sometimes.  If you do manage to get seated, there's a lovely curry soup that's super appetizing, though when I asked for spicy, he must've looked and me and thought that I was kidding cuz there was no heat in my soup.

Ah well, good thing there was Sriracha at the table.

Vietnamese iced coffee always manages to flow without getting clogged.

Service is fast.
author: Anonymouse C.

description:
3.5 stars.

it's hard to find good vietnamese place in the financial district for lunch if you're not in the mood for charles phan vietnamese.  sai's is a good option when i'm craving some old school pho or a big rice plate.  much better option than pho hoa, their closest competitor in the area.
author: Helen T.

description: The pho here is garbage and the imperial rolls are stale.  This isnt the worst pho I''ve eaten but its definitely on the bottom.  This place is also pretty expensive.  piece.
author: Fatty A.

description:
Good Vietnamese food but a bit overpriced.

When we had a craving for some Vietnamese cuisine in downtown, we would stroll over here.  My coworkers would get the PHO noodle soup ($7), coconut curry fish($8), and I would get their pork chop specials($9). All of which were decent but I've had better for a cheaper price.

I think the price is due to their location. Downtown restaurants are notoriously more expensive.
author: Bert T.

description:
I got here with my dining partner at 12:30 and were seated right away, which was nice because five minutes later the line was out the door. The first thing you will notice is the amazingly great smell that greats you as you enter (if you haven't smelled it walking down the street already)Seating can be a little cramped, but we were on the end of a table and had plenty of room.

I had the mango beef from the chef's recommendation page and my DC had a clay pot. My mango beef was good with very flavorful mangoes, but the clay pot was a little lacking in flavor and tasted more like the soy sauce she put in it than anything else. After reading so many reviews about the amount of food that they serve, I was disappointed with what we got. My beef dish didn't even fill me up and I found myself eating a granola bar as soon as I got back to my desk. 
With a price of about $8 a person I'm willing to go back and see if one of their other dishes offers more quantity.

A nice touch was that they let us sit and talk as long as we wished without rushing us out the door and even kept refilling our tea multiple times after the meal was over and the plates were cleared.

They get 4 stars for the flavorful beef I had, + 1 star for not rushing out the door, -1 star for the less than expected quantity = 4 star total.
author: Russ C.

description:
Sai is alright.  Especially compared to the very accessible cheap Vietnamese restaurants a couple of blocks away in Chinatown.  It isn't any closer to walk here from downtown than to go into Chinatown.  So it doesn't seem to have any real advantages.  The unimpressive decor, loud environment, busy lunch hours, quick services---it has it all. 

I ordered the Lemon Grass beef bun, which is listed as one of its specials.  The beef is pretty flavorful, but I can taste the abundant onions much more than the lemon grass.  

I do think that Sai deserves a second chance though.  I might like it more if I had tried more dishes.
author: Candice B.

description:
Its a good place to catch up with people during lunch in a busy atmosphere, but I dont recommend it for the food.  Good Vietnamese food is hard to find, especially authentic pho. Ever since Ive been going to Saigon Bay in Sacramento (college times), I cant seem to find any good vietnamese restaurants in the city, or in fact, anywhere in the bay area. Ive searched in San Jose, East Bay, etc, and no luck. 

If you want to spend $9 on lunch, go here. But honestly, if I wanted to spend that much money on lunch, i would go to the mall and get the thai food in food court.
author: Chieko H.

description:
This is a very busy lunch spot, but service is fast...you're in and out of this place in under 30 minutes...after a very satisfying meal.

I like the #51 here -- "Sauteed Beef Cubes"  This is the "Shaking Beef" you can find at Slanted Door, 'cept you can still have enough money to buy yourself dinner afterwards.  (And since you're not paying a lot for the food, the owners clearly didn't invest too heavily into remodeling the place in over 20 years....)

Go for the #51.... it gets 5-stars!
author: Jennie L.

description:
Took me a little longer to get around to writing this and the next few reviews.  I was actually in SF last week, and had the chance to try a few new restaurants up there.  However, the whole week's experience overall was so uninspiring that I just haven't had the urge to write them down.

So how can I be so uninspired and still give Sai's a 4 stars?  Now the food there is actually pretty good.  There was a long line out the door for lunch on a regular weekday, but the line moved really fast which was good.  I ordered the lamb curry soup w/ rice noodles, and the lamb was really tender and flavorful.  The ice coffee was pretty good too.  The "bun" that my friends ordered looked really good too.

BUT,...is Sai's any better than Golden Deli in San Gabriel, or any of its 3 sister restaurants just 1 mile away from each other?  Is Sai's better than Pho 79 on Garfield?  Nope...I guess its pretty close...but why would I want to stand in line outside a restaurant just for Vietnamese food? =P
author: Ta K.

description: I enjoyed my Pho today. I ordered it as Pho Tai (this is the one without the meatballs) I will go back!
author: Danielle V.

description: I work just around the corner from here and stop by every couple of weeks for some to-go tofu coconut curry. It's super good and a pretty decent portion. Not as spicy as I'd like it, but throw a side of Sriracha on it and you're good to go. Their imperial rolls appetizer are really tasty too. Every time I've dined in I've had a pleasant server--the younger guy is really nice and always makes conversation while I'm picking up my food too.
author: Sarah S.

description:
I love a great hole in the wall for lunch - because well it's lunch and who wants to spend 30 bucks only to waddle back to work full and poor?? Sai's is a great lunch spot if you work in downtown or are visiting the area (its right down the street from Chinatown proper). 

We ordered spring rolls and imperial rolls to start off our meal - very good. These were made fresh and the imperial rolls were not over fried which gets two fist pumps in the air from me. There is nothing worse than overdone imperial rolls. The spring rolls were fresh and one order was the perfect amount for a party of four. 

The menu was actually pretty large for this hole in the wall establishment - Pho, Clay Pots and hot dishes a plenty. Having already had my share of Vietnamese food recently I selected the Clay Pot. Partly because I love the flavors cooking in a clay pot bring out in a dish and also because it was slightly too warm in the restaurant (due to the full house for lunch) for pho which I love. My coworkers order Pho, green beans and beef and the Basil Garlic Chicken. All dishes other than Pho came with a large portion of rice which was perfect to soak in all the goodness from our respective sauces. I give it 4 starts for the flavors, the huge line out side on a holiday workday (sign there is some goodness going on up in there) and the lightning fast service. We never had to wait for water or tea and they were all very attentive to their tables. We split the bill in 4 and it came to 15 bucks. Not bad for two apps, an entree and tea. 

I will be back again and suggest you try this little hole in the wall sometime soon!
author: Heidi S.

description: Just a cheap spot to grab some lunch during the week. Everything I have ordered has been pretty damn good, but I love the chicken and shrimp clay pot. It can get pretty busy during the lunch rush between 11:45 and 1:30 so you may need to wait for a table.
author: Tony S.

description:
Blend and overpriced...don't understand the frequent line there.

Some dishes are prepared ahead of orders, be sure to ask if you go if they will make it from scratch or just re-hit something previously prepared.
author: Laurent G.

description:
So I came here to meet some fellow Yelpers for lunch.  Hiked about 8 blocks to get here in uncomfortable shoes and this only made me more famished.  I was a little hesitant when I saw the room full of people and thinking we would never eat...but the server was very prompt in taking our orders.  Of course there are so many choices that I sounded like a total idiot.  When I finally settled on the 5 spice chicken, I let my metrosexual companion twist my arm into ordering some pot dish..which was tasty...but I don't care for mushrooms.  Oh it's not that type of pot.  The Vietnamese aren't that progressive with their cuisine!

I really like the girls at Vietnam and this isn't ultra convenient to work...but if you get a craving for Vietnamese at lunch time, this is definitely worth noshing at.
author: Amy Z.

description:
A co-worker of mine dragged me to this place during a lunch break and I am absolutely hooked! :)  Everything from the spring rolls to the chow mein and the lovely Jasmine tea is so enjoyable.

Sai's is especially strong in the seasoning department, and I love the hint of garlic in the vegetarian chow mein.  It's just enough to accent the dish without overwhelming the flavor of the vegetables. 

Equally, the sauteed bean curd with lemon grass is just as amazing!!!  This place would definitely get a five star review if it wasn't such a zoo and if the restaurant itself had a little more aesthetic charm and grace.  The quality of the cuisine would most certainly cost a bit more if the restaurant was on the fancier side.
author: Jacqueline T.

description:
Definitely a great sit-down lunch around the financial district, although you'll have to fight the wait associated with any decent restaurant near this location at lunchtime.  I have had the chicken clay pot, veggie spring roles (refreshing, crisp, and great peanut sauce), and 23 1/2 (loved the sauce and veggies over the crispy noodles, but should have fought the urge to finish the entire dish) and would recommend all these dishes.  

The prices are reasonable for really great tasting fresh cooked food.  The fact that Sai's is a few blocks from my office doesn't hurt either.
author: Morgen N.

description:
The place was packed. Luckily our group of 5 got seated in 5 minutes.  Service was great.  What we got & what we liked :
Hot and sour soup - Excellent, opened up those sinuses. But watch out for the green chillies and jalapenos 
Vegetarian spring roll - rice paper on the outside was too thick and hence chewy.
Bean Curd and Three mushrooms :- not as flavorful as it could be.
Catfish in the pot : Quite good
Vegetarian crispy noodles : crunchy, shaped like a birds nest with vegetables in sweet tangy sauce.. umm okay.
author: Nilofer M.

description:
The pho is only so so.
The lamb curry noodle dish is too strong.

That said, I'm still giving the place 4 stars because the pork vermicelli bowl ("bun") is awesome.  It's bbq pork in rice noodles.  It's worth going just for this dish!

The place gets super busy during weekday lunches, but the tables clear relatively quickly.
author: Mike L.

description:
My gf turned me onto this place for lunch one day.  Love the chicken vermicelli pho when I am sick.  It has some serious healing powers...haha.  Have tried other dishes there and it's pretty good, but always still come back to my favorite chicken vermicelli.  

It is very busy around lunch time, but usually get the soups to go around dinner. Very nice people who are quick with service.
author: Dan D.

description:
Just went there for lunch. I thought it was great food for a fair price -- I had the Beef Bun lunch plate. Very yummy.

I got there a few minutes before noon with a friend and we were seated right away.

Good weekday lunch spot.
author: Simon S.

description: This place is always stacked. I had the Pho Ga, my standard choice at most Vietnamese restaurants and I was not disappointed. The deep friend spring rolls were tasty too.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
I love Sai's their food are great and price is right. 

But today I wanted a to go box and one of the box had a small baby cockroach and when I was trying to kill it, one of the waiter just came by and killed it and walk away. I had another box and this one was worst I see baby cockroaches eggs and feces and baby cockroach in the take out box. And two weeks ago my coworker had a string of hair in her noodle soup.

I seriously think they need to have the whole restaurant clean up.
author: Sally L.

description: Coming to this place for lunch once a week, love the Beef Stew Noodle Soup, service is good and fast.
author: Alex C.

description: BEEF. CURRY. STEW.  It's truly amazing.  Huge, thick chunks of beef, slow cooked till it just falls apart on your lips.  Great flavors, potatoes, carrots, and a nice spice.  Add the hot sauce, and you're in heaven.  Very comforting.  Can't say enough about the beef!  Really liked the imperial rolls as well.
author: Jon S.

description: I am quite a regular at this place. I usually order Beef Pho which I found yummy. There was one time that I ordered pan fried cashew with chicken. The sauce was ok but the chicken taste odd. I think to come to this place you have to know what to order.
author: C I.

description:
sai's is great (relatively speaking).  definitely far from the best vietnamese food i've had, but in the FiDi, this is the best you're gonna find.  hence the lunchtime line-out-the-door on busy days (beware).

i'm a big pho fan.  it's not special here, but absolutely nothing wrong with it.  the rice plates are pretty good here too (try the sesame chicken).  and, you can't go wrong with the shrimp spring rolls (and peanut sauce!).

so why the 4 stars...?
- usually nice service
- free hot tea
- good (but not great) pho and rice plates
- and (my favorite) they are open pretty late and the pho to-go is great!  they package everything for you with the noodles separated, with all the add-ins too

just arrive early before the FiDi lunch rush!
author: dan a.

description: The chicken and shrimp clay pot is the Chinese-Vietnamese version of the Korean dol sot bim bim bap.  Burnt rice rocks.
author: Wakako U.

description: Good stuff. The pho or the claypot dishes are both winners. Prompt service because it's crowded at lunch. Lunch specials are huge, too, and probably the best value.
author: Brian B.

description: Handful of options on their menu for a vegetarian like me. Close to office and a good option for lunch. Beats the Pho Hoa Noodle Soup vietnamese two blocks away. Tried the Vegetarian Rice Noodles and the portion was very good for one.  Service is very quick and thats a plus on a busy working afternoon.  Although, the downside is the congested seating and not so great interiors.
author: Tan D.

description: This one of my fav's as i work in the financial district. Its "usually" super fast and tasty. The prices are good depending on what you have. Their shrimp and pork soft rolls are very good.
author: Andrew S.

description:
I wanted to like Sai's, because its extensive "vegetarian" menu is the only thing that sets it apart from the equally busy, closer-to-my-work Golden Star.

I am just losing patience for the number of long-established East Asian restaurants in San Francisco who insist on putting "vegetarian" sections on their menus when they must know by now that their interpretation of vegetarian does not match that of many of the people who keep them in business. When you do double-check, which I have learned I must do, the wait staff are often dismissive or evasive, which confirms to me that they are aware of this mismatch but perhaps believe that fish sauce is some "secret weapon" that makes their vegetarian dishes tastier, and that ignorance is bliss.

I'm vegan, and I went to Sai's for lunch for the first time with a vegetarian friend. I ordered the mixed vegetables with coconut and curry sauce from the vegetarian section of the menu.  When it arrived, it had tofu in it, which threw me off, because obscured by the sauce and veggies, the slightly crumbly strips of tofu looked sort of like meat (and the menu description of the dish did not note bean curd, which most of the vegetarian dishes are described as containing).  Since it did not occur to me that my dish might have tofu, I thought maybe they had brought me someone else's curry, and it was meat, so I just politely checked with the waiter that this was the vegetarian curry.  He sort of scowled at me and said it had oyster sauce in it--and then proceeded to inform me that "that was why" he had told my friend that the pho wasn't available vegetarian.  My friend had had the pho before at Sai's without meat (it's not on the menu, you have to ask) and was under the mistaken impression it was vegetarian--when she attempted to order it this time he had told her it was made with either beef or seafood broth. That's fine, she's asking for something which is not on the menu, I didn't expect them to have vegetarian pho broth on hand, though it's unfortunate that someone gave her the impression the dish was vegetarian on a previous visit. 

What's perplexing to me is that not so much that they use oyster sauce in a dish that is listed under a section of the menu that is marked (not "vegetables" mind you) VEGETARIAN, but that the waiter was essentially telling me it was my fault for not realizing that because the pho wasn't available vegetarian, this curry dish was not truly vegetarian also.  

Despite the grumpiness, he told me he would have them re-make it and whisked it away, though I told him he didn't have to (I hate wasting food more than a little oyster sauce).

Clearly this waiter has had this sort of experience before, as he seemed unsurprised, like he foresaw that I would reject the dish based on the fish sauce.  Why is it so hard to just correct your menu?  Or train your waitstaff to check with patrons who order off the vegetarian menu if fishy ingredients are okay or not?

I am usually against giving restaurants low ratings because of poor service.  The quality of food at Sai's is good, and the prices are reasonable.  The coconut curry was delicious (yes, even without oyster sauce!).  I wish there was a Vietnamese restaurant in town where vegetarians and meat-eaters could enjoy a meal together, but I guess I'll have to stick to places like Enjoy Vegetarian for my curries and black bean sauce dishes at lunch in the FiDi.
author: Tamara F.

description: A little expensive then the vet restaurant then the those in Chinatown. And the pho is not as Q.
author: Sky F.

description:
I have been working in San Francisco for over a year now and I have to admit that I am a weekly regular guest for dinner in this restaurant. What the interior might be lacking the food surely makes up for it. All dishes are tasty and freshly prepared.
Aside from having a good selection of Phos some of my favorites include: Chicken with 3 Mushroom, Chicken with Asparagus, Pork & Shrimp Clay Pot, Lemongrass Chicken Clay Pot and many more.
I can also recommend the Beef Spring roll appetizer. It comes with some fish sauce for dipping and it is just a delicious mix of flavors.
author: Jens S.

description:
The Seafood Pho #17 is terrible. Don't try it unless you like bland broth with a variety of imitation seafood. Even the little shrimps tasted a bit off. They do have much better service though than Golden Star, although, Golden Star has much better food.

I've tried this place four times, and still I don't get why they are so busy. I guess they have an excellent location.
author: Joon L.

description:
Love this place for lunch, but get there before 11:45 if you don't want to wait.

Try the shrimp toast!! They use slices of french bread.
author: Antonio S.

description:
This is a great place for a quick bite for lunch or dinner at a very reasonable price.  If you decide to have lunch there I would suggest arriving before noon because it gets very crowded.   

I've had the Pho and Bun (vermicelli bowl) which is simply delicious.  I didn't find the shrimp spring rolls to be that tasty because the peanut sauce they serve has this thicker than usual consistency, as if they added gelatin to it.
author: Oscar F.

description:
You know how they say for mexican restaurants "the dirtier the better"...well the same goes for Vietnamese food! Keep that in mind when coming to Sai's, but the food is so worth it! 

My work spouse and I (my best friend since college), always turn to Sai's as an instant mood picker-upper! I've only gotten the vermicelli #80 chicken (no skin), so I can't speak to the other items on the menu, but the vermicelli bowls are TO DIE FOR.

why you ask.....
- there sauce is not fishy (ew I'm not into fish sauce, this one is more taragon-ish)
- egg rolls are amazzzing
- the bowl is huge!!!

tip...
- after pouring the sauce on the noodles, use the container to mix sriracha and hoisin YUM dip your chopsticks into sauce and then grab some noodles.

The line get long if you don't get there at noon, but it's well worth the wait!

*for people who don't know what a vermicelli bowl is, it is cold rice noodles on a bed of lettuce, cucumbers, and bean sprouts- topped with meat (beef, bbq pork, or chicken) and egg rolls*
author: elyssa w.

description: The BEST Pho I have ever had... Now that I am in Denver and the weather is getting cold, I long for it. It's like crack in a bowl - absolutely delicious!!!!!! And the rest of their food? Equally good - try the clay pots for downright yummy-ness. The place looks like a hole in the wall, but the line that starts out the door tells it all. You have to get there by 11:30am or wait till after 1pm. Yeah, it's THAT good!
author: Alicia N.

description:
Yummy!!! Need some warm, comforting food? Look no farther than Sai's! Their Curry Chicken Noodle Soup (ask for it with all white meat) is out of the world!! Comes with big bites of potato, onion, and carrot. Delicious!

Inexpensive. Great for lunch. Great take-out service.
author: Kaitlyn G.

description: I might give this place 2 stars to be generous if it weren't for the fact that I had to wait in line to get lunch here. I had the pho- I lovvve pho. But... the meat tasted like cardboard, both in taste and texture. The broth was mostly flavorless. And it's loud and full of the FiDi crowd, which I am thankfully no longer part of. I left hungry and disappointed =/
author: Kate A.

description:
I wanted Pho for lunch today; is that too much to ask for? Because I'm sick I am hankering for something hot, spicy, liquidy and full of um um goodness (not the Campbell soup kind).   I was on a mission, I rallied a friend and she indulged me.  We head off to Pho in the Embarcadero Center.  It's backed up; we, being impatient people (and I'm starting to believe what they say about those who are patient), decide to take our quest up the street to another Vietnamese restaurant.  She suggested Sai's and persuaded me to give it one more chance.  I felt it necessary to return the same consideration she gave me (with the added "I don't really like that place, I've always left disappointed with their food, but okay, I'll give it another try"). 

The place is packed, nonetheless we are seated quickly; my luck is changing (or so I thought).  We are seated at a family style table, no worries, I like the idea of sitting next to two hot techy guys.  We order, my friend & her traditional chicken w/rice & fried veggies.  Me, I order lamb in curry soup with vermicelli noodles, and before the waiter got away, I ask, "is the meat fatty?"  The waiter says, "oh no, just meat..."  Sounds yummy to me, bring it on.  We wait; my friend is served first I'm served 7 minutes later; no worries. I dig in.  What the BLEEP! Bones, I was served a bowl full of bones!  No worries, the broth is good, I'll sip on this while trying to figure out how consume the rest of the soup in a lady like fashion without choking on all the bones.  I can't, I can't do it.  I have to use my fingers; who cares what the cute techy guys next to me think about my unlady like manners, I need to eat and its just lunch for God sake.
