I pick and I pick, but where to put the bones?  I place them back down on the table, where's the harm in that?  Surely, they don't expect me to put the bones back in my soup.  Too many bones to pick through so I give up and start my slurp.  Slurp, slurp, eek, what's this?  Again, in unlady like fashion using my fingertips, I pick out the sharp bone from mouth.  No worries, I'm a trooper, I really wanted this soup...  Slurp, slurp, AUGH!!!  I can't, I can't do it, I can't eat this, it has too many bones and I'm afraid I might swallow a sharp edged one and it will tear away at my tummy.  This shouldn't be a problem; right?  I can easily swap it out for some else on the menu; right?   

HAAAAH!!!!  Evidently not to the manager.
Manager:  You ordered this, that's what you get.  
Me: Sir, I asked your waiter if the meat was fatty, he said no but did not mention anything about bones.  
Manager:  No, you ordered this, that's what you get.  
Me:  Yes, sir, I understand that this is what I ordered, I wanted the lamb in curry noodle soup, but your menu does not mention anything about bones, nor does it say "traditional".
Manager:  Fine!  That's one way of getting out of paying for your lunch.  (picks up bowl and quickly walks away muttering things under his breath as he goes).
My friend:  Wow!  What was that about?
Techy guys:  Wow, WTF?
Me:  Hum, I wonder if the manager is going to give me something else without bones.

In my moment of quandary, the manager quickly walks back over and yells at me... What do you expect when you order lunch, what do you think you're going to get?  Is this a conundrum; I ponder...  I answer, "what I asked for".
Manager screaming:  You're just trying to get of paying, you're just trying to get a free lunch!  Walks away, returns quickly, drops the bill on the table and walks away again.

I had no idea what had just occurred, I was not rude, I was not insulting, and if given the opportunity, I would have been amenable in ordering an alternate soup.  Heck anything aside from bones as I really wanted Pho.  

Manager comes back to point out that he removed the charge from the bill and added he was aware our trying to get a free meal.   

My friend:  This guy is Unbelievable!  You're being so nice and he's being such an as_hole!  You're not even arguing with him.  What is his problem?
Me:  Don't worry about it, it's not that big of a deal.  The guy is obviously stressed and it's likely I am not the first to have complained about the soup.  Besides, I will NEVER return to this establishment, it's that simple.   And added, "have you ever heard of YELP?"  ;o)

Its 2:40; I believe I'll give my one of my favorite Pho places a call for some take-out.... It's that simple and Nothing can stop me.  =o)
author: Cris B.

description: I've been to Sai's twice and the food and service has been pretty good. Even during dinner time, there's a decent number of clientele. They have everything Vietnamese in the menu. I'll have to go back here several times to try the things that caught my interest. The prices are very affordable/reasonable so it is a good deal. I heard during lunch time there are lines to get a table, which is a good indicator of a good restaurant.
author: robby r.

description: Pho comes in all forms, their yellow curry noodle soup (pho) is amazing.  The chicken version #22 is a very safe bet but try the lamb #24 if you are a lamb person.  Although it looks like they chopped the meat in a lawnmower, the taste is out of this world.   soooo gooooood.   we go there at 11:15 and are the only people there.  by noon, when the line is out the door, im on my way back to work.   i hope this place lasts forever.
author: Conor B.

description:
good eats esp chicken basil 

portions are small

and prices keep going up faster than inflation and gold prices. wth

PET PEEVE!!!
also on the receipt, why do these guys have a 10, 15, 20% suggested tip that is based off the total after tax bill.  that is just wrong.
author: Bobby B.

description: I will recommend this place for lunch. The portions are big. Avoid going from 12-12:45pm or you can opt for take out (only a few minutes wait). The grass beef bun on the Chefs was yummy. LARGEEEEE portion for $8. My coworker ordered the curry chicken noodle soup, that was pretty tasty too.
author: Ervinna L.

description: I enjoyed my beef curry noodle soup very much.  There are many options in the Financial District and yet at the same time not that many.  I went at 1:30 and it was not crowded.  The service was good and the food was fast.  I'll go back, just not before 1:15.
author: Corey V.

description: I've had two take-outs from Sai's. Both experiences were just okay. The restaurant is very popular during lunch hours.The pho was good, but on the salty side. Combo plate was a little disappointing. The price range is also on the upper side compared to similar if not better Vietnamese restaurants.
author: Yi-Bing Z.

description: I agree with Yelpers Danielle L and James C., the Curry Chicken Noodle Soup (#22) is the bomb.  Everytime I go to Sai's I can't bring myself to order anything else.  I look at the menu each time, determined to try something new but I just can't seem to speak any other number (plus if you don't get your waiter on the first pass - fuggetboutit, he may not be back for a while).  I think I will just have to continue to eat vicariously through my nearest dining companions (intentional or otherwise).  I also love the bottemless glass of tea.
author: Becca B.

description:
i think my first introduction to sai's was years ago when a co-worker led me out of the radius of usual fidi lunch spots and walked me over into the shadow of the transamerica pyramid.  and so began my obsession with chicken bun (vermicelli) w/ imperial rolls.  it's been a while since i've made the trek back (since i'm now usually stuck eating lunch at my desk) but i still have fond memories of the wonderfully spiced chicken, the plethora of fresh veggies and herbs to mix in with the noodles, and the good crispy rolls.  

bare bones decor, brusque service, and definitely come before 12:00 if you want to even have a chance at nabbing a table.
author: Jen P.

description: My first time there today and I really liked "23 1/2" dish. Vegetables and shrimp over fried noodles.  Go there before 12 or after 1 to avoid the lunch time rush.
author: Lindsay T.

description: The Chicken and Shrimp Claypot are ridiculous good.  I have been to Sai's several times with the intent to order pho or something else but that claypot calls me every time.  I have tried the lamb curry pho (excellent) and some eggplant dish (not a fan).  The service is fast and efficient.  Lunch is served with complimentary hot tea, perfect for a cold SF day.  I highly recommend!
author: Kevin D.

description: I tried the beef pho earlier this week for dinner and was satisfied, but not particularly impressed.  The beef they used with thick and chewy...like the beef you'd find in a teriyaki bowl.  Since I basically only eat the rare beef in pho (I know, no fun) it wasn't my favorite bowl (esp. since it cost $8 for a sm/med size portion), but my friend swears by the other dishes here so I promise to give it another go.
author: Krystle S.

description: Great, cheap vietnamese food.  Interesting dishes and very clean.  I always see a line out the door. Gets really packed right at the typical lunch hour so go earlier or later than noon. Try their noodle soup specials.
author: Tanger T.

description: While the food is good overall, my primary gripe is that the waitstaff is a bit brusque. Otherwise, I enjoy their coconut-based soups (which I STILL can't replicate at home) and all the appetizers look great.  Sai's features that Vietnamese combo of fresh and fried ingredients that is oh so tasty.  You get enough soup in one order for two lunches but $9 is still too much.
author: Molly J.

description: Went here around 1:30 on a Friday for some rainy-day lunch.  The place was packed, but that only made it more homey.  The menu was varied, and the service was good.  They kept on refilling our free teacups, and kept the icewater coming.  The waiter was pushing the combo menu a bit, so I ordered the number 2.  It came out well-presented, with two meat dishes (BBQ pork and lemon grass chicken), a healthy portion of rice and salad, three pieces of shrimp and two imperial rolls all on a big plate.  All for 8.75.  Not bad.  However, I had to drop this place down from 3.5 to 3 stars when, to my disappointment, I found the bargain-bounty had come out luke warm.  But I'll give em a second chance.  Maybe.
author: Mr. G.

description:
Chicken & Shrimp Clay Pot = DELICIOUSO!

Takes about 20 minutes to make, and about 20 minutes to eat. Stir in some hot sauce and you're good to go.
author: Linda I.

description: Sai's is by far the best Vietnamese restaurant we've ever tried. My favourites are the chicken clay pot and the beef lemongrass spring rolls. The menu is pretty lenghty so there's so much to choose from. They are quick, inexpensive and service is always great! This place is bustling at lunch time so we'd like to go for dinner (they're usually open till 8:45pm) when its a bit relaxed. Henry, the all around manager, owner, server knows my boyfriend and I by first name... that to me, is quality service.
author: Medj M.

description: sai's a great lunch spot in fidi! there's occasionally a wait during prime lunch time, but it moves relatively fast. since we had a group of 5 today, the wait was longer than usual. they were so great-- gave us free imperial rolls to compensate for the wait!!! the imperial rolls are delicious and one of my fave appetizers on the menu. i love the 5 spice chicken here because it doesnt feel as unhealthy as other places. i usually get the combo rice plate with brown rice and all 5 spice chicken or the chicken vermicelli bowl. everything is reasonably priced and filling. i would definitely come here for a satisfying lunch and/or to get my rice plate fix.
author: Tiffany T.

description: A friend craved Vietnamese and we went for lunch. Good bbq thin slice of pork on vermicelli noodles and imperial roll. Busy, busy place, but what really grossed me out was that in their refridgerator case they had a container of something and green MOLD on the bottom of it that was just greeting the customers with a guileless grinning MUAAAHHHH .....i'll get you yet...my pretty...right in the stomach pains 3 hours later. Oh no you dint, ya i did.
author: miriam b.

description: It's a very quaint and humble restaurant, you get what you pay for 9quality is good and serving sized are generous). An excellent place to have lunch. My only complaint would be that, the way in is a little odd. Otherwise a great place
author: Josh L.

description: Keep it simple in your ordering and you'll be happy.  Delicious spring rolls.  Pho pho pho.  Clay pot dishes.  There's a lot of other stuff on the menu and it ain't that special.  But they make very fresh spring rolls and delicious pho that really hits the spot on an unexpectedly cold or wet day.  The curry soups are off the charts good (insert drool here) but all of the soups I've tried are delicious.  Fifteen years ago, we used to walk ten blocks or so for Sai's soups.  Now I work two blocks away.  I forget about it from time to time but I keep coming back.  I think I may have to go tomorrow.
author: Warren B.

description:
since most people seem to concentrate their reviews around Pho, so will I, ...3.Its pho, not dazzling, not fancy, not spectacular, its pho. Its not gonna leave an impression in your mind. If you live or work in the area and want pho, this is one of the only choices, but dont expect it to be the best pho you've had, it will do the job though.

There are better pho place, actually a lot of better pho places.

Of course they have other dishes, they are ok, nothing fancy either...you will not be WOWed by it.
author: A W.

description:
I used to be a regular at this place back when I worked right by the Transamerica building. 

Food: They have a decent selection of vegetarian items and most of them can be slightly customized to your taste. Although, when I say spicy, they simply added jalapenos instead of spicy sauces. Nevertheless, the food was always very tasty. I usually tried the bean curd over rice, coconut curry with rice or the crispy noodles with vegetables. The vegetarian spring rolls are not deep fried and almost a meal. 

Ambience: It can get extremely crowded during lunch time, so I usually called in and ordered a take out.
author: Rahul A.

description:
just ate at sai's
now my gut's over-sized
instead of doing work
 i just wanna sit back and sigh
author: James L.

description:
I was psyched when I found Sai's--a Vietnamese restaurant  right around the corner from my office!  A dirty one too!  For Vietnamese restaurants, I think there's a direct proportion between the number of health code violations and authenticity.  

Excited, I came in and ordered in Vietnamese.  They looked at me, confused.

"Sorry, I don't speak Vietnamese that well."

No one there spoke any Vietnamese at all.  Not surprisingly, the pho tasted like it was seasoned with MSG, soy sauce, and more MSG.    

Chinatown's too close to deal settle for Sai's.
author: Ann T.

description: The restaurant itself is a bit rundown, but it's not fine dining, so get over it.  The food is good.  I get combo #3.  It's normally priced for SF.  Show up early for lunch because it fills up fast.  I'd give it 3.5 stars because Perilla is better, but I'll round up because I like the place.
author: Daniel J.

description: Their menu is surprismgly cheap for being in the financial district. I'm a fan of the pho ga, squeeze a ton of lemon in it and I can eat that stuff for days. Just went there today actually. And there's enough for 2, and only cost $6.50 :) I did not like their vietnamese spring rolls though, I felt that the shrimp lacked flavor, and the rolls cost more than my pho! Fast service though, they are great at getting people in and out during lunch hour chaos. pick up service is just as fast too. I have never waited more than 5 min for my food.
author: Marina K.

description: The seafood pho I ordered was not good.  It was a big let down b/c it was a long trek in the cold and I wanted some tasty hot pho to warm me up but it was not tasty.  Maybe it was what I ordered...I'm willing to give it another try b/c I liked the looks of what everyone else in the restaurant ordered.
author: Debbie Y.

description: I don't know about the clean part, but it's delectable Vietnamese cuisine at a bargain price.  Try to beat the lunch rush if you can!
author: T-Bone L.

description: This little place is great and filled with a ton of smaller interesting looking employees that are very helpful and will bring you hot tea when you sit down before taking your order because they care about you and don't speak english very well and their food is very good as well as very cheap given the fact that it is in the financial district and right near where i work so i can just walk there which is a big plus because it gets crowded during lunch so i go after lunchtime and sit by myself and enjoy my barbeque pork over vermicelli noodles with a vietnamese iced coffee all for about ten dollars.
author: Ben R.

description: Very good cheap Vietnamese food right in the Financial District.  Get there early though as the line for lunch gets VERY long!  The pho w/ tons of rooster sauce is a favorite of mine :-)
author: Swarup B.

description: HORRIBLE. WHY WHY WHY do people like this place? There are SOOOO many better Vietnamese places just a couple blocks away in Chinatown, I don't know why people would waste their money, time or appetite at this dump. Their food is SOOOO sub-par, they give a bad name to Vietnamese food in general.
author: Deb I.

description: This place gets busy during lunch. I can see why too, they're like the only decent lunch place in the area. I've had better Vietnamese though. I wouldn't go out of my  way to come here and only do because I work semi-close by.
author: Lester L.

description: Sai's was the girls' lunch mainstay at my job.  Whether it was a cold, or a bitchy partner, or sheer mind melt, we'd hit Sai's for some pho ga.  Sai's experimented for a few months with rather subpar chicken, as in all sorts of tendons and chewy bits and bones, but we clammored for the old stuff.  After 2 months straight of ordering pho ga with white meat only, they reverted back to the good stuff.  Phew.   Vietnamese coffee-cum-jet fuel is kind of scary, it is so very powerful.
author: Pamela D.

description: The pho isn't good. The tomato vermicelli soup is bland. The rice plates are pretty tasty, but kind of expensive for Vietnamese/Chinese food.  I'd walk a few blocks up to Chinatown for a better value.
author: Tinou B.

description: So I've been to Sai's at least twenty times and I have to admit I only order one thing - the Charbroiled Pork with Spring Rolls over Vermicelli Noodles. Perfection in a takeout container. Crunchy fried goodness in the rolls and light, fantastically bland vermicelli noodles, topped with salty sweet pork product. All with a little veggies at the bottom to make you feel somewhat healthy and a container of nuoc cham to drizzle over everything. YUM.
author: Carissa R.

description: I love the tomato noodle soup with crab meatballs a lot!!  I tried seafood noodle soup but just like the tomato one.  I can eat there 2 times a week.  Too bad that it only opens Monday to Friday during lunch time.  Although it takes me 10 minutes to walk there from my workplace and I need to wait in line most of the time, I and my coworkers just love it.  The price is reasonable for downtown location, not perfect but it tastes good and the portion is good enough for me.  The waiters even give us some shrimp paste to add into the noodle soup which just gives additional sparkles to the bowl.  Expect it would be busy when the weather is cold and it is usually packed before 1pm.
author: Roserrele W.

description:
No complaints here. Closest Vietnamese place to my Sansome St. office, and I'll definitely be back.

I had the "two balls pho" - it was beef ball and fish ball, and I really enjoyed the combination. The broth was okay, nothing spectacular, but no complaints.

Portion was just the right size, and service (at 11:30, before the big rush) was quick.

I really liked that there was some kid's crayon drawing taped to the wall in the kitchen.
author: colin l.

description: The food is good. It's usually very crowded during lunch time. The seating is a little cramped. Food takes a while to be served, so prepare to wait. If you are getting food to go, you may want to call first. Food is pretty good, but if you are willing to walk a little to Chinatown, you could get it for cheaper and yummier.
author: Pika C.

description:
you open the doors, venture to the front for take out cuz there are no seats, look left look right, everything down the line looks really yummy and the clear glass teacups add a nice touch!  

the guy with 4 arms up front was efficient i thought, but then i got back to the office and had the wrong order.   all i wanted were some damn crispy noodles.  i got rice and vegetables.  or rather, i got rice and broccoli.  for $7.55, and it wasn't good.  you always want someone else's order because it looks better, or rather, you just want what you ordered.
author: Monk R.

description:
Good food, but they are not clean!  yikes!    go to myscores.com for info
(scary)
author: Claudia E.

description: Not a great place to go for Pho or any noodle soup here, but  the rice plates like the 5 spice chicken ,please add an egg or shrimp with chicken rice claypot is what yall should try. If you want pho, go some where else and stop complaining!
author: Daniel W.

description: This place is decent but not worthy of anything over 3 stars. Besides the rice-plate specials, the portions are undersized and I'm unimpressed by their pho. Service is quick but the place is always packed. Go early (11:45) if you want a seat. Or go to Golden Star if you want better food.
author: Jason A.

description: Big fan of Vietnamese food and this place doesn't disappoint.  The soup is not too greasy, yet it hits the spot and the 5 spice chicken melts in your mouth. The fried rolls could be a little bigger and the prices could be cheaper but overall very good!
author: Kan P.

description:
This place does a rocking lunch business because it delivers the goods. When you're in for the spicy meat thing go for one of the combos. But if you're ready to be warmed inside and out, it's the chicken curry, best as a soup but can also be had as a stew too. It's just astonishingly great. I remember coming in once on a cold cold day and ordering the chicken curry soup. Was seated across from another guy (yes it's that crowded) who had already ordered. Minutes later, when it arrived, we discovered we'd both ordered the same thing, and agreed there was nothing like it downtown. Deep, not-powdery in any way, perfectly spiced. A huge bowl. Take home the extra. 

When I'm in a healthy mode i've done the asparagus or beans with shrimp, which is excellent. You can ask them to make it spicier -- they're very accommodating. Most of the wait staff is all business, but Henry the owner or manager is a sweetheart. 

Oh, and if you ask you can get their "red rice," which some of the staff call "brown rice." Much better, but I think they charge you a little extra.
author: James N.

description:
Walked by here a few times before and always wanted to give it a try. I was walking to get some pho with a coworker when we saw that it was crowded and decided to ditch our pho plans and stand in line.

I had the clay pot rice with chicken and shrimp while my coworker had the basil chicken. My dish was bland. Just, nothing special. It was shrimp, chicken and some veggies over rice that may or may not have been cooked in the pot that it came in. My coworker's basil chicken was ok. The food wasn't bad, it just wasn't great. The thai iced tea was ok though.
author: eric c.

description: When its cold and gloomy in San Francisco I would feel like noodle soup.  So at lunch I would get Pho.  Sai's Restaurant is a great Pho Noodle house.  I would always get the Pho Tai.  The service is ok, even though I go there a lot I still get ignored at times. But I learned if I raise my hand I get attention.  Thier imperial rolls are good, but I feel like they are over fried at times.  I give it a 4 because i keep comming back.
author: Enrique M.

description:
I just went for the first time, and it was really good.  Had a great bowl of crab ball and tomato soup.  The Ban Xaio (fried pancakes) were a bit odd.  My favorite food when I was in vietnam, but these were huge and not like any I'd had before.  Still not bad.

Overall, it was quick, tasty, and the menu had lots of seafood and veggie dishes.  I'll be back.
author: Jeff W.

description: Cheap and Good. One of the better place in the financial distict to get authentic vietnamese food. Get the sizzling chicken and shrimp claypot! My personal favorite. Get there early cause it usually looks like the entire financial district is waiting at their door.
author: benjamin c.

description:
busy, slow at lunch
pleasant pork+spring roll eats
chinatown's better
author: Scott S.

description: The pho here is sickening. Broth tastes like soap and something else (metallic??). Chicken was aptly described by my companion as "questionable". Noodles are overcooked and one sticky lump. Everything I see people eating around me looks pretty appetizing, but, to me pho is the test. It's the one dish where you can't hide behind deep-frying. It's pure, or it's nothing.
author: Cindy Y.

description: Good food, fresh and well prepared.  The serving size is a little small and the prices are higher then other similar restaurants in the area.  Overall worth a stop.
author: Nicholas M.

description: I had to work this weekend and found that Sai's was open on Saturday afternoon - yay!  There was one waiter working, and it was not super busy, given it was Saturday.  I ordered plain pho (just soup and the plate of basil and bean sprouts that come with) and the catfish claypot, which has eggplant and yellow onions.  Mmmm mmmmmm.  The pho came in a humongo bowl and the vegetables were fresh.  Mmmmm mmmmm again.
author: Frank S.

description: This place is all about convenience.  The food is decent, prices are only slightly elevated, orders are received in a timely fashion, the staff are willing to accommodate special orders, and (for me) it's only a few hundred feet from the office.
author: Ryan M.

description: This place is right near my work and quite popular. The food is ok, but nothing spectacular. I have to keep reminding myself not to order chicken because it never seems very cooked when i get it and it really grosses me out. Next time I'll stick to vegetarian entrees. The vietnamese iced coffee is great though (hard to get that wrong) and the noodle dishes are tasty. Make sure to avoid weekdays btw noon and 1pm.
author: Ann B.

description: Lovely family run business.  Delicious food.  BUT, roaches running on the dining room tables.  I almost puked.
author: Michele L.

description: Sai's five-spice chicken is good.  It's one of the few places that serve good Vietnamese food at a decent price unlike Slanted Door.  Their spring rolls are good too.  It gets pretty crowded and loud in there but what place in the Financial District doesn't?  I don't think they take reservations so going there in a big group can extend your waiting time.
author: Tricia L.

description: Delicious and cheap.  We had pho, shrimp rolls and pancake with basil chicken and lime. If you come after the lunch run around 2 or 3:30 the owners will give you excellent service and make vietnamese comfort food.  Great place.
author: Spencer O.

description: I give this place 5 stars b/c it's always consistently delicious. My favorite dishes are the pork egg rolls, sesame chicken (amazing!), vegetarian vermicelli bowl, chicken noodle soup, and the chicken salad. The food is always fresh and the service is always fast and friendly. The price is pretty good for the portion sizes. It is one of the few decent asian restaurants in the city.
author: Molly B.

description: 5 stars for the chicken and shrimp claypot......been to some other 15 vietnamese restarants.....this is still on top for the claypot.
author: N N.

description: This is the world's greatest beef noodle soup!!! I've been eating this everyday for lunch twice a week here. It's seriously addicitng. I always order it to go though sicne it gets pretty crowded around here at lunch time. And the old man always recognizes me too behind those bushy eyebrows...
author: Crum B.

description: Love it, Love it. Huge noodle soup bowls, amazing spring rolls...all cheap for the amount of food you get. So the place is less than lovely to look at, but aren't alot of places here? Busy around lunch but well worth the short wait. Fast turnover times also makes it an easy fast stop during the lunch hour.
author: Big G.

description: TO BE AVOIDED: I had vegetarian spring rolls for lunch today at Sai's. I took a big bite. They had sand and dirt in them. A LOT of sand and dirt, mostly in the lettuce. They refunded me my money but basically I'm left with feeling like I just took a big bite of dirt covered in peanut sauce. Gross.
author: E P.

description: Great lunch place.  There are a lot of tables, but still has that hole-in-the-wall good food feel.  This place is always crowded and usually has lines out the door on Fridays.  The food comes out fast and is quite tasty whether you are having Pho or one of their other dishes.
author: George C.

description: They do catfish in claypot well, and are open past normal lunch hours which can be a rarity in the financial district.  The family is attentive and tireless in their effort to refill your glass of tea.  A good choice for the everyday meal.
author: Nick M.

description: I've eaten here about 7 times so far, when I'm in the mood for Vietnamese food and it's not feasible for me to go down to SJ for the real stuff.  I agree with some of the other reviewers who mentioned that their bowl of pho  tasted like dish soap.  I've had that happen to me too a couple of times.  I like their rice combinations for a lighter, but filling meal.  I took my roommate here for the first time a couple of weeks ago and she liked that when we ordered the pho and the rice combination to share, they brought out extra bowls and plates for us.  Even though the food is a bland version of real Vietnamese food, they have the basic flavors down and it fulfills my needs temporarily.  My biggest gripe about the place: I hate smelling like the places after I get out.  Oh, and it's recommended to come here 20 minutes before twelve at lunch time. This place fills up fast on the typical cold SF days.  There's usually a line by 12 o'clock.
author: Trinh N.

description: I came here for lunch and it was crowded!  They were pretty busy so I can kinda understand that it took a while for them to notice we were ready to order.  As usual, I got my catfish clay pot...I'm still searching for great catfish claypot that would compare to my first experience with the dish back in SoCal.  I miss the origional catfish claypot....it was sooo good in SoCal.  Anyways, their catfish was a little bland and it just wasn't the greatest.  Probably the worst catfish claypot I've ever had at any vietnamese resturant.  I guess their other dishes could be good.  This joint is quite popular after all...but totally over priced for vietnamese food.  Not surprising since it's in FiDi.  They sure do know their supply and demand curves and take full advantage of it!  I would give this place 3 stars, until the cutest most addorable little baby....ROACH in my friend's to go box.  *barf*   Unfortunately for him, it was too late and he already started to put his food in it.  Ok it's not gonna kill you and hey, maybe it's really hard to keep tiny bugs out resturants.   So, I'll give them a break.  I'll let tiny bugs slide...but the food still wasn't great.
author: Nelson W.

description: great for take out, i usually go at night so i don't really experience the crowds.  i usually get the chicken pho and shrimp springrolls.  awesome.  4 stars bc it's a little pricey.  but delicious
author: Meagan D.
